f.d: @#/ /lung ston pa rtsa ba sum cu pa/
THE ROOT OF GRAMMAR, “THE THIRTY”
by Thumi Sambhota, translated by Tony Duff
@#/ /rgya gar skad du/ byA ka ra Na mU la triM shad nA ma/ bod skad du/ lung ston pa rtsa ba sum cu pa zhes bya ba/
In Sanskrit: vyākaraṇa-mūla-triṃśhad-nāma In Tibetan: ལུང་སྟོན་པ་རྩ་བ་སུམ་ཅུ་པ་ཞེས་བྱ་བ། In English: The Root of Grammar, The Thirty
ngag gi dbang phyug 'jam pa'i dbyangs la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
I prostrate to the Lord of Speech, Mañjughoṣha.

gang la yon tan mchog mnga' ba'i/ / dkon cog de la phyag 'tshal lo/ / gang gis sgra dbyangs kun gsungs pa'i/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs la phyag 'tshal lo/ / gang gis ming gzhi sngon gsungs pa/ / rtag zhi ba la phyag 'tshal lo/ / sdeb sbyor legs mdzad mkhas rnams dang / / bla ma la yang phyag 'tshal nas/ /

To the ones that have supreme qualities, The Jewels, I prostrate. To the one who speaks all verbal sounds, Mañjughoṣha, I prostrate. To the elicitor in the past of the bases of words, Sadāśhivaḥ, I prostrate. To the experts who made correct composition And also to the guru, I prostrate. That done …
bslab pa kun gyi gzhi 'dzin cing / / rig byed smra ba rnams kyi rgyu/ / ming tshig rjod pa kun gyi gzhi/ / yi ge'i sbyor ba bshad par bya/ /
It forms the basis underlying the trainings and is The cause of the expounders of the Vedas; The basis underlying names, phrases, and expressions The connecting of letters will be explained.
yi ge A li kA li gnyis/ / A li gsal byed i sogs bzhi/ / kA li sum cu tham pa 'o/ /
de la rjes 'jug bcu yin te/ / de las lnga ni sngon du'ang 'jug / mi 'jug pa ni nyi shu'o/ /
kA li phyed dang brgyad sde ni/ / bzhi bzhi dag tu phye ba las/ / dang po gsum pa bzhi pa la/ / mas gnyis drug pa'i gsum pa dang / / bdun pa la ni sha ma gtogs/ / rjes 'jug yi ge bcu ru 'dod/ /

The kāli are in eight sections, one a half, Through division into lots of four from which The first, the third, and the fourth’s Bottom two; the third of the sixth; and Excluding ཤ་ sha, the remainder of the seventh Are declared to be the ten suffix letters.
rjes 'jug yi ge bcu nyid las/ / dang po gsum pa lnga pa drug / bdun pa rnams ni sngon du'ang 'jug /
Of the ten suffix letters themselves, The first, third, fifth, sixth, and Seventh ones are also pre-fixed.
ming gzhi gnyis sam gsum sbrel lam/ / de la dbyangs kyi bzhi ldan yang / / gang du'ang 'jug min sbyar ba'ang min/ /
Two name-bases or three linked or A vowel to that to make a four-part Are nowhere placed nor connected.
rjes 'jug yi ge bcu po ni/ / ming gang gi ni mthar sbyar ba/ / de la A li bzhi pa sbyar/ / slar bsdu bar ni shes par bya/ /
The ten suffix letters Connected at the end of a name Have the fourth āli connected to them To be known as “concluders”.

rjes 'jug yi ge bcu rnams las/ / gang ming mtha' na bcu pa gnas/ / de la A li gnyis pa sbyar/ / gang ming mtha' na brgyad pa gnas/ / de la gnyis pa u yang sbyar/ / gang ming mtha' na gsum pa gnas/ / de la A li gnyis pa sbyar/ / bzhi pa dgu pa dngos kyang ste/ / las dang ched dang rten gnas dang / / de nyid tshe skabs la sgra yin/ /
rjes 'jug yi ge bcu po la/ / i dang mthun lugs 'di zhes bya/ /
For the ten suffix letters, The system of harmony possessing ཨི་ I will be thus.
dang po gnyis la dang po mthun/ / gsum lnga bcu la kya dang sbyar/ / bdun pa nyid la bdun pa ste/ / lhag ma rnams la gya sbyar ba/ /
de dag i sbyar 'brel ba'i sa/ /
Those, with ཨི་ connected, are the site of the connective.
de nyid la ni bcu pa sbyar/ / byed pa po ru shes par bya/ / A li phyis nas gnyis pa sbyar/ / tshig rgyan gnyis dang sdud par 'gyur/ /
Those themselves with ས་, the tenth, connected Are to be known as “the agent”. The āli erased then the second connected Becomes two phrase ornaments and inclusion.
la don su la u phyis nas/ / de la gsum pa'i dang po sbyar/ / de la A li gsum pa sbyar/ / de ni lhag dang bcas pa'o/ /
Having erased the ཨུ་ on la-equivalent སུ་, The first of the third is connected to it, And the third āli is connected to that; That is a continuative.
rjes 'jug yi ge bcu po la/ / drug pa sbyar na 'byed sdud yin/ /
The ten suffix letters with The sixth connected are separation-inclusion.
rjes 'jug yi ge bcu po yi/ / bzhi pa dgu pa la bcu pa/ / sbyar ba 'byung khungs sa yin te/ / dgar dang sdud pa'ang de bzhin yin/ /
The ten suffix letters’ Fourth and ninth with the tenth Connected are the site of the source; They are also, likewise, segregation and inclusion.
gang ming brjod pa'i dang po ru/ / kye sbyar ba ni bod pa yin/ /
Initial to the expression of some name The connection of ཀྱེ་ is calling.
gang ming mtha' dang mthun pa yi/ / bzhi pa la ni i sbyar ba/ / dgar dang brnan pa'i tshig tu 'gyur/ /
In harmony with the ending of whatever name The fourth, by having an ཨི་ connected to it, Becomes a word of segregation and highlighting.
ming gang rung ba'i bar mtshams su/ / gsum pa la ni gnyis pa sbyar/ / de ni sdud dang 'byed pa dang / / rgyu mtshan tshe skabs gdams ngag lnga'o/ /
At the places between whatever names, The third has the second connected to it; That is the five of congregation, separation, Reason, timing, and verbal instruction.
gang ming gi ni ya mtha' ru/ / gsum pa la ni e sbyar ba/ / tha snyad dbang du gsum yin te/ / dngos po'i dbang du bzhi ru 'gyur/ / dus kyi dbang du gnyis yin no/ /
At upper end of some name, The third having ཨེ་ connected to it, From the standpoint of convention is three; From the standpoint of thing becomes four; and From the standpoint of time is two.
gang ming brjod pa'i dang po ru/ / dang po la ni gnyis pa sbyar/ / spyi la khyab pa nyid du 'gyur/ /
Initial to the expression of some name The first having the second connected Becomes the encompassing generality itself.
gang ming gi ni ma mtha' na/ / pu ling+ga yi sgra med pa/ / de la pu ling+ga sbyar na/ / bdag po'i sar ni shes par bya/ /
When to the lower end of some name Without pulinga term A pulinga is connected, that Is to be known as “the site of the owner”.
gang ming brjod pa'i ya mtha' na/ / s+t+rI ling+ga yi sgra med pa/ / de la s+t+rI ling+ga sbyar na/ / dgog pa'i gnas su shes par bya/ /
When to the upper end of some name Without strīlinga term A strīlinga is connected, that Is to be known as “the position of negation”.
tshigs su bcad pa'i mtshams sbyor rnams/ / cung zad bsdus pa yod na yang / / de ni de bzhin sbyar bar bya/ /
The junctures contained In the verses are few however It is how they are to be connected.

sngon 'jug yod dam med kyang rung / / ming gzhi'i yi ge gang yin la/ / nyis 'brel yod dam sum 'brel yod/ / A li bzhi las gang ldan yang / / rjes 'jug bcu po ma zhugs na/ / ming gzhan sbyor ba yod mi srid/ /

Whether there are prefixes or not, A name-base letter whatever it is Might be in double or triple relationship And might have any one of the four āli but Unless one of the ten suffixes is in place, Connection to another name will not be possible.
rjes 'jug bcu yi don shes na/ / 'bri dang klog dang bshad rnams kyi/ / mtshams sbyor sgra la thogs med cing / / 'brel ba smra ba'i mchog tu 'gyur/ /
If the meaning of the ten suffixes is known, When writing, reading, and explaining, There will not be any hindrance to juncture’s terms and There will be the excellence of related exposition.
gzhan yang rjes 'jug shes pa yis/ / don gyi sbyor ba ma mthong yang / / don dang mthun pa'i sbyor ba shes/ /
Furthermore, by knowledge of the suffixes, Though connections of the meaning have not been seen Connections according to the meaning will be known.
rjes 'jug sbyor ba mkhas pa na/ / lung gi don dang sbyor ba dang / / bla ma'i man ngag gsum sbyar nas/ / don gyi thog tu dbab par bya/ /

Having become expert in the connections of suffixes, The meaning of scripture and connection and The guru’s foremost instructions will, all three, come together; You should thus alight right on the meaning.
bslab la brtson pa'i gang zag gis/ / dang por nga ro rnams la sbyang / / sngon 'jug ming gzhi rjes 'jug gsum/ / klog gi ched du bslab pa yin/ /
Persons wanting to put effort into a discipline First must learn the tones then The threefold prefixes, name-bases, and suffixes Will be their training for reading.
rjes 'jug bzhi yi sbyor ba ni/ / mnyan bsam bstan pa'i don du sbyar/ /
The four connections of suffixes will connect Them to listening, contemplating, and teaching.
yan lag de dag mthu yis ni/ / 'bras bu'i ched du don la dbab/ /
By means of those branches and for the sake Of the fruit, they will seek the meaning.
bslab pa'i rim pa 'di yis ni/ / gang zhig 'bad pa chung ngus kyang / / shes rab myur du grol bar 'gyur/ /
Through this sequence of the trainings Someone of even small effort will Quickly have his understanding opened.
de phyir dang por 'di nyid bslab/ / de nas rgyas pa'ang mnyan byas te/ / bslab pa gang la dad pa yi/ / gzhung nyid bla ma dag las mnyan/ /
Therefore, first train in this one Then, having listened also to extensive ones, For the training in which you have faith, Hear its main texts from the gurus.
slob dpon de nyid du 'dzin cing / / le lo g.yeng ba rnam par spangs/ / zo bzang dad pa la brten pa/ / skyes bu des ni myur rtogs te/ / de la dus su 'doms par bya/ / cig shos de las ldog pa'o/ /

A being who accepts the āchārya as such, Who completely abandons laziness and distraction, And who depends on fine, good character and faith Does thereby become quickly realized so He should be instructed over time; The opposite one is the reverse.
de ltar kun gyis rtogs gyur cig /
byA ka ra Na'i rtsa ba zlo ka sum cu pa zhes bya ba slob dpon a nus mdzad pa rdzogs so// //
“The Root of Grammar, The Thirty” by Āchārya Anu is complete.
@#/ /lung ston pa rtags kyi 'jug pa/
GRAMMAR, THE APPLICATION OF GENDER SIGNS
by Thumi Sambhota, translated by Tony Duff
@#/ /rgya gar skad du/ byA ka ra Na ling+ga pa tA ra nA ma/ bod skad du/ lung ston pa rtags kyi 'jug pa zhes bya ba/
In Sanskrit: vyākaraṇa lingāvatāra nāma In Tibetan: ལུང་སྟོན་པ་རྟགས་ཀྱི་འཇུག་པ་ཞེས་བྱ་བ། In English: Grammar, The Application of Gender Signs
byA ka ra Na'i dbang phyug la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
I prostrate to the lord of Grammar.
smra ba'i skyes mchog smra ba'i rgyal/ / thams cad mkhyen la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
I pay homage to the supreme speaker, The king speaker, the omniscient one.

pho yi yi ge 'ba' zhig la/ / sde ba phyed dang brgyad gnas pa'ang / / sde tshan lnga ru dril byas nas/ / pho dang ma ning mo dang ni/ / shin tu mo dang bzhi bzhi ru/ / sde ba bzhi pa yan chad dbye/ / lhag ma bcu bzhi gnas pa la/ / tsa sogs gsum ni ca sogs sbyar/ / wa ni ba dang sbyar bar bya/ / lhag ma drug ni mo ru sbyar/ / ra la ha ni mo gsham ste/ / a ni mtshan med ces kyang bya/ /

The male letters only allocated into Eight sections, one a half, also Having been condensed into five groups, Are divided into fours of the four Male, neutral, female, and extremely female Up to the end of the fourth section; For the fourteen left as the remainder, The three ཙ་, and so on, are connected with ཅ་, and so on, The ཝ་ is connected with བ་, Six of the rest are connected to female, The ར་, ལ་, and ཧ་ are called “barren”, And ཨ་ is also called “characterless”.
mo yi yi ge'i nang nas ni/ / 'jug pa'i yi ge bcu dbyung bya/ / 'jug pa bcu yi nang nas ni/ / sngon 'jug yi ge lnga dbyung bya/ /
The ten letters for suffixing will be Drawn from the female letters And the five prefix letters will be Drawn from the ten suffixes.
sngon 'jug yi ge lnga bo la/ / pho dang ma ning mo dang ni/ / shin tu mo dang bzhi ru dbye/ / de dag re re'ang bzhi byed de/ / gang la 'jug byed gang gis byed/ / ji ltar 'jug byed ci phyir byed/ /

The five prefix letters Are divided into four: Male, neutral, female, and extremely female. Each of those also has four do’s: To which does it affix; which does it; How does it affix; and why is it done?
gang la 'jug par byed ce na/ / pho ni pho dang mo la 'jug / mo ni mo dang ma ning la/ / ma ning yang ni pho mo la'o/ /
If you ask, “To which does it affix?” Male is affixed to male and female; Female to female and neutral; and Neutral also to male and female.
shin tu mo ni ma ning dang / / mo dang shin tu mo nyid la'o/ / mi 'jug pa ni 'di lta ste/ / pho ni ma ning la mi 'jug / mo ni pho la 'jug pa min/ / ma ning rang la rang mi 'jug /
rang gi sde dang 'phrad pa na/ / pho yang mo la 'jug mi 'gyur/ / ma ning mo yang de bzhin no/ /
If it is in contact with its own section: It is not affixed to either male or female. Neutral and female are also like that.
ji ltar 'jug par byed ce na/ / pho ni drag pa'i tshul gyis te/ / ma ning ran par 'jug pa yin/ / mo ni zhan pa'i tshul gyis te/ / shin tu mo ni mnyam pas so/ /
If you ask, “How does it affix?” Male is via a stronger way and Neutral is moderate affixation. Female is via a weaker way and Extremely female is via a flat one.
ci phyir 'jug par byed ce na/ / pho ni 'das dang gzhan bsgrub phyir/ / ma ning gnyis ka da ltar ched/ / mo ni bdag da ma 'ongs phyir/ / shin tu mo ni mnyam phyir ro/ /
rjes 'jug yi ge bcu po la/ / pho mo ma ning gsum du dbye/ / pho la skyes bu rab 'bring gsum/ / mo la mo dang shin tu mo/ / ma ning 'gyur dang mtshan gnyis dang / / mtshan med dag dang gsum du 'dod/ /
de yang byed pa bzhi byed de/ / gang la 'jug byed gang gis byed/ / ji ltar 'jug byed ci phyir byed/ / gang la yi ge thams cad la/ / gang gis bcu po de dag gis/ /
Further, it is done with four do’s: To which does it affix; which does it; How does it affix; and why is it done? To which? To all letters. By what? Those ten.
ji ltar rnam pa gnyis yin te/ / sgra yi 'jug tshul don gyi tshul/ / pho gsum mo gnyis ma ning gsum/ / drag zhan bar ma gsum du 'jug /
How has two aspects: Way of affixation by sound and way by meaning. Three male, two female, and three neutral Are affixed as three—stronger, weaker, and moderate.
drag pa gsum nyid nang phrad dam/ / gal te zhan pa nang phrad na/ / de la'ang nang gi cha shas kyis/ / de yang drag zhan gnyis su dbye/ /
For the stronger three, internal contact, and For the weaker, if there is internal contact, In addition the internal factor is used To divide them further into two, stronger and weaker.

ma ning gsum du gang gtogs pa/ / drag dang phrad na drag par 'gyur/ / zhan dang phrad na zhan par 'gyur/ / gnyis ka dag dang phrad gyur na/ / de ni gnyis ka can du 'gyur/ / gnyis ka dag dang ma phrad na/ / gang du yang ni mi 'gyur ro/ /

What has been incorporated in the three neutrals is: If contact is with stronger, it changes to stronger; If contact is with weaker, it changes to weaker; If contact is with both, It changes to something that has both; and If it has not contacted either, It does not change to either at all.

des na 'gyur dang mtshan gnyis dang / / mtshan med dag dang gsum du 'dod/ / de ni sgra yi 'jug tshul lo/ / don ni rnam pa gnyis yin te/ / snga ma gang ltar gyur pa dang / / phyi ma gang ltar 'gyur ba 'o/ /

Therefore, it is held to be three: changeable, Dual-character, and characterless. That is the way of affixation of sound. Meaning has two aspects: The way that the prior one changed; The way that the subsequent one will change.
snga ma sngon 'jug lnga bzhin sbyar/ / phyi ma dag gi 'dren tshul ni/ / pho yis pho yi ming mtha' drang / / mo yis mo yi ming mtha' drang / / ma ning gis ni ma ning ngo / /

ming mtha' de dag nyid kyis ni/ / de nyid rang gi sgra mthun pa'i/ / chos dngos las dang byed pa dang / / sbyin dang 'byung khungs 'brel ba dang / / gnas dang bod pa'i sgra yang drang / / gzhan yang slar bsdu lhag bcas dang / / 'byed sdud bsnan dang bdag po dang*/ / dgag sgrub rgyun dang dus la'ang 'jug /

Those name endings themselves draw Their own concordant terms of Things, objects, agents, Giving, source, connection, Place and calling terms. And, furthermore, concluders, continuatives, Separators, includers, emphasisers, and owners, Negators, accomplishers, and timings also are affixed.
de dag snga shugs 'dren pas 'byung / / de dag nang gses gang 'jug pa/ / mtha' sbyar 'og ma'i ming don las/ /
Those come drawn by force of the prior one. Which of those sub-divisions will be affixed comes From the name equivalent to be connected beyond, at its end.

spyir 'jug yod dam byed pa yod/ / de bzhin ched byed rten byed dang / / las bya blang bya bsgrub par bya/ / sngon du 'os pa gnas pa 'am/ / gzhan yang tshig don 'og ma las/ / bsdu rgyu yod dam med pa dang*/ / gong ma las kyang de bzhin te/ / rnam grangs dag kyang bkod pa las/ /

There is generality affixing and there is doing, Likewise does purpose, does support, and Karma to be done, acceptance to be done, accomplishment to be done, Prior is a suitable position, and Furthermore, from the phrase equivalent beyond, There is to be included or not and Likewise from the one before, too, From an arrangement of enumerations, too,

bskyar ba yod dam med pa dang / / pho sgra dang ni mo sgra dag / ming gi mtha' na yod med dang / / rgyan du gyur pa rnams la yang / / don la bsnyegs pa yod med dang*/ / bstan bya lhag ma yod med dang / / tshig don rdzogs dang ma rdzogs kyis/ / de dag nang gses rnam par dbye/ /

Whether there is repetition or not, and Whether male terms and female terms Are at the end of the word or not, and For the ones become ornaments also Whether they follow up to a meaning or not, and Whether there is extra to be shown or not, and Whether the phrase equivalents are complete or not. Thereby, their sub-divisions are completely dissected.
ci phyir 'jug par byed ce na/ / yi ge'i khongs nas ming dbyung ste/ / ming gi khongs nas tshig phyung nas/ / tshig gis don rnams ston par byed/ /
If you ask, “Why is the affixing done?” From the letters, names are drawn, From the names, phrases are drawn, then Phrases are what show meanings.
mo yi yi ge med pa na/ / pho yig brjod pa med par 'gyur/ / pho yig de dag rnams la yang / / 'jug par bcas pa med na ni/ / ming dang tshig kyang gsal mi nus/ /
If female letters were not to exist, Male letters would become inexpressible, And if those male letters were To become without affixation, then Names and phrases also could not be distinct.

ming tshig gsal ba med na ni/ / don rnams brjod par mi 'gyur ro/ / de ltar gyur na 'jig rten du/ / don mtshon brjod pa kun kyang med/ / rig byed smra ba'ang yod mi 'gyur/ / nyan thos rang rgyal sangs rgyas kyi/ / bslab pa rnams kyang med par 'gyur/ /

If names and phrases were not distinct, Then meanings would become inexpressible. If that happened, the world would be totally Without expressions conveyingmeaning; The propounders of the Vedas would not exist; And the shrāvaka-, pratyeka-, and buddha- Trainings also would become non-existent.
ji ltar 'jig rten sems can rnams/ / phung po khams dang skye mched dang*/ / grub mtha' gzhan yang yod na yang / / rang nyid kyis ni mi shes bzhin/ /
How would it be, sentient beings of the world Having skandhas, dhātus, ayatanas, and Tenet systems, and furthermore existing yet, Themselves not understanding themselves?

de bzhin yi ge'i 'jug tshul rnams/ / smra ba kun la gnas gyur kyang / / rang tshul de nyid mi shes pas/ / don la sbyor ba ga la shes/ / de phyir smra ba'i dbang phyug gi / rjes smras 'di kun rtogs gyur cig /

Likewise, the ways of affixing letters Might be present in every one who speaks but, How could they, not understanding its ways, Know how to connect them to be meaningful? Therefore may this, spoken following The lords of speech, be comprehended by all.
byA ka ra Na'i rtsa ba brgyad pa las kun tu bzang po'i byA ka ra Na gnyis pa'i skabs te drug pa'o// //
Of the eight roots of grammar at the time of the second grammar of Samantabhadra, this is the sixth.
thon mi'i legs bshad sum cu pa'i snying po ljon pa'i dbang po bzhugs so/ /
“THE GREAT LIVING TREE” THE ESSENCE OF THONMI’S FINE EXPLANATION THE THIRTY
by Yangchen Drubpay Dorje, translated by Tony Duff
@#/ /na mo gu ru many+dzu g+ho Sha ya/
Namo Guru Mañjughoṣhaya.
bla ma mchog dang dbyer med pa'i/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs la gus btud nas/ / thon mi'i legs bshad sum cu pa'i/ / snying po mdor bsdus bshad par bya/ /
I respectfully bow to the supreme guru Who is inseparable from Mañjughoṣha and Having done so, will explain in a brief way The essence of Thonmi’s fine explanation, The Thirty.
dbyangs kyi bya ba gsal po ru/ / byed pa i u e o bzhi/ / gsal byed ka sogs sum cu yin/ /
The exhibitors of vowel function Are the four ཨི་, ཨུ་, ཨེ་, and ཨོ་. The consonants are the thirty of ཀ་ and so on.
ga nga da na ba ma 'a/ / ra la sa rnams rjes 'jug bcu/ /
ག་ང་ད་ན་བ་མ་འ་ར་ལ་ and ས་ are the ten suffixes.
da dang sa gnyis yang 'jug ste/ / da ni na ra la gsum dang / / sa ni ga nga ba mar 'thob/ / ga da ba ma 'a sngon 'jug/
ད་ and ས་ both are re-suffixes; ད་ is obtained with ན་ར་ལ་ and ས་ is obtained with ག་ང་བ་ and མ་. ག་ད་བ་མ་ and འ་ are the prefixes.
go ngo do no bo mo 'o/ / ro lo so to slar bsdu ste/ / rdzogs tshig zla sdud ces kyang bya/ /
གོ་ངོ་དོ་ནོ་བོ་མོ་འོ་རོ་ལོ་སོ་ and ཏོ་ are the concluders, Also called completing words and coupled concluders.
drag yod to dang mtha' med 'o/ / gzhan rnams ming mtha'i rjes mthun sbyar/ /
ཏོ is connected when there is a forceful ending; འོ when there is no ending; And the others to be concordant with the suffix at name’s ending.
su ra ru du na la tu/ / la don rnam pa bdun yin te/ / rnam dbye gnyis bzhi bdun pa dang / / de nyid tshe skabs rnams la 'jug/
sa su ga ba drag mthar tu/ / nga da na ma ra la du/ / 'a dang mtha' med ra dang ru/ /
gi kyi gyi 'i yi lnga po/ / rnam dbye drug pa 'brel sgra dang / / de rnams sa mtha' can lnga ni/ / rnam dbye gsum pa byed sgra ste/ /
The five གི་ཀྱི་གྱི་འི་ and ཡི་ are the sixth case, “connective terms” and Those five with a ས་ ending are the third case, “agentive terms”.
sbyor tshul na ma ra la gyi/ / da ba sa kyi ga nga gi/'a dang mtha' med 'i dang yi/ /
kyang yang 'ang gsum rgyan sdud de/ / ga da ba sa drag mthar kyang / / nga na ma ra la mthar yang / / 'a dang mtha' med 'ang dang yang / /
The three ཀྱང་ཡང་ and འང་ ornament and include: ག་ད་བ་ས་ and forceful endings get ཀྱང་; ང་ན་མ་ར་ and ལ་ endings get ཡང་; and འ་ and no ending get འང་ and ཡང་.
te de ste gsum lhag bcas te/ / na ra la sa drag mthar te/ / da de ga nga ba ma 'a/ / mtha' med rnams la sa ste 'thob/ /
The three ཏེ་དེ་སྟེ་ are continuatives: ན་ར་ལ་ས་ and forceful endings get ཏེ་; ད་ gets དེ་; ག་ང་བ་མ་འ་ and No ending gets ས་ as སྟེ་.
gam ngam dam nam bam mam 'am/ / ram lam sam tam 'byed sdud de/ / sbyor tshul slar bsdu'i skabs dang mtshungs/ /
གམ་ངམ་དམ་ནམ་བམ་མམ་འམ་རམ་ལམ་སམ་ and ཏམ་ separate and include; Their mode of connection is the same as concluder’s case.
ra ru 'i yi 'ang yang rnams/ / rkang pa mi skong skong ba'i khyad/ / 'o 'u 'am gyi gong du tsheg/ med dang yod pa'ang de bzhin yin/ /
ར་ and རུ་; འི་ and ཡི་; འང་ and ཡང་ are distinguished Respectively as not verse padding and padding; འོ་ and འུ་ and འམ་ with and without A prior tsheg are also like that.
nas las 'byung khungs dgar sdud de/ / 'byung khungs dngos la gang sbyar 'thus/ / rigs mthun dgar nas mi mthun las/ / sdud la nas sgra kho na 'jug/
kye dang kwa ye bod sgra ste/ / phal cher ming gi thog mar sbyor/ /
ཀྱེ་ and ཀྭ་ཡེ་ are calling terms. They are mostly connected ahead of the names.
ni ni dgar dang brnan pa'i sgra/ / dang ni sdud 'byed rgyu mtshan dang / / tshe skabs gdams ngag lnga la 'jug/
ནི་ is a term of segregation and of highlighting. དང་ has the five uses of inclusion, separation, reason, Timing, and instruction.
ming gi thog ma'i de sgra ni/ / tha snyad 'das ma thag pa dang / / rnam grangs gzhan can gnyis la 'jug/
The དེ་ term at the beginning of a name Has the two uses of immediately preceding convention And accounting for something else.
ci ji su gang spyi sgra ste/ / zhig ste slad 'dra phyir la ci/ / snyed srid ltar bzhin skad la ji/ / su ni gang zag gang kun la'o/ /
na ro yod med pa ba ma/ / bdag po'i sgra ste ga da na/ / ba ma sa dang drag mthar pa/ / nga 'a ra la mtha' med la/ / bdag sgra yar gyur ba dang ni/ / cha la pa nyid sbyor ba legs/ /

པ་བ་ and མ་ with and without naro are terms of the owner. At ག་ད་ན་བ་མ་ས་ and forceful endings, པ་ is obtained. At ང་འ་ར་ and ལ་ for terms of the owner that become far, བ་, And for parts, the connection of པ་ is good.
ming mtha'i pa ba'ang phal cher 'dra/ / ma ni nges med skabs dang sbyar/ /
པ་ and བ་ at name endings also are mostly like that. མ་ is indefinite, connect it as required.
ma mi min med dgag sgra ste/ / ma mi thog ma min med mjug / ma ni bar gyi gsal byed la'ang / /
མ་མི་མིན་ and མེད་ are terms of negation. མ་ and མི་ ahead, མིན་ and མེད་ at the end, And མ་ as an in-between-consonant as well.

tshig phrad zhing sogs nga na ma/ / 'a dang ra la mtha' med mthar/ / zhing zhes zhe 'o zhe na zhig / ga da ba dang da drag mthar/ / cing ces ce 'o ce na cig / sa mthar dmigs bsal zhes ma gtogs/ / shing shig she 'o she na 'thob/ /
'on kyang kha cig lhan cig sogs/ / ming gi cha dang ma nor gces/ /
However, in ཁ་ཅིག་, ལྷན་ཅིག་, and so on, They are part of a name so take care not to err!
rkyang pa 'phul la 'a mtha' dgos/ / gug kyed brtsegs 'dogs can la spang / /
When a bare letter is fronted, an ending འ་ is required; With a hook, bend, superfix, or subfix it is dropped.
lhug pa'i don mang ming mtshams dang / / don 'bring 'byed dang don nyung rdzogs/ / tshigs bcad ga mthar chig shad bya/ /
rdzogs tshig mtha' can lhug pa dang / / tshigs bcad rkang mthar nyis shad 'thob/ / don tshan chen mo rdzogs pa dang / / le'u'i mtshams su bzhi shad dgos/ /
Prose ending in a completing word and Verse at the end of a line gets two shad. At the completion of a great section of meaning and At the close of a chapter, four shad are required.
nga yig ma gtogs yig shad bar/ / tsheg med de sogs zhib tu 'bad/ /
Except for letter ང་, there is no tsheg between a letter and a shad. For those and the rest make an effort for precision.
tshig gi lo mas ma bsgribs shing / / don gyi 'bras bu g.yur za ba'i/ / legs bshad ljon pa'i dbang po 'di/ / dbyangs can grub pa'i rdo rjes spel/ //
This great living tree of fine explanation Which is not obscured by a leafy-ness of words And has fruits of meaning ripe to eat Was propagated by Yangchen Drubpay Dorje.
@#/ /sum cu pa'i snying po'i don gsal byed legs bshad ljon pa'i dbang po bzhugs so/ /

d.crumb: the fine explanation great living tree

f.d: “THE FINE EXPLANATION GREAT LIVING TREE” THE CLARIFIER OF THE MEANING OF THE ESSENCE OF “THE THIRTY”
by Yangchen Drubpay Dorje, trab-nslated by Tony Duff
oM swa sti/ sum cu pa'i snying po'i don mdor bsdus ni/

Oṃ svāsti
The meaning in brief of The Essence of “The Thirty” follows.
na mo gu ru many+dzu g+ho Sha ya/
► “Namo Guru Mañjughoṣhaya …”
zhes pa rgya gar legs sbyar gyi skad yin/ de bod skad du bsgyur na bla ma 'jam pa'i dbyangs la phyag 'tshal lo/ / zhes rgya skad kyis mchod par brjod pa yin/

is Indian Sanskrit language. When translated into Tibetan it is བླ་མ་འཇམ་པའི་དབྱངས་ལ་ཕྱག་འཚལ་ལོ། and when translated into English it is “Homage to Guru Mañjughoṣha”. This is the expression of worship done via Indian language.
bla ma mchog dang dbyer med pa'i/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs la gus btud nas/ /
► “I respectfully bow to the supreme guru Who is inseparable from Mañjughoṣha and …”
zhes pa rang gi bla ma dang rje btsun 'jam pa'i dbyangs ngo bo dbyer med du bltas nas phyag 'tshal ba ste bod skad kyis mchod par brjod pa yin/
is a prostration made while seeing my guru and Jetsun Mañjugho- ṣha inseparable in essence. This is the expression of worship done via Tibetan language.
thon mi'i legs bshad sum cu pa'i/ / snying po mdor bsdus bshad par bya/ /
► “Having done so, will explain in a brief way The essence of Thonmi’s fine explanation, The Thirty …”
zhes blon po thon mi sam b+ho Ta'i legs bshad sum rtags gnyis nas sum cu pa'i snying po'i don mdor bsdus bshad par bya zhes brtsam par dam bca' ba yin/
means that, of Minister Thonmi Saṃbhoûa’s two fine explanations The Thirty and Gender Signs, I will explain in a brief way the essential meaning of The Thirty. This is the declaration of composition.
dbyangs kyi bya ba gsal po ru/ / byed pa i u e o bzhi/ / gsal byed ka sogs sum cu yin/ /
► “The exhibitors of vowel function Are the four ཨི་, ཨུ་, ཨེ་, and ཨོ་. The consonants are the thirty of ཀ་ and so on.”

zhes pa spyir yi ge la dbyangs dang gsal byed gnyis yod/ de la ma 'dus pa'i yi ge med/ de'i nang nas rang cag bod gangs can gyi skad la nye bar mkho ba A li dbyangs kyi bya ba gsal por byed pa'i i u e o bzhi yod/ mi gsal ba'i tshul du a yang yod/ kA li gsal byed ni ka nas a'i bar sum cu yin/

In general, letters are made up of both vowels and consonants. There are no letters not included within these two. Within them, our language of Snowy Tibet has for its requisites four exhibitors of the function of the āli vowels: ཨི་, ཨུ་, ཨེ་, and ཨོ་. There is also an ཨ་ “a” which is present in an un-exhibited way. The kāli consonants going from ཀ་ through ཨ་ are thirty in number.
ga nga da na ba ma 'a/ / ra la sa rnams rjes 'jug bcu/ /
► “ག་ང་ད་ན་བ་མ་འ་ར་ལ་ and ས་ are the ten suffixes …”
zhes pa de rnams ming gzhi'i rjes su 'jug pas na rjes 'jug bcu yin te dper na/ rtag/ bzang /bshad/ mdun/ btab/ bsam/ mda'/ shar/ dpal/ byas lta bu/
They are placed after the name-base, therefore they are the ten suffixes. An example of each is contained in རྟག བཟང་། བཤད། མདུན། བཏབ། བསམ། མདའ། ཤར། དཔལ། and བྱས།.
da dang sa gnyis yang 'jug ste/ /
► “ད་ and ས་ both are re-suffixes …”
zhes pa da dang sa gnyis rjes 'jug yin pa ma zad rjes 'jug gi rjes su yang bskyar 'jug pas na yang 'jug yin/ sbyor tshul ni/
Both ད་ and ས་ are suffixes and not only that but, since they both get placed again after suffixes, are also re-suffixes.
da ni na ra la gsum dang / /
► “ད་ is obtained with ན་ར་ལ་ …”
zhes pa yang 'jug da ni rjes 'jug na dang ra dang la gsum gyi mthar 'jug ste dper na/ phyind/ gyurd/ bstsald/ lta bu/
Re-suffix ད་ is placed with endings of the three suffixes ན་, ར་, and ལ་ as in ཕྱིནད། གྱུརད། and སྩལད།.
sa ni ga nga ba mar 'thob/ /
► “And ས་ is obtained with ག་ང་བ་ and མ་”
ces pa yang 'jug sa ni rjes 'jug ga dang nga dang ba dang ma rnams kyi mthar 'jug ste dper na/ rdzogs/ gangs/ btabs/ khams/ lta bu/
Re-suffix ས་ is placed with endings of ག་, ང་, བ་, and མ་ as in རྫོགས། གངས། བཏབས། and ཁམས།.
ga da ba ma 'a sngon 'jug/
► “ག་ད་བ་མ་འ་ are the prefixes …”
ces pa de rnams ming gzhi'i sngon du 'jug pas na sngon 'jug lnga yin te dper na/ gtor/ dpal/ btab/ mkhas/ 'jam/ lta bu/
Those letters are placed before the name-base, therefore they are the five prefixes, as in གཏོར། དཔལ། བཏབ། མཁས། and འཇམ།.
go ngo do no bo mo 'o/ / ro lo so to slar bsdu ste/ / rdzogs tshig zla sdud ces kyang bya/ /
► “གོ་ངོ་དོ་ནོ་བོ་མོ་འོ་རོ་ལོ་སོ་ and ཏོ་ are the concluders, Also called completing words and coupled concluders …”
zhes pa bcu gcig po de rnams la sum cu par slar bsdu dang /dag yig gzhan nas rdzogs tshig dang /smra sgo mtshon char zla sdud zer/ sbyor tshul ni/

In The Thirty those eleven are called “concluders”; in other Pure Letters they are called “completing words”; and in the Speech Door Weapon they are called “coupled concluders”. Their mode of connection is as follows.
drag yod to dang /
► “ཏོ་ is connected when there is a forceful ending;
zhes pa da drag gam da'i yang 'jug yod par to 'thob ste dper na/ phyind to/ /gyurd to/ /bstsald to/ /lta bu/
When there is a forceful ད་, that is, a re-suffixed ད་, ཏོ་ is obtained as in ཕྱིནད་ཏོ། གྱུརད་ཏོ། and སྩལད་ཏོ།.
mtha' med 'o/ /
► འོ་ when there is no ending …”
mtha' rten med sar 'o 'thob ste dper na/ bya'o/ /lta bu/
Where there is no ending འོ་ is obtained, for example, བྱའོ།.
gzhan rnams ming mtha'i rjes mthun sbyar/ /
► “And the others to be concordant with the suffix at the name’s ending …”

zhes pa gzhan rnams ming gi mthar rjes 'jug gang yod kyang de dang mthun par sbyor dgos te dper na/ stag go/ bzang ngo / /bshad do/ /gsan no/ /btab bo/ /bsam mo/ /mda' 'o/ /shar ro/ /gsal lo/ /byas so/ /lta bu/

means that the others must be connected so that they are concor- dant with whatever suffix is present at the name’s ending, as in སྟག་གོ བཟང་ངོ། བཤད་དོ། བསན་ནོ། བཏབ་བོ། བསམ་མོ། མདའ་འོ། ཤར་རོ། གསལ་ལོ། and བྱས་སོ།.
su ra ru du na la tu/ / la don rnam pa bdun yin te/ /
► “སུ་རུ་ར་དུ་ན་ལ་ཏུ་ are the seven la-equivalents.”
zhes pa de rnams la la don gyi rnam dbye bdun zer/ de rnams don gang la 'jug na/
Those seven are called “the seven la-equivalent cases”. What meanings are they used to give?
rnam dbye gnyis bzhi bdun pa dang / / de nyid tshe skabs rnams la 'jug/
► “They are used for cases two, four, and seven, And with identity and timing.”

ces pa/ shar phyogs su 'gro lta bu rnam dbye gnyis pa las su bya ba dang /rtar rtswa byin lta bu rnam dbye bzhi pa dgos ched dang / lha khang du rten gsum yod lta bu rnam dbye bdun pa rten gnas dang /'od du 'tsher lta bu rnam dbye gnyis pa'i nang tshan de nyid dang /nyi ma 'char kha ru 'gro lta bu rnam dbye bdun pa'i nang tshan tshe skabs te don lnga la 'jug/ sbyor tshul ni/
sa su/
► “ས་ gets སུ་ …”
zhes sa mthar su 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ g.yas su/ las su/ lta bu/
that is, an ending ས་ gets སུ་ as in གཡས་སུ། and ལས་སུ།.
ga ba drag mthar tu/ /
► “ག་བ་ and forceful ད་ get ཏུ་ …”
zhes pa de rnams kyi mthar tu 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ 'gag tu/ lag tu/ rgyab tu/ 'gab tu/ kund tu/ sgyurd tu gsol/ bstsald tu gsol lta bu/
that is, ག་བ་ and forceful ད་ endings get ཏུ་, for example, འགག་ཏུ། ལག་ཏུ། རྒྱབ་ཏུ། འགབ་ཏུ། ཀུནད་ཏུ། སྒྱུརད་ཏུ་གསོལ། and སྩལད་ཏུ་གསོལ།.
nga da na ma ra la du/ /
► “ང་ད་ན་མ་ར་ and ལ་ get དུ་ …”
zhes pa drug po de'i mthar du 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ steng du/ bshad du/ mdun du/ lam du/ gser du/ dpal du lta bu/
that is, those six endings get དུ་, for example, སྟེང་དུ། བཤད་དུ། མདུན་དུ། ལམ་དུ། གསེར་དུ། and དཔལ་དུ།.
'a dang mtha' med ra dang ru/ /
► “And འ་ and no ending gets ར་ and རུ་ …”
zhes pa 'a mtha' rten la yod pa dang mtha' rten med par ra dang ru gang rigs 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ rta mdar/ rta mda' ru/ khar/ kha ru lta bu/
that is, when འ་ is at the ending position or when there is no ending, ར་ or རུ་, whichever is appropriate, is obtained, as in རྟ་མདར། and རྟ་མདའ་རུ།, and in ཁར། and ཁ་རུ།.
gi kyi gyi 'i yi lnga po/ / rnam dbye drug pa 'brel sgra dang / /
► “The five གི་ཀྱི་གྱི་འི་ and ཡི་ are the sixth case, “connective terms” …”

zhes pa de rnams sa mtha' med pa ni/ zangs kyi zhag blug lta bu gzhi mthun gyi drug pa dang /steng gi mi lta bu rten brten pa'i 'brel ba dang /lag pa'i sor mo lta bu yan lag can dang yan lag gi 'brel ba sogs rnam dbye drug pa tshig snga phyi 'brel ba'i sgra dang /

These without a ས་ ending are the sixth case, terms that connect preceding and succeeding phrases. In the example ཟངས་ཀྱི་ཞག་བླུག “a bronze butter-tea urn”, the term connects concordant bases; in སྟེང་གི་མི། “the man above”, the term connects support and sup- ported; in ལག་པའི་སོར་མོ། “the hand’s finger”, the term connects something having limbs with its limbs; and so on.
de rnams sa mtha' can lnga ni/ / rnam dbye gsum pa byed sgra ste/ /
► “And those five with a ས་ ending are the third case, “agentive terms” …”

zhes pa gi sogs sa mtha' lnga ni/ rnam dbye gang la sbyor yul de rang gis nye 'gyangs ci rigs su bya ba zhig byed pa'i don rnam dbye gsum pa byed pa po'i sgra ste dper na/ mig gis bltas lta bu bya ba nye bar byas pa dang /mig gis shel rtse'i rtse mo nas phyogs thams cad du yang dang yang du legs par bltas so lta bu bya ba 'gyangs par byas pa'o/ / drug gsum gnyis ka'i sbyor tshul ni/

Those five terms གི་ and so on but with a ས་ ending are third cases, terms of the agent. These cases have the meaning that their recipients—the places to which they are connected—are perform- ing an action, no matter whether the verb of the action is close to the recipient or not; for example in མིག་གིས་བལྟས། “looked with the eyes” where the verb of the action is close by the agent and in མིག་ གིས་ཤེལ་རྩེའི་རྩེ་མོ་ནས་ཕྱོགས་ཐམས་ཅད་དུ་ཡང་དང་ཡང་དུ་ལེགས་པ་ར་བལྟས་སོ། “looked carefully again and again in every direction through a telescope with the eyes” where the verb is far from it.
For both the sixth and the third cases the mode of connection is as follows.
sbyor tshul na ma ra la gyi/ /
► “Their mode of connection is: ན་མ་ར་ and ལ་ get གྱི་ …”

zhes pa de rnams kyi mthar drug gsum gyi 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ mdun gyi/ mdun gyis bltas/ gtam gyi 'go/ gtam gyis bshad/ char gyi zegs ma/ char gyis tshos/ chos dpal gyi phyag/ chos dpal gyis gsungs lta bu/

At those endings, the sixth and third cases get གྱི་, for example: མདུན་གྱི། “the front of” and མདུན་གྱིས་བལྟས། “looked at from the front”; གཏམ་གྱི་འོག “latter part of the story” and གཏམ་གྱིས་བཤད། “explained with a story”; ཆར་གྱི་ཟེགས་མ། “drops of rain” and ཆར་གྱིས་ཚོས། “cooked with rainwater”; ཆོས་དཔལ་གྱི་ཕྱག “Chopal’s hand” and ཆོས་དཔལ་གྱིས་ གསུངས། “Chopal said”.
da ba sa kyi/
► “ད་བ་ and ས་ get ཀྱི་ …”

zhes pa de rnams kyi mthar drug gsum kyi 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ khyod kyi gdong pa/ khyod kyis bshad/ rgyab kyi gos/ rgyab kyis khyer/ gos kyi cha ga/ gos kyis g.yogs lta bu dang /shugs kyis go dgos pa da drag yod par yang kyi 'thob bo/ /

At those endings, the sixth and third cases get ཀྱི་, for example: ཁྱོད་ཀྱི་གདོང་པ་། “your face” and ཁྱོད་ཀྱིས་བཤད། “you explained, explained by you”; རྒྱབ་ཀྱི་གོས། “clothing of the back” and རྒྱབ་ཀྱིས་ཁྱེར། “carried on the back”; གོས་ཀྱི་ཆ་ག “hem of the clothing” and གོས་ཀྱིས་གཡོགས། “covered with clothing (that is, dressed, not naked)”. In addition, it should be understood by implication that a forceful ད་ also gets ཀྱི་.
ga nga gi/
► “ག་ and ང་ get གི་ …”
zhes pa de gnyis kyi mthar drug gsum gi 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ bdag gi nor/ bdag gis bshad/ chang gi sbang ma/ chang gis ra ro/ lta bu/

At both of those endings, the sixth and the third cases get གི་, for example: བདག་གི་ནོར། “my wealth” and བདག་གིས་བཤད། “I explained, explained by me”; ཆང་གི་སྦང་མ། “the lees of the beer” and ཆང་གིས་ར་རོ། “intoxicated by beer”.
'a dang mtha' med 'i dang yi/ /
► “འ་ and no ending gets འི་ and ཡི་ …”

zhes pa 'a mtha' rten la yod pa dang mtha' rten med par drug gsum 'i dang yi gang rigs 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ mda'i ltong /mda' yi ltong /mdas bsad/ mda' yis bsad/ kha'i so/ kha yi so/ khas zas/ kha yis zas/

When འ་ is at the ending position or there is no ending, the sixth and third get འི་ or ཡི་ whichever suits as in མདའི་ལྟོང་། and མདའ་ཡི་ལྟོང་། “notch of an arrow”; and མདས་བསད། and མདའ་ཡིས་བསད། “killed by an arrow”; ཁའི་སོ། and ཁ་ཡི་སོ། “teeth of the mouth”; and ཁས་ཟས། and ཁ་ཡིས་ཟས། “ate with the mouth”.
kyang yang 'ang gsum rgyan sdud de/ /
► “The three ཀྱང་ཡང་འང་ ornament and include …”
zhes pa de gsum tshig rgyan gnyis dang /sdud pa'i don gsum la 'jug pa las/
When these are placed they have two meanings as phrase orna- ments and a third meaning as inclusion.
dang po tshig snga phyi mthun par ston pa'i mthun pa'i tshig rgyan la 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ mdzes kyang mdzes/ dri ma kha yang kha/ sha za'ang za lta bu/

Firstly, they are placed as phrase ornaments of concordance in which they show concordance between preceding and succeeding phrases, as in མརྫེས་ཀྱང་མརྫེས། “more beautiful than beautiful!” དྲི་མ་ཁ་ ཡང་ཁ། “a thoroughly bad smell”, ཤ་ཟའང་ཟ། “ate and ate meat”.
tshig snga phyi mi mthun par ston pa'i mi mthun pa'i tshig rgyan la 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ mdzes kyang gos med/ kun gyi lha yang mchod mkhan med/ rgyan dga'ang phyis bdar med lta bu/

Secondly, they are placed as phrase ornaments of non-concor- dance in which they show non-concordance of preceding and succeeding phrases, as in མརྫེས་ཀྱང་གོས་མེད། “beautiful but without good clothes”; ཀུན་གྱི་ལྷ་ཡང་མཆོད་མཁན་མེད། “all the deities but no-one to make offerings”; རྒྱན་དགའང་ཕྱིས་བདར་མེད། “nice jewellery but tarnished”.
kyang sogs kyi nus pas don gzhan zhig sdud pa'i don la 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ lhas kyang btud do/ /sha yang za/ lce'ang tshig lta bu/

Thirdly, ཀྱང་ and so on can include another item when they are placed to have that meaning, as in ལྷས་ཀྱང་བཏུད་དོ། “the gods also bowed”, ཤ་ཡང་ཟ། “Eat meat, too!”, and ལྕེའང་ཚིག་ “burned the tongue as well”.
ga da ba sa drag mthar kyang / /
► “ག་ད་བ་ས་ and forceful endings get ཀྱང་ …”

zhes pa de rnams kyi mthar kyang 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ bdag kyang 'gro/ bshad kyang mi nyan/ rgyab kyang na/ chos kyang shes/ phyind kyang ma bsleb/ bka' bsgyurd kyang mi nyan/ bka' bstsald kyang mi go lta bu/

At those endings ཀྱང་ is obtained, for example, བདག་ཀྱང་འགྲོ། “I will go too”; བཤད་ཀྱང་མི་ཉན། “explained to but not listening”; རྒྱབ་ཀྱང་ན། “back hurt, too”; ཆོས་ཀྱང་ཤེས། “also knew the dharma”; ཕྱིནད་ཀྱང་མ་བསླེབ། “left but not arrived yet”; བཀའ་བསྒྱུར་ཀྱང་མི་ཉན། “was ordered but did not listen to the command”; བཀའ་སྩལད་ཀྱང་མི་གོ “was given explanations but did not understand”.
nga na ma ra la mthar yang / /
► “ང་ན་མ་ར་ and ལ་ endings get ཡང་ …”
zhes pa de rnams kyi mthar yang 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ lha khang yang yod/ lan yang mi 'debs/ lam yang nor/ khar yang bcug/ dpal yang che lta bu/

At those endings ཡང་ is obtained, for example, ལྷ་ཁང་ཡང་ཡོད། “there is a shrine-room, too”; ལན་ཡང་མི་འདེབ། “the reply was bad, too”; ལམ་ ཡང་ནོར། “also mistook the road”; ཁར་ཡང་བཅུག “also put into the mouth”; དཔལ་ཡང་ཆེ། “even greater glory”.
'a dang mtha' med 'ang dang yang / /
► “And འ་ and no ending gets འང་ and ཡང་ …”
zhes pa 'a mtha' rten la yod pa dang mtha' rten med par 'ang dang yang gang rigs thob pa'i dpe ni/ mda'ang shes/ mda' yang shes/ sna'ang ring /sna yang ring /lta bu/

When འ་ is at the ending position or when there is no ending, འང་ or ཡང་ whichever suits is obtained, as in མདའང་ཤེས། and མདའ་ཡང་ཤེས། “knew archery, too”; སྣའང་རིང་། སྣ་ཡང་རིང་། “also was not short- tempered”.
te de ste gsum lhag bcas te/ /
► “The three ཏེ་དེ་སྟེ་ are continuatives …”
zhes pa ming mtha'i ta rkyang te dang /de dang /sa ste gsum mdor bsdu na/ phyag 'tshal te bshad/ chos bshad de go/ song ste bslebs lta bu/ bstan bya lhag ma 'dren pa'i don yin no/ / sbyor tshul ni/

At the end of a name, a bare ཏ་ as ཏེ་ then as དེ་ then with ས་ as སྟེ་ have, in short, the meaning of leading on to something extra that is still to be shown. For example, in ཕྱག་འཚལ་ཏེ་བཤད། “prostrated then spoke”; ཆོས་བཤད་དེ་གོ “the dharma was spoken and under- stood”; སོང་སྟེ་སླེབས། “departed then arrived”. Their mode of connection is as follows.
na ra la sa drag mthar te/ /
► “ན་ར་ལ་ས་ and forceful endings get ཏེ་ …”
zhes pa bdun po de'i mthar ta rkyang te 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ nyan te go/ 'phar te 'gro/ dgra btul te yong /rngos te tshig/ phyind te bslebs/ chos bsgyurd te bshad/ bstsald te yi rang lta bu/

At those six endings, bare ཏ་ as ཏེ་ is obtained as in ཉན་ཏེ་གོ “listen and understand”; འཕར་ཏེ་འགྲོ། “got up and left”; དགྲ་བཏུལ་ཏེ་ཡོང། “overcame the enemies then returned”; རྔོས་ཏེ་ཚིག “cut down and burn (after the harvest); ཕྱིནད་ཏེ་བསླེབས། “left and arrived”; ཆོས་བསྒྱུར་ཏེ་བཤད། “translated and spoke the dharma”; སྩལད་ཏེ་ཡི་རང་། “pleased and accepted what was told”.
da de/
► “ད་ gets དེ་ …”
zhes pa da'i mthar de 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ bsad de za lta bu/
At that ending, དེ་ is obtained as in བསད་དེ་ཟ། “kill and eat”.
ga nga ba ma 'a/ / mtha' med rnams la sa ste 'thob/ /
► “ག་ང་བ་མ་འ་ and no ending get ས་ as སྟེ་ …”
ces pa drug po de'i mthar sa ste 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ chu bkag ste bskyil/ 'phang ste 'phog/ 'bru btab ste skyes/ don bsam ste sgom/ lung pa'i mda' ste gu yangs/ rdo ste shin tu sra/ lta bu/

At those six endings ས་ as སྟེ་ is obtained as in ཆུ་བཀག་སྟེ་བསྐྱིལ། “the dammed waters pooled together“; འཕང་སྟེ་འཕོག “fired and hit”; འབྲུ་བཏབ་སྟེ་སྐྱེས། “the grain was planted and grew”; དོན་བསམ་སྟེ་སྒོམ། “contemplated the meaning then cultivated it”; ལུང་པའི་མདའ་སྟེ་གུ་ཡངས།”the confluence of the valley was broad and open”; རྡོ་སྟེ་ཤིན་ཏུ་སྲ། “(like) rock; very hard”.
gam ngam dam nam bam mam 'am/ / ram lam sam tam 'byed sdud de/ /
► “གམ་ངམ་དམ་ནམ་བམ་མམ་འམ་རམ་ལམ་སམ་ and ཏམ་ separate and include …”

zhes pa gam sogs bcu gcig po de dbye gzhi thog mar byas nas dbye ba mang po 'byed pa'i don la 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ bum pa'i rgyu ni gser ram/ dngul lam/ zangs sam/ rag gam/ rdza las bya'o lta bu/ dbye gzhi mjug tu byas nas dbye ba mang po sdud pa'i don la 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ gser ram/ dngul lam/ zangs sam/ rag gam/ rdza las bum pa bya'o lta bu/ yang yin nam min/ yod dam med lta bu/ yin min dang yod med kyi dbye ba 'byed pa 'byed pa'i don du gsungs/ de rnams sbyor tshul ni/

These eleven of གམ་ and so on, are placed to have the meaning of separation of multiple items where they are being separated out of one basis, as in བུམ་པའི་རྒྱུ་ནི་གསེར་རམ། དངུལ་ལམ། ཟངས་སམ། རག་གམ། རྫ་ལས་བྱ་འོ། “The substances used to make pots are gold, silver, brass, bronze, and terracotta”. They are also placed to have the meaning of inclusion of multiple items which are being put into one basis, as in གསེར་རམ། དངུལ་ལམ། ཟངས་སམ། རག་གམ། རྫ་ལས་བུམ་པ་བྱའོ། “Gold, silver, brass, bronze, and clay are used to make pots”.
Additionally, these eleven are stated to have the meaning of separation where the distinctions “is, is not” and “exists, does not exist” are being made, as in ཡིན་ནམ་མིན། “either is or is not” and ཡོད་དམ་མེད། “either exists or does not exist”. Their mode of application is as follows.
sbyor tshul slar bsdu'i skabs dang mtshungs/ /
► “Their mode of connection is the same as concluder’s case …”

zhes pa drag yod tam 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ phyind tam/ gyurd tam/ bstsald tam lta bu/ mtha' rten med par 'am 'thob pa ni/ kha'am lta bu/ gzhan rnams ming mtha'i rjes mthun sbyar/ / zhes pa ming mthar rjes 'jug gang yod kyang de dang mthun par sbyor dgos pa ni/ stag gam/ bzang ngam/ yod dam/ yin nam/ lab bam/ bsam mam/ mtha' 'am/ shar ram/ gsal lam/ byas sam/ lta bu/

“When there is a forceful ད་”, ཏམ་ is obtained as in ཕྱིན་དཏམ། གྱུརད་ཏམ། སྩལད་ཏམ།. “When there is no ending”, འམ་ is obtained as in ཁའམ།. “And the others to be concordant with the suffix at name’s ending” means that the others must be connected so that they are concordant with whatever suffix is present at the name’s ending, as in སྟག་གམ། བཟང་ངམ། ཡོད་དམ། ཡིན་ནམ། ལབ་བམ། བསམ་མམ། མཐའ་འམ། ཤར་རམ། གསལ་ལམ། and བྱས་སམ།.
ra ru 'i yi 'ang yang rnams/ / rkang pa mi skong skong ba'i khyad/ /
► “ར་ and རུ་; འི་ and ཡི་; འང་ and ཡང་ are distinguished Respectively as not verse padding and padding.”

ces pa/ la don gyi ra dang ru/ drug gsum gyi 'i dang yi/ rgyan sdud kyi 'ang dang yang rnams rkang pa kha skong mi dgos na ra dang 'i dang 'ang 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ rang nyid lhar gsal thugs ka nas/ /dpal lha'i phyag gi mda' dar ni/ /lha mo'ang bdag la shin tu dgyes/ /lta bu/ rkang pa kha skong dgos na ru dang yi dang yang 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ rang nyid lha ru gsal nas ni/ /lha yi phyag gi mda' dar ni/ /lha yang bdag la shin tu dgyes/ /lta bu/

There are the la-equivalents ར་ and རུ་, the sixth and third cases འི་ and ཡི་, and the ornament-inclusion terms འང་ and ཡང་. When a line of verse does not need padding ར་, འི་, and འང་ are obtained as in རང་ཉིད་ལྷར་གསལ་ཐུགས་ཀ་ནས། །དཔལ་ལྷའི་ཕྱག་གི་མདའ་དར་ནི། །ལྷ་མོའང་བདག་ལ་ཤིན་ཏུ་དགྱེས།. When a line does need padding རུ་, ཡི་, and ཡང་ are obtained as in རང་ཉིད་ལྷ་རུ་གསལ་ནས་ནི། །ལྷ་ཡི་ཕྱག་གི་མདའ་དར་ནི། ལྷ་ཡང་བདག་ལ་ཤིན་ཏུ་དགྱེས།.
'o 'u 'am gyi gong du tsheg/ med dang yod pa'ang de bzhin yin/ /
► “འོ་ and འུ་ and འམ་ with and without A prior tsheg are also like that.”

zhes pa slar sdu'i 'o dang /ming gi 'u dang /'byed sdud kyi 'am rnams rkang pa kha skong mi dgos na de rnams kyi gong du tsheg mi 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ dpal ldan lha mo'o srung ma'i gtso/ /pad ma'i ze'u 'bru dag las skyes/ /bdud mo'am yang na 'bag mo ste/ /lta bu/rkang pa kha skong dgos na de rnams kyi gong du tsheg 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ 'di ni dpal ldan lha mo 'o/ /ze 'u 'bru las brdzus te skyes/ /lha 'am yang na bdud mo ste/ /lta bu/

When a line of verse does not need padding, the འོ་ of concluders, the འུ་ of names, and the འམ་ of separation-inclusion do not get a tsheg before them as in དཔལ་ལྡན་ལྷ་མོའོ་སྲུང་མའི་གཙོ། །པ་ད་མའི་ཟེའུ་འབྲུ་དག་ལས་སྐྱེས། །བདུད་མོའམ་ཡང་ན་འབའ་མོ་སྟེ།. When a line does need padding, they do get a tsheg before them as in འདི་ནི་དཔལ་ལྡན་ལྷ་མོ་འོ། །ཟེ་འུ་འབྲུ་ལ་བརྫུས་ཏེ་སྐྱེས། །ལྷ་འམ་ཡང་ན་བདུད་མོ་སྟེ།.
nas las 'byung khungs dgar sdud de/ /
► “ནས་ and ལས་ source, segregate, and include …”
zhes pa nas dang las gnyis ni rnam dbye lnga pa 'byung khungs dngos dang /de'i char gtogs dgar gzhi las logs su dgar ba'i don dang /mang po sdud pa'i don la 'jug pa las/ de rnams kyi dbye ba ni/

Both ནས་ and ལས་ are placed to mean the fifth case, actual source. They are also placed to mean its aspects, segregation out from a basis and inclusion of many things. The difference between them is as follows.
'byung khungs dngos la gang sbyar 'thus/ /
► “For actual source, either one may be connected …”
zhes pa 'byung khungs dngos yin na nas dang las gang sbyar kyang 'thus pa'i dpe ni/ sa nas rtswa skyes/ sa las rtswa skyes/ ba las 'o ma 'jo/ ba nas 'o ma 'jo lta bu/ dgar ba la gnyis/

When it is actual source, it is all right to connect either ནས་ or ལས་, for example in ས་ནས་རྩྭ་སྐྱེ། and ས་ལས་རྩྭ་སྐྱེས། “grass grows from the ground” and in བ་ལས་འོ་མ་འཇོ། and བ་ནས་འོ་མ་འཇོ། “milk is obtained from cows”.
In segregation there are two:
rigs mthun dgar nas/
► “Concordant-class segregation gets ནས་ …”
zhes pa dgar gzhi dang dgar chos rigs mthun pa nas ma gtogs las mi 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ lha rnams kyi nang nas brgya byin gzugs mdzes lta bu/

When the basis from which the segregation is made and that which is segregated from it are of concordant class, only ནས་ and never ལས་ is obtained, as in ལྷ་རྣམས་ཀྱི་ནང་ནས་བརྒྱ་བྱིན་གཟུགས་མརྫེས། “of the various gods, Kaushika has the most beautiful form”.
mi mthun las/ /
► “… and non-concordant ལས་.”
zhes pa dgar gzhi dang dgar chos rigs mi mthun pa la las ma gtogs nas mi 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ lha las mi dman lta bu/
When the basis from which the segregation is made and that which is segregated from it are of non-concordant class, only ལས་ and never ནས་ is obtained, as in ལྷ་ལས་མི་དམན། “men are lower than gods”.
sdud la nas sgra kho na 'jug/
► “For inclusion only the term ནས་ is used …”
ces pa sdud pa'i don la nas sgra kho na 'jug pa las las mi 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ spyi gtsug nas rkang mthil gyi bar/ lta bu/
For the purpose of inclusion, the term ནས་ alone is placed, due to which ལས་ is not obtained, as for example in: སྤྱི་གཙུག་ནས་རྐང་མཐིལ་གྱི་བར། “from the top of the head to the soles of the feet”.
kye dang kwa ye bod sgra ste/ /
► “ཀྱེ་ and ཀྭ་ཡེ་ are calling terms …”
zhes pa yul khyad par can la bod pa kye dang /yul mnyam pa la bod pa kwa ye dang /shugs bstan yul dman pa la bod pa kwas dang /wa ye dang /was rnams la 'jug/ sbyor tshul ni/

With a distinguished object, ཀྱེ་ is placed; with an equal object ཀྭ་ཡེ; and it is shown only by implication but with an inferior object ཀས་, ཝ་ཡི་, and ཝས་ are placed. Their mode of connection is that:
phal cher ming gi thog mar sbyor/ /
► “They are mostly connected ahead of the names.”

zhes pa phal che ba 'bod bya gang yin gyi ming gi thog mar sbyor dgos pa'i dpe ni/ kye rgyal po chen po/ kwa ye grogs po/ kwas ma chen/ wa ye chibs dpon/ was bong dpon lta bu/ phal cher gyi shugs bstan skabs 'gar ming gi mthar sbyor dgos pa'i dpe ni/ ngag gi dngos grub stsol cig dbyangs can kye/ /lta bu/

It is necessary to connect these ahead of most names of whoever is to be called, as in ཀྱེ་རྒྱལ་པོ་ཆེན་པོ། “Oh, great king!”, ཀྭ་ཡེ་གྲོགས་པོ། “Oh friend!”, ཀྭས་མ་ཆེན། “Hey, cook …”; ཝ་ཡེ་ཆེ་བ་དཔོན། “Excuse me, you there in charge of the elderly!”; ཝས་བོང་དཔོན། “Oy, you in charge of the donkeys!”. However, it sometimes it must be connected at the end of the name, for example ངག་གི་དངོས་གྲུབ་སྩོལ་ཅིག་དབྱངས་ཅན་ཀྱེ། “Oh Sarasvati, grant me the siddhi of speech!”.
ni ni dgar dang brnan pa'i sgra/ /
► “ནི་ is a term of segregation and of highlighting.”

zhes pa ni dgar gzhi las logs su dgar ba'i don dang /nan tan brnan pa'i don gnyis la 'jug pa las dang po dgar ba'i dpe ni/ sngon 'gro/ dngos gzhi/ mjug gsum las dang po sngon 'gro ni/ lta bu/ gnyis pa brnan pa'i dpe ni/ ja ni byung /mar ni byung /tshwa ni byung /bul ni byung /lta bu/ sdom pa thams cad ldan par ni/ / lta bu tshig gi kha skong rnams kyang brnan pa'i sgrar 'gyur ro/ /

Placement of ནི་ is used for the two meanings of segregation out from a basis of segregation and highlighting. As an example of the first, segregation, སྔོན་འགྲོ། དངོས་གཞི། མཇུག་གསུམ་ལས་དང་པོ་སྔོན་འགྲོ་ནི། “of the three, the preliminaries, main part, and conclusion, the preliminaries for a beginner are:”. And as an example of the second, highlighting, ཇ་ནི་བྱུང་། མར་ནི་བྱུང་། ཇ་ནི་བྱུང་། བུལ་ནི་བྱུང་། “Tea—got that; butter—got that; salt—got that; bul—got that. In wordings like སྡོམ་པ་ཐམས་ཅད་ལྡན་པ་ར་ནི། padding words also become a term that highlights.
dang ni sdud 'byed rgyu mtshan dang / / tshe skabs gdams ngag lnga la 'jug/
► “དང་ has the five uses of inclusion, separation, reason, Timing, and instruction.”

ces pa/ ming gi bar mtshams su yod pa'i dang zhes pa don lnga la 'jug pa las/ dbye gzhi mjug tu yod pa'i sdud pa'i don la 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ mig dang /rna ba dang /sna dang /lce dang /lus rnams ni dbang po'o/ /lta bu/ dbye gzhi thog mar yod pa'i 'byed pa'i don la 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ dbang po lnga ni/ mig dang /rna ba dang /sna dang /lce dang /lus so/ /lta bu/ rgyu mtshan gyi don la 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ yi ge bris pa dang dag byed mkhas min shes so/ /lta bu/ dus brjod pa tshe skabs kyi don la 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ nyi ma shar ba dang 'gro lta bu/ gdams ngag 'doms pa'i don la 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ yi ge bris dang /sum rtags sbyongs dang /dag yig zin dang /lta bu/

The so-called “དང་ dang which sits in between words” is placed to give these five meanings: inclusion into a basis of separation at the end, as in མིག་དང་། རྣ་བ་དང་། སྣ་དང་། ལྕེ་དང་། ལུས་རྣམས་ནི་དབང་པོའོ། “eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and body are sense faculties”; separation out from a basis of separation present at the begin-ning, as in དབང་པོ་ལྔ་ནི་མིག་དང་། རྣ་བ་དང་། སྣ་དང་། ལྕེ་དང་། ལུས་པོ། “the five sense faculties of eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and body”; a reason, as in ཡི་གེ་བྲིས་པ་དང་དག་བྱེད་མཁས་མིན་ཤེས་སོ། “he wrote letters so we knew that he was not good at grammar”; timings that express time, as in ཉི་མ་ཤར་བ་དང་འགྲོ། “we go with the sunrise”; giving a verbal instruction, as in ཡི་གེ་བྲིས་དང་། སུམ་རྟགས་སྦྱོང་དང་། “learn to write, study and Signs, and memorize Pure Letters.”
ming gi thog ma'i de sgra ni/ / tha snyad 'das ma thag pa dang / / rnam grangs gzhan can gnyis la 'jug/
► “The དེ term at the beginning of a name Has the two uses of immediately preceding convention And accounting for something else.”

ces pa ming gi thog mar yod pa'i de sgra don mang por 'jug par bshad kyang mdor bsdu na/ tha snyad 'das pa dang /rnam grangs gzhan can gnyis la 'jug pa las/ dang po brjod tshul de nyid la thad kar btags pa'i dus 'das pa la 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ mi gzhon pa'o/ / de gzugs ring ngo / / de ngo zheng che'o/ / de skad sbom mo/ lta bu/ gnyis pa dngos su mi gsal yang de sgra'i shul du rnam grangs gzhan zhig sbyor rgyu yod pa'i rnam grangs gzhan can la 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ de la ltos shig/ de ma shod cig/ de khyer shog/ lta bu/

The དེ་ term present at the beginning of a name is explained as having many usages with different meanings. However, to summarize them, it is used for both the preceding convention and accounting for something else. It is placed: 1. with just that immediately preceding thing in the flow of expression, as in མི་གཞོན་པ་འོ། །དེ་གཟུགས་རིང་ངོ་། །དེ་ངོ་ཞིང་ ཆེའོ། །དེ་སྐད་སྦོམ་མོ། “The man is young. He is tall. His face is broad. His voice is deep”; 2. to account for something else which is the use of the དེ་ term to stand in for something else which needs to be accounted for even though it is not obvious, as in: དེ་ལ་ལྟོས་ཤིག “Rely on that!”, དེ་མ་ཤོད་ཅིག “Don’t speak of that!” དེ་ཁྱེར་ཤོག “Please carry it!”
ci ji su gang spyi sgra ste/ /
► “ཅི་ཇི་སུ་ and གང་ are terms of generality”
zhes pa ci sogs bzhi po de bye brag ma yin par spyi la khyab pa'i don la 'jug go/ sbyor tshul ni/

Those four, ཅི་ and so on, are placed to give the meaning of encompassing generalities, the non-specifics.
Their mode of connection is as follows.
zhig ste slad 'dra phyir la ci/ /
► “ཅི་ with ཞིག་སྟེ་སླད་འདྲ་ and ཕྱིར་ …”
zhes pa zhig sogs lnga la ci 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ ci zhig/ ci ste/ ci slad/ ci 'dra/ ci'i phyir lta bu dang /zhig la ji zhig lta bu ji sbyar yang rung ngo /
ཅི་ is used with the five, ཞིག་ and the others, as in ཅི་ཞིག ཅི་སྟེ། ཅི་ སླད། ཅི་འདྲ། and ཅིའི་ཕྱིར།. And it is also workable to connect ཞིག་ to ཇི་, as for example with ཇི་ཞིག་.
snyed srid ltar bzhin skad la ji/ /
► “ཇི་ with སྙེད་སྲིད་ལྟར་བཞིན་ and སྐད་ …”
zhes pa snyed sogs lnga la ji 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ ji snyed/ ji srid/ ji ltar/ ji bzhin /ji skad/ lta bu'o/ /
ཇི་ is applied to the five, སྙད་ and the others, as in ཇི་སྙེད། ཇི་སྲིད། ཇི་ལྟར། ཇི་བཞིན། and ཇི་སྐད།.
su ni gang zag/
► “སུ་ to persons …”
ces pa su ni gang zag sems yod la 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ su yin/ su yis zer/ su la yod/ lta bu/
སུ་ is used with sentient persons as in སུ་ཡིན། སུ་ཡིས་ཟེར། and སུ་ལ་ ཡོད།.
gang kun la'o/ /
► “And གང་ to all.”
zhes pa gang sems ldan sems med kun la 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ gang nas yin/ gang zhig yin lta bu/
གང་ is used with everything, both that which has a mind and that which does not have a mind, as in གང་ནས་ཡིན། and གང་ཞིག་ཡིན།.
na ro yod med pa ba ma/ / bdag po'i sgra ste/
► “པ་བ་མ་ with and without naro are terms of the owner …”

zhes pa na ro yod pa'i po dang /bo dang /mo gsum dang /na ro med pa'i pa dang /ba dang /ma ste drug po de sngar ming gi cha shas su med pa/ dol yas/ gyol/ phyug/ 'gag/ lha rtse/ chang/ lta bu la gsar du sbyar na sngar gyi ming don mi ston par/ de'i bdag po'am/ der sdod mkhan lta bu don gzhan zhig ston pa bdag po'i sgra ste dper na/ dol yas po/ gyol po/ phyug mo/ 'gag pa/ lha rtse ba/ chang ma/ lta bu/ de rnams sbyor tshul ni/

There are the three items པོ་, བོ་, and མོ་ with a naro and the three items པ་, བ་, and མ་ without a naro. When those six are connected for the first time to a word that previously did not have such a part—such as དོལ་ཡས། གྱོལ། ཕྱུག འགག ལྷ་རྩེ། and ཆང་། —they are like the owner of or thing present with the name which now shows a meaning that did not show previously. This is the term of the owner, for example in དོལ་ཡས་པོ། གྱོལ་པོ། ཕྱུག་མོ། འགག་པ་། ལྷ་རྩེ་བ། and ཆང་མ།. Their mode of connection is as follows.
ga da na/ / ba ma sa dang drag mthar pa/ /
► “At ག་ད་ན་བ་མ་ས་ and forceful endings, པ་ is obtained …”
zhes pa de rnams la bdag sgra pa 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ g.yag pa/ bzhad pa/ ldan pa/ lab pa/ grong gsum pa/ dbus pa/ phar phyind pa/ dbang bskurd pa/ chu bskyild pa/ lta bu/
At those endings the term of the owner པ་ is obtained as in གཡག་པ་། བཞད་པ་། ལྡན་པ་། ལབ་པ་། གྲོང་གསུམ་པ་། དབུས་པ་། ཕར་ཕྱིནད་པ་། དབང་བསྐུརད་པ་། and ཆུ་བསྐྱིལད་པ་།.
nga 'a ra la mtha' med la/ / bdag sgra yar gyur ba dang ni/ /
► “At ང་འ་ར་ and ལ་ for terms of the owner that become far, བ་ …”
zhes pa lnga po de rnams kyi mtha' can gyi ming dang sdeb sa med pa bdag sgra yar gyur na ba phyed wa 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ kha byang ba/ rta mda' ba/ byang shar ba/ khams dol ba/ gzhis rtse ba/ lta bu/

When names with one of those five endings have no place of addition, the term of the owner becomes something else added farther along in which case the connection of the half བ་ which is a ཝ་, as in ཁ་བྱང་བ། རྟ་མདའ་བ། བྱང་ཤར་བ། ཁམས་དོལ་བ། and གཞིས་རྩེ་བ། is good.
cha la pa nyid sbyor ba legs/ /
► “And for parts, the connection of པ་ is good …”
zhes pa ming dang sdeb sa yod pa bdag sgra cha la song na pa nyid sbyor ba phal cher la legs pa'i dpe ni/ byang pa/ mda' pa/ gur pa/ dol pa/ rtse pa lta bu/
When names have a place of addition, the term of the owner becomes part of the name, in which case the connection of པ་ for the most part is good, as in བྱང་པ་། མདའ་པ་། གུར་པ་། དོལ་པ་། and རྩེ་པ་།.
ming mtha'i pa ba'ang phal cher 'dra/ /
► “པ་ and བ་ as name-endings also are mostly like that.”
zhes pa bdag sgra ma yin pa ming mtha'i pa ba'ang sbyor tshul phal cher de dang 'dra ba/ lag pa/ rkang pa/ lta bu/
The པ་ and བ་ at the end of a name which are not a term of the owner also have a mode of connection which for the most part is like that, as in ལག་པ་། and རྐང་པ་།.
ma ni nges med skabs dang sbyar/ /
► “མ་ is indefinite, connect it on circumstance.”
zhes pa bdag sgra ma ni 'di la 'di 'thob kyi nges pa med pas skabs dang sbyar dgos pa'i dpe ni/ ja ma/ chang ma/ thang ma/ rong ma/ lta bu/
As for the མ་ term of the owner, what gets it is not definite, therefore it is connected as required, as in ཇ་མ། ཆང་མ། ཐང་མ། and རོང་མ།.
ma mi min med dgag sgra ste/ /
► “མ་མི་མིན་ and མེད་ are terms of negation …”
zhes pa bzhi po de sbyar na sbyor yul gyi don de ma yin pa'am med par ston pa'i dgag pa'i sgra yin/ sbyor tshul ni/

When those four are connected to something, they are terms of negation, showing that the meaning of the recipient to which they have been connected is “is not” or “does not exist”.
Their mode of connection is as follows.
ma mi thog ma/ /
► “མ་ and མི་ ahead …”
zhes pa dgag sgra ma dang mi gnyis dgag bya'i thog mar sbyor dgos pa'i dpe ni/ ma yin/ mi 'dug/ lta bu/
The two terms of negation མ་ and མི་ must be connected ahead of that to be negated, as in མ་ཡིན། and མི་འདུག. Then,
min med mjug/
► “མིན་ and མེད་ at the end …”
ces pa dgag sgra min dang med gnyis dgag bya'i mjug tu sbyor dgos pa'i dpe ni/ lha min/ 'dre med lta bu/
The two terms of negation མིན་ and མེད་ must be connected at the end of that to be negated, as in ལྷ་མིན། and འདྲེ་མེད།.
ma ni bar gyi gsal byed la'ang / /
► “And མ་ as an in-between-consonant as well.”

zhes pa dgag sgra ma ni dgag bya'i thog mar sbyor dgos par ma zad dgag bya gnyis kyi bar du sbyar na stod smad gnyis ka dgag nus pa'i bar gyi gsal byed la'ang 'jug pa'i dpe ni/ rta ma bong /ra ma lug/ lta bu/

The term of negation མ་ must be connected ahead of that to be negated but that is not its only use. It is used as an in-between-consonant as well; when connected between two items to be negated, it is able to negate the items on either side of it, as in རྟ་མ་བོང་། “not a horse, not an ass” and in ར་མ་ལུག་ “not a goat, not a sheep”.
tshig phrad zhing sogs/
► “As for the phrase linkers ཞིང་ and so on …”
zhes pa zhing sogs dang /cing sogs dang /shing sogs ni tshig don snga phyi phrad byed lta bu yin/ sbyor tshul ni/
ཞིང་ and the rest, ཅིང་ and the rest, and ཤིང་ and the rest are like linkers that bring together previous and subsequent phrases. Their mode of connection is as follows.
nga na ma/ / 'a dang ra la mtha' med mthar/ / zhing zhes zhe 'o zhe na zhig/
► “ང་ན་མ་འ་ར་ལ་ and no ending get ཞིང་ཞེས་ཞེ་འོ་ཞེ་ན་ཞིག་.”

ces pa nga sogs bdun po de'i mthar zhing sogs lnga sbyor dgos pa'i dpe ni/ song zhing /song zhes zer ro/ / song zhe'o/ / song zhe na/ lha khang zhig yod/ lta bu/ de bzhin du 'byon zhing /bsam zhing /mi 'da' zhing /blo la shar zhing /gsal zhing /zhal la lta zhing /lta bu rigs 'gre/

The five of ཞིང་ and the rest must be connected at the seven endings of ང་ and so on, for example as in སོང་ཞིང་། སོང་ཞེས་ཟེར་རོ། སོང་ཞེའོ། སོང་ཞེ་ན། ལྷ་ཁང་ཞིག་ཡོད། and similarly, but with the type of ending alternated, as in བྱོན་ཞིང་། བསམ་ཞིང་། མི་འདའ་ཞིང་། བློར་ཤར་ཞིང་། གསལ་ཞིང་། and ཞལ་ལ་ལྟ་ཞིང་།.
ga da ba dang da drag mthar/ / cing ces ce 'o ce na cig/
► “ག་ད་བ་ and forceful ད་ endings get ཅིང་ཅེས་ཅེ་འོ་ཅེ་ན་ཅིག་.”

ces pa ga da ba dang da drag yod par cing sogs lnga sbyor dgos pa'i dpe ni/ bkag cing /bkag ces zer ro/ / bkag ce'o/ / bkag ce na/ chu khog cig lta bu/ de bzhin du bshad cing /bkab cing /yind cing /yi ge bskurd cing /chu bskyild cing /lta bu rigs 'gre/

The five ཅིང་ and so on must be connected where there is a ག་ད་བ་ or forceful ད་ for example as in བཀག་ཅིང་། བཀག་ཅེས་ཟེར་རོ། །བཀག་ཅེའོ། །བཀག་ཅེ་ན། ཆུ་ཁོག་ཅིག and similarly, but with the type of ending alternated, as in བཤད་ཅིང་། བཀབ་ཅིང་། ཡིནད་ཅིང་། ཡི་གེ་བསྐུརད་ཅིང་། ཆུ་བསྐྱིལད་ཅིང་།.
sa mthar dmigs bsal zhes ma gtogs/ /
► “ས་ endings, except for special ཞེས་,
zhes pa sa mthar tshig phrad dmigs bsal shes mi sbyor bar zhes sbyor dgos pa'i dpe ni/ chos byas zhes zer ro/ /lta bu/
At ས་ endings, there is the special case of having to connect the phrase linker ཞེས་ instead of ཤེས་ as in ཆོས་བྱས་ཞེས་ཟེར་རོ།.
shing shig she 'o she na 'thob/ /
get ཤིང་ཤིག་ཤེ་འོ་ཤེ་ན་.”

ces pa gzhan sa mthar shing sogs bzhi 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ byas shing / gyis shig/ byas she'o/ / byas she na/ lta bu/ gong gi zhe'o dang / ce'o dang /she'o rnams zer ro zhes pa'i don dang / zhe na dang /ce na dang / she na rnams zer na zhes pa'i don yin/

Except for that, ས་ endings get the four of ཤིང་, ཤིག་, ཤེ་འོ་, and ཤེ་ན་ as in བྱས་ཤིང་།, གྱིས་ཤིག, བྱས་ཤེའོ།, and བྱས་ཤེ་ན།. The ཞེའོ་, ཅེའོ་, and ཤེའོ་ mentioned above have the meaning of ཟེར་རོ། “said” and the ཞེ་ན་, ཅེ་ན་, and ཤེ་ན་ mentioned above have the meaning of ཟེར་ན་ “if it is said, asked”.
'on kyang kha cig lhan cig sogs/ / ming gi cha dang ma nor gces/ /
► “However, in ཁ་ཅིག, ལྷན་ཅིག་, and so on, They are part of a name so take care not to err!”

zhes pa 'on kyang kha cig dang /lhan cig dang /chabs cig dang /thabs cig dang /stabs cig dang /skabs cig sogs ming gi cha shas yin cing tshig phrad min pas de 'dra dang ma nor bar byed pa shin tu gces so/ /
However, in ཁ་ཅིག ལྷན་ཅིག ཆབས་ཅིག ཐབས་ཅིག སྟབས་ཅིག སྐབས་ཅིག and so on, they are not a phrase linker but part of a name, so be very careful not to make an error here.
rkyang pa 'phul la 'a mtha' dgos/ / gug kyed brtsegs 'dogs can la spang / /
► “When a bare letter is fronted, an ending འ་ is required; With a hook, bend, superfix or subfix it is dropped.”

zhes pa gug ces pas gi gu zhabs kyu/ kyed ces pas 'greng bu na ro/ brtsegs zhes pas ra mgo la mgo sa mgo/ 'dogs zhes pas ya ra la wa'i smad 'dogs bzhi ste de rnams gang yang med pa ni rkyang pa yin cing /de 'dra'i rkyang pa yin la 'phul byed sngon 'jug lnga gang yang rung ba yod na 'a mtha' nges par dgos pa'i dpe ni/ dpa' bo/ mda' pa/ 'ga' zhig/ lta bu/ gong du bshad pa'i gug kyed brtsegs 'dogs can la 'a mtha' spong dgos pa'i dpe ni/ sems can g.yi/ gwa pa/ dar ba'i bde/ go byed brda/ rkyang te yu mo/ lta bu/ da ni dbu chen gyi shad dang /dbu med la yang thams cad mkhyen pa d+harma b+ha dra'i phyag bzhes su tsheg shad mdzad pa bcas kyi 'thob tshul ni/

“Hook” means gigu or zhabkyu; “bend” means drengbu or naro; “superfix” means ra-head, la-head, or sa-head; and “subfix” means the four sub-fixes ya, ra, la, and wa.
Whatever does not have any of those at all is “bare” and whenever any of the five prefixes is fronted onto such an bare letter, an འ་ ending is definitely required, for example in དཔ་འ་བོ།, མདའ་པ་།, and འགའ་ཞིག. For letters which do have a hook, a bend, a superfix and-or a subfix as explained above, the affixed འ་ must be dropped as in: སེམས་ཅན་གཡི།, གྭ་པ་།, དར་བའི་བདེ།, གོ་བྱེད་བརྡ།, and རྐྱང་ཏེ་ཡུ་མོ།.
Now regarding the shad of dbu.can and dbu.med too, All-knowing Dharmabhadra considers that tsheg’s and shad’s should be placed as follows.
lhug pa'i don mang ming mtshams dang / /
► “In prose where there is much meaning, at the boundary of a name …”

zhes pa tshig lhug don mang po yod par ming gi skad pa bcad pa lta bu ma yin pa ming gi mtshams su shad dang tsheg shad re 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ rin po che'i za ma tog dang /ngag gi sgron ma dang /li shi'i gur khang sogs la lta bu/

In prose where there is much meaning, a shad or tsheg-shad is not positioned where its placement would cut across a name but at the boundary of the name as in རིན་པོ་ཆེའི་ཟ་མ་ཏོག་དང་། ངག་གི་སྒྲོལ་མ་དང་། ལི་ཤིའི་གུར་ཁང་སོགས་ལ།.
don 'bring 'byed dang / /
► “To divide medium meanings …”
zhes pa don mang nyung 'bring tsam yod na ming don gyi dbye ba 'byed phyir dgos na ming mtshams su shad re 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ sum cu pa dang /rtags 'jug gi lta bu/

Where there is an amount of meaning which is just middling and a shad is needed in order to separate name-equivalents, a single shad is placed at the boundary of the name as in སུམ་ཅུ་པ་དང་། རྟགས་འཇུག་གི་ལྟ་བུ།.
don nyung rdzogs/ /
► “At completed lesser meanings …”
zhes pa don nyung ngu las med na rdzogs mtshams su shad re 'thob pa/ de rang yin/ lta bu/
When a lesser meaning has no more to it, a shad is positioned at each completion boundary as in དེ་རང་ཡིནད།.
tshigs bcad ga mthar chig shad bya/ /
► “And in verse at an ending ག་, a single shad should be made.”
zhes pa tshigs bcad kyi rkang pa'i mthar ga yod na shad re 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ rnam grangs gzhan can gnyis la 'jug/ lta bu/
Verse which has ག་ at the end of the line gets a single shad as in རྣམ་གྲངས་གཞན་ཅན་གཉིས་ལ་འཇུག ། ་་.
rdzogs tshig mtha' can lhug pa dang / /
► “Prose ending in a completing word and …”
zhes pa go ngo do no sogs rdzogs tshig mtha' can gyi tshig lhug la shad gnyis 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ 'di ni rkyang ngo / /lta bu/
Prose that ends in one of the completing words—གོ་, ངོ་, དོ་, ནོ་, etcetera—gets two shad, for example in འདི་ནི་རྐྱང་ངོ་། ། ་་.
tshigs bcad rkang mthar nyis shad 'thob/ /
► “Verse at the end of a line gets two shad.”
ces pa rkang mthar ga med pa'i tshigs bcad thams cad kyi rkang mthar shad gnyis 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ bla ma mchog dang dbyer med pa'i/ /lta bu/
In verse, all lines that do not have ག་ at the end get two shad at the end, as for example in བླ་མ་མཆོག་དང་དབྱེར་མེད་པ་འི། ། ་་.
don tshan chen mo rdzogs pa dang / /
► “At the completion of a great section of meaning and …”
zhes pa don tshan chen mo rdzogs mtshams yin na shad bzhi 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ dag byed gsal ba'i me long rdzogs so// //lta bu/
The completion boundary of a great section of meaning gets four shad, as for example in: དག་བྱེད་གསལ་བའི་མེ་ལོང་རྫོགས་སོ།། །།ལྟ་བུ།.
le'u'i mtshams su bzhi shad dgos/ /
► “At the close of a chapter four shad are required.”
zhes pa le'u'i mtshams su shad bzhi 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ sku bltams pa'i le'u ste dang po'o// //lta bu/
The boundary of a ལེའུ་ chapter, gets four shad as in སྐུ་བལྟམས་པའི་ལེའུ་སྟེ་དང་པོའོ།། །།ལྟ་བུ།.
nga yig ma gtogs yig shad bar/ /tsheg med/
► “Except for letter ང་, there is no tsheg between a letter and a shad”

ces pa dbu chen gyi skabs su mtha'i nga yig dang shad kyi bar du pa dang nor dogs kyi phye tsheg gam nga tsheg 'thob pa'i dpe ni/ ma bsgribs shing /lta bu/ gzhan ma yi ge dang shad kyi bar du tsheg mi byed pa'i dpe ni/ g.yur za ba'i/ lta bu/

In the case of dbu.can only, a “differentiating-tsheg” or “nga- tsheg” is required between a final letter ང་ nga and a shad in order to stop the possibility of that construction being mistaken for པ་, as in མ་བསྒྲིབས་ཤིང་།; other letter-shad combinations do not have a tsheg inserted in between as for example in གཡུར་ཟ་བའི།.
de sogs zhib tu 'bad/ /
► “For those and the rest make an effort for precision.”

ces pa de la sogs pa tshig don phra mo la yang zhib tu brtags shing dpyad nas 'bad dgos so zhes pa ste/ de ltar sum cu pa'i snying po'i don gsal bar byed pa 'di ni blo gsar gzhon nu tshig don zhib cing rgyas pa blo'i ra bar mi gshong ba rnams kyi don du/ rtsa ba nas bshad pa'i tshig don dper brjod dang bcas pa mdor bsdus bzung bde bar bris pa yin pas/ 'di'i tshig don khong du chud pa'i rjes su des rigs 'gre nas dper brjod mang du byed pa dang /sum cu pa'i don rgyas par ston pa'i legs bshad rnams la phra zhing mdzangs la zhib pa'i blo gros kyis yang dang yang du brtags shing dpyad nas sum cu pa'i don la mkhas pa'i pha rol du phyin pa ci nas kyang mdzad 'tshal lo/ /

There are few words here but it is necessary to make an effort to examine and analyse them precisely. This clarifier of the meaning of The Essence of “The Thirty” was written to be an easy to under- stand, condensed explanation of the root with examples for those new, young students whose minds could not accommodate a subtle and vast explanation. Once it has been mastered, I request them please to examine and analyse precisely, over and again, texts with more examples and after that the reference works that extensively show the meaning of The Thirty and so to go by whatever means possible to complete expertise in the meaning of The Thirty.

dgos med tshig gi lo ma ni/ / phang phung g.yo bas ma bsgribs shing / / dgos nges don gyi 'bras bu mchog / ro brgya'i bcud ldan g.yur za ba'i/ / gsal byed legs bshad ljon pa 'di/ / ljon pa kun gyi dbang po ste/ / dbyangs can grub pa'i rdo rje yi/ / blo mchog 'dzin ma'i lto las 'khrungs/ /

This living tree of clarifying explanation, The greatest of all living trees, Not obscured by leafy-ness of un-necessary words Dangling and swaying about And having the supreme fruit, the necessary definitive meaning, Ripe and ready to eat with juice of one hundred flavours, Came to life from the sustenance that maintains the intellect Of Yangchen Drubpay Dorje.
shub+haM/ / dge legs 'phel// //
Shubham!
@#/ /yul gangs can gyi skad kyis brda sprod pa'i bstan bcos sum cu pa dang / rtags kyi 'jug pa'i rnam bshad mkhas mchog si tu'i zhal lung zhes bya ba bzhugs so/ /
SITU’S WORDS
by Ngulchu Dharmabhadra, translated by Tony Duff
@#/ /na mo gu ru many+dzu g+ho ShA ya/ /
Homage to Mañjughoṣha.

yon tan mchog mnga' slu med rin chen gsum/ / ye shes me long gtsug na zla ba dang / / rta dbyangs btsun pa zla ba sam b+ho Ta/ / la sogs 'phags bod mkhas pa'i tshogs spyi dang / / khyad par dam chos 'o ma'i rgyun bzang gis/ / mang thos lung gi lus stobs cher bskyed nas/ / rtogs pa'i bsam 'phel lag rtser smin mdzad pa'i/ / drin can bla ma'i tshogs la gus btud nas/ /

To the Three Precious Ones, Non-deceptive Holders of Supreme Qualities; To wisdom’s mirror Crested with a Moon, To Saṃbhoûa the moon of the masters of melodious vocals, And so on—the assembly of Indian and Tibetan experts in general; And in particular to the assembly of gurus whose kindness Has, based on a strong body of much hearing and scripture generated From an excellent flow of milk of the holy dharma, Developed realization and ripened it in my hand, I respectfully bow.
ming tshig rin chen 'byung gnas sin+d+hu'i bdag/ rig byed rnam bzhi smra ba'i nyer len rgyu/ / bslab gsum myu gu skyed byed rgya mtsho'i gos/ / gang de mdor bsdus tshig gis bshad par bya/ /

Sindhu’s Master, the source of precious things, names and phrases which is The immediate cause of the propounders of the four Vedas and Sprouter of the three trainings clothing the ocean, I will explain in a few, short words.

de la 'dir yul gangs can gyi skad kyis brda sprod pa'i bstan bcos kun gyi ma phyir gyur pa sum rtags gnyis kyi tshig don cung zad tsam bshad pa la gnyis/ sum cu pa bshad pa dang / rtags kyi 'jug pa bshad pa'o/ /

What remains of all the treatises that defined grammar in the language of the Snowy Land, The Thirty and Application of Gender Signs, will be explained here in just a few words. Of the two explanations, first is the explanation of The Thirty.
dang po [sum cu pa bshad pa]
PART 1: THE EXPLANATION OF THE THIRTY VERSES
['di] la gnyis/ bstan bcos rtsom pa la 'jug pa'i yan lag dang / bstan bcos dngos so/ /
dang po [bstan bcos rtsom pa la 'jug pa'i yan lag]
I. The branches created in a śhāstra’s composition
['di] la gnyis/ mtshan don dang / 'gyur phyag go/
dang po [mtshan don] ni/
A. The meaning of the name
The text says:
rgya gar skad du/ byA ka ra Na mU la triM shad nA ma/ bod skad du/ lung ston pa rtsa ba sum cu pa zhes bya ba/
“In Sanskrit: Vyākaraṇa-mūla-trimshad-nāma In Tibetan: ལུང་སྟོན་པ་རྩ་བ་སུམ་ཅུ་པ་ཞེས་བྱ་བ། [In English: The Root of Grammar, The Thirty].”

zhes pa ste/ byA ka ra Na lung ston pa/ mU la rtsa ba/ triM shad sum cu pa/ nA ma zhes bya ba'o/ / de yang sgra'i mtshan nyid lung du ston cing le'u phyi ma rnams kyi rten gzhir gyur pa gang zhig gzhung tshad sh+lau ka sum cur gnas pas de skad ces bya'o/ / 'dir rgya skad smos pa ni rgya gar mkhas pa'i bstan bcos la dper mdzad pa go ba'i ched dang / gzhung tshad sh+lau ka sum cu so gsum yod pa la sum cu pa zhes btags pa ni mchod brjod dang rtsom par dam bca' skabs gzhan dang mthun mong yin pa la dgongs so/ /

Vyākaraṇa is ལུང་སྟོན་པ་ “grammar”; mūla is རྩ་བ་ “root”; trimshad is སུམ་ཅུ་པ་ “The Thirty”; and nāma is ཞེས་བྱ་བ་ “named”. In addition, the title receives its name as follows: this text that concerns the characteristics of terms, that is, grammar, and which becomes the basis for the later sections has thirty verses in it.
The Sanskrit wording is there for the purpose of understanding that this is modelled on the śhāstras of the Indian experts.
Assigning the name “Thirty Verses” to a text whose length is thirty-three śhlokas is done with the intention that the expres- sion of worship and declaration of composition are in a common, separate section.
gnyis pa 'gyur phyag ni/
B. The translator’s homage
The text says:
ngag gi dbang phyug 'jam pa'i dbyangs la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
“I prostrate to the Lord of Speech, Mañjughoṣha.”

zhes pa ste/ bstan bcos 'di 'phags yul nas bsgyur ba'i bstan bcos khungs ma rnams dang mtshungs par 'doms pa'i don du thon mi nyid kyis bsgyur ba'i mdo rgyud rnams dang mthun par 'phags pa 'jam dpal la 'gyur phyag mdzad pa'o/ /

Thonmi, with the meaning that this śhāstra is put together in accordance with the original sources, the śhāstras translated from the Noble Land, and in accordance with sūtras and tantras trans- lated by him, prostrates to Noble Mañjuśhrī.
gnyis pa bstan bcos dngos
II. The actual śhāstra
['di] la gnyis/ gzhung spyi'i yan lag tu mchod par brjod cing bshad par dam bca' ba dang / skabs don sum cu pa nyid rgyas par bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [gzhung spyi'i yan lag tu mchod par brjod cing bshad par dam bca' ba]
A. The branches of texts in general—the expression of worship and the declaration of explanation
['di] la gnyis/ mchod par brjod pa dang / bshad par dam bca' ba'o/ /
dang po [mchod par brjod pa]
1. The expression of worship

['di] la bzhi/ dkon mchog gsum la spyir phyag 'tshal ba/ bye brag tu 'jam pa'i dbyangs la phyag 'tshal ba/ dgos pa'i dbang gis rtag zhi ba la phyag 'tshal ba/ drin gzo ba'i phyir mkhas pa spyi dang bye brag la phyag 'tshal ba'o/ /
dang po ni/
a. In general, homage to the Three Jewels
The text says:
gang la yon tan mchog mnga' ba'i/ / dkon mchog de la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
“To the ones that have supreme qualities, The Jewels, I prostrate.”

zhes pa ste/ gang zhig la rim pa bzhin don gnyis mthar phyin pa dang / 'gog lam gyi bden pa gnyis dang / rig grol gyi yon tan mchog tu gyur pa mnga' ba'i sangs rgyas dang / chos dang / dge 'dun te dkon mchog gsum po de rnams la sgo gsum gus pas phyag 'tshal lo/ / zhes pa'am/ yang na/ phyag 'tshal lo/ / gang la yon tan mchog mnga' ba'i dkon mchog de la'o/ / zhes bshad kyang rung ngo/ /

This is saying, “To whatever it is that has the supreme qualities of having gradually completed the two aims, of having the two truths of the path of cessation, and having intelligence and liberation, that is to Buddha, Dharma, and Saṅgha, the Three Jewels, I respectfully prostrate with my three doors.” Alternatively, to explain this as, “Prostration to that which has the supreme quali- ties, to the Three Jewels” would be fine.
gnyis pa bye brag tu 'jam pa'i dbyangs la phyag 'tshal ba ni/
b. Specifically, homage to Mañjughoṣha
The text says:
gang gis sgra dbyangs kun gsungs pa'i/ / 'jam pa'i dbyangs la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
“To the one who speaks all verbal sounds, Mañjughoṣha, I prostrate.”

zhes pa ste/ gang gis sgra dbyangs brjod pa thams cad gsungs pas gsung gi dbang phyug tu gyur pa/ ngag gi nyes pa'i rtsub reg dang bral zhing 'jam pa'i yon tan dang ldan pa'i gsung dbyangs kyi bdag nyid de la phyag 'tshal lo/ / zhes pa'o/ / de yang rje btsun nyid rgyal ba thams cad kyi mkhyen rab kyi ngo bo yin pa dang / mkhyen rab de gsung dbyangs kyi rgyu yin pa dang / gsung ni sgra dbyangs brjod pa thams cad kyi 'byung khungs yin pas 'jam pa'i dbyangs nyid sgra dbyangs gsung ba por bstan to/ /

This is saying, “To the one who, due to speaking every verbally sounded expression, becomes the Lord of Speech; to the embodi- ment of the voice—ghoṣha—of enlightened speech which has the quality of gentleness—mañju—of being freed from the coarseness of faulty conventional speech, I prostrate.”
Because that Jetsun is the essence of the supreme knowledge of all conquerors, Because he is the cause of the sounds of speech of that supreme knowledge, and Because his speech is the source of every verbalized expression, it is Mañjughoṣha who is shown as the speaker of verbal sounds.
gsum pa dgos pa'i dbang gis rtag zhi ba la phyag 'tshal ba ni/
c. Because of need, homage to Śhiva
The text says:
gang gis ming gzhi sngon gsungs pa/ / rtag zhi ba la phyag 'tshal lo/ /
“To he, the elicitor in the past of the bases of words, Sadāśhivaḥ, I prostrate.”
