zhes pa ste/ gang gis ming tshig brjod pa kun gyi gzhir gyur pa'i dbyangs gsal gyi yi ge sngon du gsung ba por 'jig rten na grags pa lha'i dbang po rtag tu zhi ba ste dbang phyug chen po la phyag 'tshal lo/ / zhes pa'o/ / de yang bram ze rnams kyi gzhung du byed po nyi shu rtsa bzhi bshad pa las yi ge'i byed pa po dbang phyug chen por grags pa dang sgo bstun nas phyi rol pa rnams rjes su gzung ba'i slad du yin par gsungs so/ /

This is saying, “To he, the elicitor in the past of the consonants and vowel letters which form the basis of all names, phrases, and expressions, who is renowned in the world as the Lord of Gods Sadāśhivaḥ, that is, Maheśhvara—I prostrate”.
In saying that, he conforms with what is generally known, that of the twenty-four creators explained in the Braḥmans’ textual tradition, the creator of letters is Maheśhvara, and by doing so accepts outsiders.
bzhi pa drin gzo ba'i phyir mkhas pa spyi dang bye brag la phyag 'tshal ba ni/
d. To show gratitude, general and specific homage to the experts
The text says:
sdeb sbyor legs mdzad mkhas rnams dang / / bla ma la yang phyag 'tshal nas/ /
“To the experts who made correct written composition And also to the guru, I prostrate. That done …”

zhes pa ste/ sgra skad kyi brjod pa dang don sdeb legs par sbyor ba'i tshul ston pa'i sgo nas tshig don gnyis la mi rmongs pa'i shes rab skyed nus pa'i gzhung rtsom zhing 'doms par mdzad pa'i mkhas pa spyi dang / bye brag tu mkhan po nyid la de lta'i bya ba mdzad pa'i bram ze li bi ka ra la sogs pa'i bla ma rnams la'ang phyag mdzad pa ste/ nas ni lhag bcas kyi sgra'o/ /

With that he makes a prostration to the experts in general who composed and arranged the textbooks which are able to rouse unclouded intelligence in regard to both word and meaning because they teach how to construct verbal expressions of lan- guage and how to compose their written form correctly. He also makes a prostration specifically to the experts who performed that function for the master himself, his gurus Braḥman Livikara, and so on. “That done” is a continuative term.
gnyis pa bshad par dam bca' ba ni/
2. The declaration of explanation
The text says:
bslab pa kun gyi gzhi 'dzin cing / / rig byed smra ba rnams kyi rgyu/ / ming tshig brjod pa kun gyi gzhi/ / yi ge'i sbyor ba bshad par bya/ /
“It forms the basis underlying the trainings and is The cause of the expounders of the Vedas; The basis underlying names, phrases, and expressions The connecting of letters will be explained.”

zhes pa ste/ sangs rgyas pa'i tshul khrims dang / ting nge 'dzin dang / shes rab kyi bslab pa'i gzhi thams cad ltos pa'i sgo nas 'dzin par byed cing / phyi rol pa'i nges brjod dang / mchod sbyin dang / snyan tshig dang / srid srung ste rig byed bzhi yan lag dang bcas pa'i gzhung lugs mtha' dag smra ba rnams kyi rgyu'ang yin la/ spyir yi ge las ming dang / ming las tshig dang / tshig las brjod pa 'byung ba'i phyir 'jig rten dang 'jig rten las 'das pa'i ming tshig brjod pa thams cad kyi gzhir gyur pa ni yi ge'i sbyor ba yin pas de bshad par bya'o/ / zhes pa'o/ / de yang bod kyi yi ge'i sbyor ba ni brjod bya dang / gtsug lag gnyis kyi blang dor la ma rmongs pa ni dgos pa dang / mthar thug rnam mkhyen thob pa ni nying dgos dang / snga phyi 'brel chags pa ni 'brel pa'o/ /

This is saying, “The connecting of letters forms the basis overall of the Buddha’s trainings of śhīla, samādhi, and prajñā and is also the cause of the propounders of the entire textual system of the outsider’s four Vedas—Ṛigveda, Yajurveda, Sāmveda, and Arthavaveda—together with their branches. Given that and given the general fact that letters are the source of names, names the source of phrases, and phrases the source of expressions, the connecting of letters is the basis of every name, phrase, and expression worldly and beyond worldly, thus the connecting of letters will be explained.”
The connecting of Tibetan letters is as follows: there is that itself which is what is to be expressed; there is not being confused about the acceptance and rejection of the two vihāras, which is the need; there is the ultimate attainment of omniscience, which is the core need; and there is relationship which happens between the former and latter, which is the relationship.
gnyis pa skabs don sum cu pa nyid rgyas par bshad pa
B. The extensive explanation of the śhāstra in this case, The Thirty itself
['di] la gnyis/ yi ge'i sbyor ba rgyas par bshad pa dang / gdams ngag brjod pas mjug bsdu ba'o/ /
dang po [yi ge'i sbyor ba rgyas par bshad pa]
1. The connecting of letters
['di] la gnyis/ sbyar bya yi ge'i rnam gzhag bshad pa dang / sbyor tshul tshig phrad kyi 'jug pa bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [sbyar bya yi ge'i rnam gzhag bshad pa]
a. What is connected, a presentation of the letters
['di] la gnyis/ bod yig gi dbyangs gsal ngos gzung ba dang / khyad par gyi dbye ba bstan pa'o/ /
dang po [bod yig gi dbyangs gsal ngos gzung ba] ni/
(1) The vowels and consonants of Tibetan letters identified
The text says:
yi ge A li kA li gnyis/ / A li gsal byed i sogs bzhi/ / kA li sum cu tham pa'o/ /

zhes pa ste/ spyir yi ge la A li ste a la sogs pa'i 'phreng ba dbyangs yig dang / kA li ste ka la sogs pa'i 'phreng ba gsal byed kyi yi ge gnyis su yod la/ bye brag tu bod yig la ni legs sbyar gyi A li'i bya ba gsal bar mtshon par byed pa'i yi ge i u e o bzhi dang / kA li mtshon par byed pa/ ka kha ga nga / ca cha ja nya/ ta tha da na/ pa pha ba ma/ tsa tsha dza wa/ zha za 'a ya/ ra la sha sa/ ha a/ ste sum cu tham pa yod do/ /zhes pa'o/ /

This is saying, “Generally, letters consist of both āli, that is, the string of vowel letters ཨི་, and so on, and kāli, that is, the string of consonant letters ཀ་, and so on. Specifically, in Tibetan lettering, there are four letters that are indicators that exhibit the function of the Sanskrit āli—ཨི་ཨུ་ཨེ་ཨོ་, and thirty that are indicators of the kāli—ཀ་ཁ་ག་ང་། ཅ་ཆ་ཇ་ཉ། ཏ་ཐ་ད་ན། པ་ཕ་བ་མ། ཙ་ཚ་ཛ་ཝ། ཞ་ཟ་འ་ཡ། ར་ལ་ཤ་ས། ཧ་ཨ།.”
gnyis pa khyad par gyi dbye ba bstan pa
(2) Showing the differentiation into divisions
['di] la gnyis/ mdor bstan pa dang / rgyas par bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [mdor bstan pa] ni/
(a) Synopsis
The text says:
de la rjes 'jug bcu yin te/ / de las lnga ni sngon du'ang 'jug/ mi 'jug pa ni nyi shu'o/ /

zhes pa ste/ bshad ma thag pa'i yi ge kA li de dag la dbye na rjes su 'jug pa bcu dang / rjes 'jug de nyid las lnga ni sngon du'ang 'jug pa yin pas sngon 'jug lnga dang / sngon rjes gnyis kar mi 'jug pa'i yi ge nyi shu ste tshan pa gsum du dbye 'o/ /zhes pa'o/ /

This is saying, “When the thirty kāli letters just set down are differentiated, they fall into three categories: ten are suffixes; five of those ten suffixes, since they are also pre-affixed, are prefixes; and the ones which are not placed as either prefixes or suffixes are twenty in number.”
gnyis pa rgyas par bshad pa
(b) Extensive explanation
['di] la gnyis/ dbye sgo spyir bstan pa dang / bye brag so sor bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [dbye sgo spyir bstan pa] ni/
i) Overview of the principle behind the division
The text says:
kA li phyed dang brgyad sde ni/ / bzhi bzhi dag tu phye ba las/ /
“The kāli are in eight sections, one a half, Through division into lots of four from which …”

zhes pa ste/ kA li sum cu po de rnams ka sde dang / ca sde dang / ta sde dang / pa sde dang / tsa sde dang / zha sde dang / ra sde ste sde pa ring po bdun dang / ha sde phyed du byas nas phyed dang brgyad kyi sde tshan du bgos pa ni sde pa re re la yi ge bzhi bzhi ru phye ba yin cing / las ni 'byung khungs kyi sgra'o/ /

Those thirty kāli are portioned into seven full-length groups—the ཀ་, ཅ་, ཏ་, པ་, ཙ་, ཞ་, and ར་ sections—and a half-group—the ཧ་ section—by dividing them up into lots of four letters and assigning one lot to each section. “From which” is a source term.
gnyis pa bye brag so sor bshad pa
ii) The particulars individually explained
['di] la gsum/ rjes 'jug bshad pa/ sngon 'jug bshad pa/ mi 'jug pa bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [rjes 'jug bshad pa] ni/
a) Suffixes
The text says:
dang po gsum pa bzhi pa las/ / mas gnyis drug pa'i gsum pa dang / / bdun pa las ni sha ma gtogs/ / rjes 'jug yi ge bcu ru 'dod/ /
“The first, the third, and the fourth’s Bottom two; the third of the sixth; and Excluding ཤ་, the remainder of the seventh Are declared to be the ten suffix letters.”

ces pa ste/ gong du rjes 'jug bcu zhes bshad pa de gang zhe na/ sde pa dang po dang / gsum pa dang / bzhi pa rnams kyi mas kyi yi ge gnyis gnyis te/ ga nga / da na/ ba ma rnams dang / sde pa drug pa'i gsum pa 'a dang / bdun pa'i sha ma gtogs lhag ma ra la sa gsum mo/ / de'ang yi ge thams cad kyi rjes su 'di dag 'jug pa'i phyir rjes 'jug ces bya zhing yi ge'i grangs bcu nyid du nges pa yin no/ /

The text above explained “ten suffixes” so what are they? They are the first, the third, and the fourth sections’ bottom two letters, that is, ག་ང་ and ད་ན་ and བ་མ་; the third one of the sixth section, འ་; and the three ར་ལ་ས་ which are, after excluding ཤ་, the remainder of the seventh. Because these are placed after all letters they are called suffixes and their enumeration is determined to be ten.
gnyis pa sngon 'jug bshad pa ni/
b) Prefixes
The text says:
rjes 'jug yi ge bcu nyid las/ / dang po gsum pa lnga pa drug/ bdun pa rnams ni sngon du'ang 'jug/
“Of the ten suffix letters themselves, The first, third, fifth, sixth, and Seventh ones are also pre-fixed.”

ces pa ste/ gong du sngon 'jug lnga zhes bshad pa de gang zhe na/ rjes 'jug gi yi ge bcu po de dag nyid las dang po ga/ gsum pa da/ lnga pa ba/ drug pa ma/ bdun pa 'a rnams yin cing / de dag rjes su 'jug par ma zad sngon du 'jug pa'ang yod pas sngon 'jug ces kyang bya ste/ yi ge'i grangs lnga nyid du nges pa yin no/ /

The text above explained “five prefixes” so what are they? Of those ten suffix letters, they are the first ག་, the third ད་, the fifth བ་, the sixth མ་, and the seventh འ་ ones. Since they are not only suffixed but also are prefixed, they are also called “prefixes”; their enumeration is determined to be five.
gsum pa mi 'jug pa bshad pa ni/
c) Not-affixed
The text says:
ming gzhi gnyis sam gsum sbrel lam/ / de la dbyangs kyi bzhi ldan yang / / gang du'ang 'jug min sbyar ba'ang min/ /
“Two name-bases or three linked or A vowel to that to make a four-part Are nowhere placed nor connected.”

zhes pa ste/ sngon 'jug dang rjes 'jug bsal ba'i lhag ma ming gzhi kho na yin pa/ ka kha/ ca cha ja nya/ ta tha/ pa pha/ tsa tsha dza wa/ zha za ya/ sha/ ha a ste yi ge nyi shu tham pa ni tsheg bar gcig tu gnyis sam gsum sbrel ba'am/ de la dbyangs i sogs gang rung re sbyar ba'i bzhi ldan du byas pa/ tsaka/ tshaphakha/ waziya/ lta bu gangs ljongs su grags pa'i tha snyad gang la'ang 'jug pa min pas 'di bzhin sbyar bar rigs pa'ang ma yin no/ / de yang skabs 'di'i ming gzhi ni sngon rjes gnyis kyi 'jug yul du gyur pa'i gsal byed kyi yi ge yin la/ des na sngon rjes ming gsum ci rigs par 'gyur ba sngon 'jug lnga/ rjes ming gnyis ci rigs par 'gyur ba rjes 'jug lhag ma lnga/ ming gzhi kho na yin pa mi 'jug pa nyi shu tham pa ste gsum du dbyer yod pa las 'dir ni phyi ma 'chad pa'i skabs so/ /

Regarding the twenty letters ཀ་ཁ། ཅ་ཆ་ཇ་ཉ། ཏ་ཐ། པ་ཕ། ཙ་ཚ་ཛ་ཝ། ཞ་ཟ་ཡ། ཤ། ཧ་ཨ། which are the name-bases only that remain after eliminating the prefixes and suffixes, two of these linked to make one intertsheg such as ཙཀ་ or three linked to make such as ཚཕཁ་ or any one of the four vowels, ཨི་ etcetera, connected to such a three-part to make a four-part like ཝཟིཡ་ are nowhere placed in the conventions known in the Snowy Land hence it is also not correct for them to be connected like this.
Now, the name-bases are consonant letters which become the recipients of suffixes and-or prefixes. The letters that make up the five prefixes can operate in any of three categories—they can operate as a prefix, suffix, or name-base. The letters that make up the other five suffixes can operate either as a suffix or a name-base.
The twenty not-placed letters can only operate as name-bases. Of the three categories, it is the last category that is being dealt with in that section above.
gnyis pa sbyor tshul tshig phrad kyi 'jug pa bshad pa
b. The ways they are connected: placement as phrase linkers
['di] la gnyis/ rjes 'jug la ltos pa'i phrad rnam dbye dang bcas pa bshad pa dang / rjes 'jug la ma ltos pa'i phrad rang dbang can bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [rjes 'jug la ltos pa'i phrad rnam dbye dang bcas pa bshad pa]
(1) Case-associated linkers reliant on suffixes
['di] la brgyad/ slar bsdu bshad pa/ la don bshad pa/ i ldan gyi rnam dbye bshad pa/ rgyan sdud bshad pa/ lhag bcas bshad pa/ 'byed sdud bshad pa/ 'byung khungs bshad pa/ bod pa'i sgra bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [slar bsdu bshad pa] ni/
(a) Concluders
The text says:
rjes 'jug yi ge bcu po ni/ / ming gang gi ni mthar sbyar ba/ / de la A li bzhi pa sbyar/ / slar bsdu bar ni shes par bya/ /
“The ten suffix letters Connected at the end of a name Have the fourth āli connected to them To be known as “concluders”.”

zhes pa ste/ sngar bshad pa'i rjes 'jug gi yi ge bcu po de rnams nyid ming tshig gang gi mthar sbyar ba yod kyang rung / de dag la A li bzhi pa o yig ste sna ru sbyar ba ni/ skabs bab kyi brjod bya'i don de nyid de tsam gyis bsdu bar song bas slar bsdu'i sgra zhes sam/ rdzogs tshig ces kyang bya'o/ / de yang gzhung gi dngos bstan rtag go/ bzang ngo/ /yod do/ /yin no/ /sgrub bo/ /bsam mo/ /bya'o/ /'gyur ro/ sel lo/ /byas so/ /zhes pa lta bu bcu dang / da drag gis thob pa'i shugs bstan/ gyurd to/ /lta bu gcig ste bcu gcig yod do/ /

Any one of the previously explained ten suffix letters is connected at the end of some name or phrase and then has the fourth āli, the ཨོ་ letter, that is, the sna ru, connected to it. Just that construction itself concludes the particular meaning being expressed at the time so it is known as a “concluding term” and also as a “completing word”.
There are eleven of them; ten are explicitly presented in the text for example in རྟག་གོ བཟང་ངོ་། ཡོད་དོ། ཡིན་ནོ། སྒྲུབ་བོ། བསམ་མོ། བྱའོ། འགྱུར་རོ། སེལ་ལོ། and བྱས་སོ།, and the one implicitly presented is obtained at forceful ད་ as in གྱུརད་ཏོ།.
gnyis pa la don bshad pa ni/
(b) La-equivalents
The text says:

rjes 'jug yi ge bcu rnams las/ / gang ming mtha' na bcu pa gnas/ / de la A li gnyis pa sbyar/ / gang ming mtha' na brgyad pa gnas/ / de la gnyis pa u yang sbyar/ / gang ming mtha' na gsum pa gnas/ / de la A li gnyis pa sbyar/ / bzhi pa dgu pa dngos kyang ste/ / las dang ched dang rten gnas dang / / de nyid tshe skabs la sgra yin/ /

zhes pa ste/ rjes 'jug yi ge bcu po de rnams nyid las/ gang yang rung ba'i ming gi mtha' na la don gyi rnam dbye sbyar ba'i ched du bcu pa sa yig gnas pa de la A li gnyis pa u yig sbyar bas/ su/ zhes grub pa dang / de bzhin du tsheg bar gcig nyid du ming mthar brgyad pa ra yig sbyar te gnas pa lhag par lta bu dang / yang ra yig de nyid tsheg bar phyes pa la u yig kyang sbyar ba'i ru zhes pa dang / rjes 'jug gsum pa da yig gnas par u yig sbyar ba'i du dang / rjes 'jug bzhi pa na dang / dgu pa la gnyis ni dbyangs kyis ma brgyan pa'i dngos po nyid du gnas pa'ang ste dngos bstan drug dang / shugs bstan ta yig u zhugs kyi tu bcas

In order to connect the la-equivalent case at the end of name, the following is done. Of the ten suffix letters, at the end of some name whatever it might be, the tenth suffix letter ས་ is positioned and has the second āli, letter ཨུ་, connected to it so that “སུ་” is produced. Similarly, at end of a name the eighth, letter ར་, is connected into a single intertsheg and becomes part of it, as in ལྷག་ པ་ར་. Also, that same ར་ letter but kept separate from the intertsheg and having the ཨུ་ letter connected to it as well is connected as “རུ་ ”. And, the third suffix, letter ད་, is positioned with the ཨུ་ letter is connected to it, as དུ་. Both the fourth suffix, ན་, and the ninth suffix, ལ་, are positioned unadorned with vowel as themselves “in fact”. That makes an explicit presentation of six. There is an implicit presentation of the seventh, ཏུ་, which is letter ཏ་ having ཨུ་ in place.

bdun po 'di rnams ni/ shar phyogs su 'gro lta bu byed pa pos bya ba gang la byed pa'i don can du sbyar na rnam dbye gnyis pa las su bya ba'i sgra dang / /rtar rtswa byin lta bu bya ba gang zhig gis bya ba'i yul de'am/ de dang 'brel ba'i las la phan 'dogs par 'gyur ba'i don can du sbyar na rnam dbye bzhi pa dgos ched kyi sgra dang / dpral ba ru sme ba yod lta bu gang zhig gang la brten pa'i don can du sbyar na rnam dbye bdun pa rten gnas kyi sgra dang / 'od du 'tsher lta bu yul gang zhig la bya ba gang zhig byed pa'i tshe las dang bya ba ngo bo gcig pa'i don can du sbyar na rnam dbye gnyis pa'i bye brag de nyid kyi sgra dang / nyi ma shar ba na chos ston lta bu dus brjod pa'i don can du sbyar na rnam dbye bdun pa'i bye brag tshe skabs kyi sgrar shes dgos shing /

These seven are as follows. When they are connected to have the meaning “where an agent is doing some action” as in ཤར་ཕྱོགས་སུ་འགྲོ “going to the east”, they are the second case, “terms of the object of an activity”. When they are connected to have the meaning “some action which is benefiting the object of the action or the object connected with it” as in རྟར་རྩྭ་བྱིན། “gave grass to the horse”, they are the fourth case, “terms of necessity and or purpose”. When they are connected to have the meaning “something supported on something else”, as in དཔྲལ་རུ་སྨེ་བ་ཡོད། “there is a mole on the forehead”, they are the seventh case, “terms of location”. When they are connected to have the meaning “at the time of something being acted on and something acting, the object and action are one entity” as in འོད་དུ་འཚེར་བ། “radiating light”, they are a particular of the second case “terms of identity”. When they are connected to have the meaning “expressing time” as in ཉི་མ་ཤར་བ་ན་ཆོས་སྟོན། “teaching the dharma when the sun rises”, they are a particular of the seventh case, “terms of timing”.

de dag thams cad rnam dbyer sbyor ba na la sgra'i 'jug pa dang phal cher mthun pa dang mtha'i gsal byed yin pas la sgra zhes kyang brjod par bya ste/ 'on kyang na la gnyis de nyid kyi don can la ni 'jug par mi 'gyur te/ smra sgo las na'i 'jug pa bcu bzhi tsam bshad pa'i skabs su de nyid la 'jug pa mi 'byung ba dang / du la sogs pa la dang mthun/ / de nyid dag ni lhag pa yin/ / zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

All of them when connected as a case are generally equivalent to the placement of a la term and are consonants at an ending, thus they too are called “la-terms”. Nonetheless, the two letters ན་ and ལ་ are not placed to have the meaning of “identity” because the Speech Door Weapon when explaining some fourteen placements of ན་ says that placement as identity does not happen but that,
“For དུ་, du and so on conforming to la Identity is extra.”
gsum pa i ldan gyi rnam dbye bshad pa
(c) The cases with vowel I
['di] la gnyis/ mdor bstan pa dang / rgyas par bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [mdor bstan pa] ni/
i) Synopsis
The text says:
rjes 'jug yi ge bcu po la/ / i ldan mthun lugs 'di zhes bya/ /
“For the ten suffix letters, The system of harmony possessing ཨི་ I will be thus.”

zhes pa ste/ rjes 'jug yi ge bcu po de dag gang rung rjes su zhugs pa'i ming rnams la i yig dang sbyar ba'i rnam dbye+e'i phrad rnams ji ltar mthun par sbyor ba'i lugs ni 'di dang 'di'o zhes bstan par bya'o/ /zhes so/ /

This is saying, “For names that have any of those ten suffix letters in place, the system of how case linkers having an ཨི་ I letter attached are harmoniously connected will be taught as “being like this and that”.
gnyis pa rgyas par bshad pa
ii) Extensive explanation
['di] la gnyis/ 'brel sgra bshad pa dang / byed pa po'i sgra bshad pa'o/ /
dang po ['brel sgra bshad pa] ni/
a) Connective terms
The text says:
dang po gnyis la dang po mthun/ / gsum lnga bcu la kya dang sbyar/ / bdun pa nyid la bdun pa ste/ / lhag ma rnams la gya sbyar ba/ / de dag i sbyar 'brel ba'i sa/ /

zhes pa ste/ rjes 'jug bcu'i dang po ga dang nga gnyis gang rung rjes su zhugs pa'i ming rnams la ni rjes 'jug dang po ga nyid mthun zhing / de bzhin du rjes 'jug gsum pa da dang / lnga pa ba dang / bcu pa sa rnams rjes su zhugs pa la kya dang sbyar ba dang / bdun pa 'a yig gi mtha' can rnams la dngos su 'a yig yod dam med kyang rung bdun pa 'a nyid sbyar ba dang / shugs bstan 'a mtha' can la rkang pa kha skong dgos pa'i tshe ya yig sbyar ba dang / de dag las gzhan lhag ma na ma ra la bzhi po'i mtha' can rnams la gya nyid sbyar ba mthun pa bcas

For any names with either of the first ག་ or second ང་ of the ten suffixes in place, the first suffix ག་ itself is harmonious then, likewise, for those with the third, ད་, the fifth, བ་, and the tenth, ས་ suffixes in place, a ཀྱ་ connection is harmonious. For those having endings of the seventh, letter འ་, whether letter འ་ is actually there or not a connection with the seventh, འ་, itself is harmonious and it is implicitly presented that for those having an འ་ ending when verse-filler is required a connection with ཡ་ letter is harmonious. For those having the four endings other than those—the remaining letters ན་མ་ར་ and ལ་—a གྱ་ connection is harmonious.

de dag thams cad la rim pa bzhin i yig ste gi gu sbyar bas/ gi/ kyi/ 'i/ yi/ gyi rnams su grub pa de rnams gang zhig gang dang sgra mthun pa'i ming mtha' so so dang sbyar bas/ bdag gi/ gang gi/ khyod kyi/ rgyab kyi/ g.yas kyi/ de'i/ de yi/ mdun gyi/ lam gyi/ gser gyi/ dngul gyi sogs su 'gyur te/ de dag ni rten dang brten pa'am/ yan lag dang yan lag can sogs ming don phan tshun 'brel ba brjod pa'i don can gyi sgra yin pas rnam dbye drug pa 'brel ba'i sa zhes bya'o/ /

To all of those as a further step an ཨི་ letter, that is, a gi gu, is con- nected resulting in གི, ཀྱི་, འི་, ཡི་, and གྱི. They are individually connected to whichever terms have name-endings they are in harmony with, changing for example to དག་གི གང་གི ཁྱོད་ཀྱི། རྒྱབ་ཀྱི། གཡས་ཀྱི། དེའི། དེ་ཡི། མདུན་གྱི། ལམ་གྱི། གསེར་གྱི། དངུལ་གྱི།, and so on; they are now terms having the meaning of expressing a mutual connection between name-equivalents— support and supported, limbs and that having the limbs, and so on—because of which they are the sixth case, called “the site of connection”.

gi sogs de dag mi mthun pa'i tshig rgyan la 'jug pa lta bu gzhung 'dir dngos su ma bstan pa'i don gzhan dang gzhan la 'jug pa snga phyir mang du snang yang 'dir gzhung gi dngos bstan tsam las mi 'chad pas smra sgo sogs gzhung gzhan du rtogs par bya'o/ /

There are other meanings for གི་ and the others such as “phrase ornaments of non-concordance” that are not explicitly presented in this text and many other usages that have appeared over time. Since they are not explained explicitly in the slightest in this text, they will have to be understood from other texts, the Speech Door Weapon, and so on.
gnyis pa byed pa po'i sgra bshad pa ni/
b) Terms of the agent
The text says:
de nyid la ni bcu pa sbyar/ / byed pa po ru shes par bya/ /
“Those themselves with ས་, the tenth, connected Are to be known as “the agent”.”

zhes pa ste/ sngar bshad pa'i rnam dbye drug pa'i sgra gi/ kyi/ 'i/ yi/ gyi ste lnga po de dag nyid la rjes 'jug bcu pa sa yig sbyar bas/ gis/ kyis/ 'is/ yis/ gyis rnams su grub pa ni bya ba la sbyor bar ston pas na rnam dbye gsum pa byed pa po'i sa ru shes par bya ste/ dper na bdag gis bstan/ khyod kyis nyan/ de'is byin/ 'di yis blangs/ gser gyis nyos lta bu'o/ /

When those previously explained terms of the sixth case—the five terms གི་, ཀྱི་, འི་, ཡི་, and གྱི་—have the tenth suffix, letter ས་, connected to them, the resulting གིས་, ཀྱིས་, འིས་, ཡིས་, and གྱིས་ show connection to an action therefore are to be known as third case, “the site of the agent”; for example, བདག་གིས་བསྟན། “I showed”, ཁྱོད་ཀྱིས་ཉན། “you listen”, དེའིས་བྱིན། “give with that”, འདི་ཡིས་བླངས། “taken by this”, and གསེར་གྱིས་ཉོས། “purchase with gold”.
bzhi pa rgyan sdud bshad pa ni/
(d) Ornament and Inclusion
The text says:
A li phyis nas gnyis pa sbyar/ / tshig rgyan gnyis dang sdud par 'gyur/ /
“The āli erased then the second connected Becomes two phrase ornaments and inclusion.”

zhes pa ste/ gong du bshad pa'i 'brel sgra de dag las/ kyi/ 'i/ yi/ gsum gyi A li ste gi gu phyis nas so sor rjes 'jug gnyis pa nga yig sbyar bas/ kyang / 'ang / yang / zhes grub pa de rnams ni/ gsal yang gsal/ mdzes kyang mdzes/ lta bu tshig snga phyi mthun par ston pa'i rgyan dang / btud kyang khro/ mdza'ang slu lta bu tshig snga phyi mi mthun par ston pa'i rgyan te tshig rgyan gnyis dang / mir ma zad lhas kyang btud do/ / lta bu gzhi'am don gzhan zhig la sdud cing sbyor ba'i sgrar 'gyur ro/ / zhes so/ /

This is saying, “The āli, that is, the gi gu, is erased from three of the connective terms explained above—ཀྱི་, འི་, and ཡི་—then the second suffix, letter ང་, is connected. The resulting “ཀྱང་”, “འང་”, and “ཡང་” become two phrase ornaments—ornaments that show concordance between former and later wordings as in གསལ་ཡང་གསལ། “completely clear” and མརྫེས་ཀྱང་མརྫེས། “just beautiful” , and ornaments that show non-concordance between former and later wordings as in བཏུད་ཀྱང་ཁྲོ། “bowing down but angry” and མཛའང་བསླུ། “loving but deceiving”—and a term which causes another base or meaning to be included and joined in as in མིར་མ་ཟད་ལྷས་ཀྱང་བཏུད་དོ།; “not only men but gods also paid respect”.”
lnga pa lhag bcas bshad pa ni/
(e) Continuative
The text says:
la don su la u phyis nas/ / de la gsum pa'i dang po sbyar/ / de la A li gsum pa sbyar/ / de ni lhag ma dang bcas pa'o/ /
“Having erased the ཨུ་ on la-equivalent སུ་, The first of the third is connected to it, And the third āli is connected to that; That is a continuative.”

zhes pa ste/ sngar bshad pa'i la don gyi nang tshan su zhes pa de'i u yig ste zhabs kyu phyis nas sa rkyang gnas pa de la kA li'i sde pa gsum pa'i dang po ta yig sbyar zhing / de la slar yang steng du A li gsum pa ste 'greng bu sbyar bas/ ste/ zhes grub pa dang / 'og nas 'byung ba'i de dang / shugs bstan gyi te rkyang bcas gsum po de rnams ni/ ming tshig gang gi mthar sbyar yang bstan bya'i lhag ma 'dren pa'i don du 'gyur bas lhag ma dang bcas pa'i sgra zhes bya ste/ de yang / mda' 'phangs te phog/ phyag 'tshal te bshad/ 'phar te 'gro lta bu nas dang cing sogs kyi phrad dang 'jug pa mthun pa ni mtshams sbyor dang / dngos po ni gsum ste/ bem po dang / shes pa dang / ldan min 'du byed do lta bu tshig snga ma'i gsal byed du phyi ma 'dren pa ni dam bca' dang / khyod ni dpal te khyod ni mgon/ / lta bu la dang 'jug pa mthun cing lhag ma yod pa tsam ston pa ni gzhan 'dren pa ste rags pa tsam dbye na gsum du 'gyur ro/ /

Having erased the ཨུ་ letter, that is, the zhabs kyu, of the member “སུ་” of the previously explained la-equivalents, the letter “ས་” remains. The first letter of the third section of kāli, ཏ་, is con- nected to it and then the third āli, that is, the ’greng bu, is further connected on top of that. When the three items of the resulting “སྟེ་”, the དེ་ that follows on from it, and the implicit bare ཏེ་ are connected to the end of some name or phrase, they produce a meaning of “leading on to something remaining to be shown”, thus they are called “terms showing that there is more associated”.
Moreover, when that function is just roughly differentiated, it becomes threefold as follows. In cases where it is congruent with the usage of the linkers ནས་, དང་, ཅིང་, and so on, for example in མདའ་འཕངས་ཏེ་ཕོག “the arrow was fired then struck”, ཕྱག་འཚལ་ཏེ་བཤད། “prostrated then explained”, and འཕར་ཏེ་འགྲོ་ “got up and went”, it is a boundary continuative. In cases where it leads onto later words as part of clarifying previous words, for example in དངོས་པོ་ནི་ གསུམ་སྟེ། བེམ་པོ་དང་། ཤེས་པ་དང་། ལྡན་མིན་འདུ་བྱེད་དོ།“phenomena are of three types: matter, consciousness, and non-associated formatives”, it is a declarative. And, in cases where it is congruent with the usage of a ལ་ and shows just that there is more, for example in ཁྱོད་ནི་དཔལ་ཏེ་ཁྱོད་ནི་དགོན། “you are the glory, you are the protector”, it is “leading on to another”.
drug pa 'byed sdud bshad pa ni/
(f) Separation-Inclusion
The text says:
rjes 'jug yi ge bcu po la/ / drug pa sbyar na 'byed sdud yin/ /
“The ten suffix letters with The sixth connected are separation-inclusion.”

zhes pa ste/ rjes 'jug gi yi ge bcu po de rnams la de nyid kyi drug pa ma yig sbyar bas/ gam/ ngam/ dam/ nam/ bam/ mam/ 'am/ ram/ lam/ sam rnams su grub pa de dag dang / shugs bstan tam bcas bcu gcig po rnams ni/ phung po ni lnga ste/ gzugs sam/ tshor ba'am/ 'du shes sam/ 'du byed dam/ rnam par shes pa'o lta bu dbye gzhi gcig las bye brag so sor 'byed pa dang / gzugs sam/ tshor ba'am/ 'du shes sam/ 'du byed dam/ rnam par shes pa ni phung po'o lta bu tshig don mang po phyogs gcig tu sdud pa'i sgrar 'jug pa yin no/ / zhes so/ / de yang yod dam med lta bu dri tshig rnams kyang yod med kyi khyad par 'byed pa'i tshig yin pas 'byed pa'i sgra nyid du nges so/ /

This is saying, “Those ten suffix letters with their sixth one, the letter མ་, connected to them result in གམ། ངམ། དམ། ནམ། བམ། མམ། འམ། རམ། ལམ། and སམ།. Those together with implicitly presented ཏམ། making eleven, are placed as terms which separate out individually the particulars from one basis of separation, as in ཕུང་པོ་ནི་ལྔ་སྟེ། གཟུགས་སམ། ཚོར་བའམ། འདུ་ཤེས་སམ། འདུ་བྱེད་དམ། རྣམ་པ་ར་ཤེས་པ་འོ། “the skandhas are five: form, feeling, perception, formatives, and consciousness” and are placed as terms which include many phrase-equivalents into one item, as in གཟུགས་ སམ། ཚོར་བའམ། འདུ་ཤེས་སམ། འདུ་བྱེད་དམ། རྣམ་པ་ར་ཤེས་པ་ནི་ཕུང་པོ་ལྔའོ། “form, feeling, perception, formatives, and consciousness are the five skandhas”.”
Additionally, in usages like ཡོད་དམ་མེད་ “exists or not?” they are interrogative terms but also are terms that distinguish between exists and does not exist, therefore they are ascertained to be terms of separation.
bdun pa 'byung khungs bshad pa
(g) Source
['di] la gnyis/ 'byung khungs dngos bshad pa dang / de dgar sdud la 'jug pa'i tshul lo/ /
dang po ['byung khungs dngos bshad pa] ni/
i) Actual Source
The text says:
rjes 'jug yi ge bcu po yi/ / bzhi pa dgu pa la bcu pa/ / sbyar ba 'byung khungs sa yin te/ /
“The ten suffix letters’ Fourth and ninth with the tenth Connected are the site of the source;”

zhes pa ste/ rjes 'jug yi ge bcu po de'i bzhi pa na dang / dgu pa la gnyis so sor bcu pa sa yig sbyar bas/ nas/ las zhes grub pa ni/ sa nas rtswa skyes/ ba las 'o ma 'jo/ lta bu chos gang las gang zhig bral ba'am 'byung ba ston pa'i don du mtshungs par 'jug pas rnam dbye lnga pa 'byung khungs kyi sa yin cing / te ni lhag bcas so/ / yang du ba las mer shes lta bu las kyi sgra kho na rgyu mtshan la 'jug pa yod kyang rnam dbye lnga pa las ma 'das te/ mer shes pa'i rgyu mtshan de du ba mthong ba las byung bas so/ /

The suffix letters’ fourth, ན་, and ninth, ལ་, each have the tenth, letter ས་, connected, to form “ནས་” and “ལས་”. Those two are equally placed to have the meaning of showing the thing which something has parted from or originated from, as in ས་ནས་རྩྭ་སྐྱེས། “grass grows from the earth” and བ་ལས་འོ་མ་འཇོ། “milk is obtained from cows”, whereby they are the fifth case, the site of the source. The semi-colon is a continuative.
Also, although there is placement only of the ལས་ term to mean a reason as in དུ་བ་ལས་མེར་ཤེས།, “because of smoke one knows that there is fire”, this does not depart from the fifth case because the reason for knowing that there is fire originates from sight of smoke.
gnyis pa de dgar sdud la 'jug pa'i tshul ni/
ii) The way it is placed for Segregation-Inclusion
The text says:
dgar dang sdud pa'ang de bzhin yin/ /
“They are also, likewise, segregation and inclusion.”

zhes pa ste/ bshad ma thag pa'i nas dang las kyi sgra de dag 'byung khungs kho nar ma zad/ dgar gzhi las logs su dgar ba'i don la'ang 'jug cing / de las nas kyi sgra gcig pu ni mtshams 'dzin cing sdud pa'i don du'ang de bzhin du 'jug pa yin te/ lha rnams kyi nang nas brgya byin mdzes lta bu dgar gzhi dang dgar chos ris mthun pa la nas dang / lha las mi dman lta bu dgar gzhi dang dgar chos ris mi mthun pa la las dang / gzugs nas rnam mkhyen gyi bar lta bu sdud pa la nas 'jug cing dgar sdud gnyis ka yang rnam dbye lnga pa'i khongs su gtogs te/ dgar ba ni dgar gzhi las dgar chos bye ba ltar snang ba dang / sdud pa ni thog ma gang nas brtsams pa de las bsdu bya rnams byung ba ltar snang bas so/ /

Those ནས་ and ལས་ terms just explained are not only placed for source. They are also likewise placed for the meaning of segregation out from a base of segregation and, of them, the ནས་ term alone is also placed for the meanings of boundary marking and inclusion. Where the base of the segregation and the thing segregated from it are of the same status, a ནས་ is placed as in ལྷ་ རྣམས་ཀྱི་ནང་ནས་བརྒྱ་བྱིན་མརྫེས་ “of the gods, Indra is the beautiful one”. Where the base of the segregation and the thing segregated from it are not of the same status ལས་ is placed as in ལྷ་ལས་མི་དམན་ “men are lower than gods”. A ནས་ is is placed for inclusion as in གཟུགས་ནས་རྣམ་མཁྱེན་གྱི་བར་ “from form up to omniscience” . Both segregation and inclusion are included in the fifth case; segregation because it takes the form of segregated items dissected out from a basis of segregation and inclusion it takes the form of some beginning point from which that to be included arises.
brgyad pa bod pa'i sgra bshad pa ni/
(h) Terms of Calling
The text says:
gang ming brjod pa'i dang po ru/ / kye sbyar ba ni bod pa yin/ /
“Initial to the expression of some name The connection of ཀྱེ་ is calling.”

zhes pa ste/ gang yang rung ba'i ming brjod pa'i thog mar kye zhes sbyar ba ni/ kye rgyal po chen po lta bu yul khyad par can la bod pa gsal bar byed pa'i sgra yin la/ shugs bstan kwa ye dang kwa dang wa ye lta bu ni yul dman pa la bod pa gsal byed kyi sgra yin no/ /

At the beginning of the expression of some name, whatever it might be, the connection of “ཀྱེ་” as in ཀྱེ་རྒྱལ་པོ་ཆེན་པོ “Oh great king” is a term which indicates calling out to a distinguished object. Implicitly presented here are terms which indicate calling to an inferior object such as ཀྭ་ཡེ་ “kva ye”, ཀྭ་ “kva”; and ཝ་ཡེ་ “wa ye”.
gnyis pa rjes 'jug la ma ltos pa'i phrad rang dbang can bshad pa
(2) Independent linkers not reliant on suffixes
['di] la drug/ ni sgra bshad pa/ dang sgra bshad pa/ de sgra bshad pa/ gang sgra bshad pa/ bdag sgra bshad pa/ dgag sgra bshad pa'o/ /
dang po ni/
(a) The ནི་ term
The text says:
gang ming mtha' dang mthun pa yi/ / bzhi pa la ni i sbyar ba/ / dgar dang brnan pa'i tshig tu 'gyur/ /
“In harmony with the ending of whatever name The fourth, by having an ཨི་ connected to it, Becomes a word of segregation and highlighting”

zhes pa ste/ gang yang rung ba'i ming tshig gi mtha' dang mthun par sbyar rung ba'i phrad rjes 'jug bzhi pa na yig la dbyangs i sbyar bas/ ni zhes grub pa de ni sbyor dngos mjug gsum gyi dang po ni/ lta bu dgar gzhi las tha dad du dmigs bsal nas dgar ba'i don dang / dal ba'i rten bzang po ni thob/ dge ba'i bshes gnyen dang ni mjal/ blo gros kyi mig dang ni ldan lta bu don gang yin pa de la nges bzung ngam nan tan du brnan pa'i don la'ang 'jug pa'i tshig tu 'gyur la/ sdom pa thams cad ldan par ni/ / lta bu tshig gi kha skong du 'jug pa rnams kyang brnan pa'i sgra nyid yin no/ /

The fourth suffix letter ན་ by having an ཨི་ vowel connected to it results in ནི་, a linker that harmoniously connects with any name or phrase ending. This linker is placed to have the meaning of segregating out something from a basis of segregation so that it is distinct as in སྦྱོར་དངོས་མཇུག་གསུམ་གྱི། དང་པོ་ནི། “of introduction, main part, and conclusion, the first is as follows”. It is also placed to have the meaning of precisely highlighting or identifying some particular meaning” as in དལ་བའི་རྟེན་བཟང་པོ་ནི་ཐོབ། དགེ་བའི་བཤེས་གཉེན་དང་ནི་མཇལ། བློ་གྲོས་ཀྱི་མིག་དང་ནི་ལྡན། literally “a good support of (what exactly?) leisure is to be obtained; a spiritual friend is (what exactly?) to be met; the eye of intelligence is (what exactly?) to be possessed”. Its placement as a padding word as in སྡོམ་པ་ཐམས་ཅད་ལྡན་པ་ར་ནི། also is a term of highlighting.
gnyis pa dang sgra bshad pa ni/
(b) The དང་ term
The text says:
ming gang rung ba'i bar mtshams su/ / gsum pa la ni gnyis pa sbyar/ / de ni sdud dang 'byed pa dang / / rgyu mtshan tshe skabs gdams ngag lnga'o/ /
“At the places between whatever names, The third has the second connected to it; That is the five of inclusion, separation, Reason, timing, and verbal instruction.”

zhes pa ste/ ming tshig gang yang rung ba'i bar mtshams rnams su rjes 'jug gsum pa da yig la gnyis pa nga yig sbyar bas/ dang zhes grub pa de ni/ mig dang / rna ba dang / sna dang / lce dang / lus rnams ni dbang po'o lta bu tshig snga phyi phyogs gcig tu sdud pa dang / dbang po rnams ni/ mig dang / rna ba dang / sna dang / lce dang / lus so lta bu so sor 'byed pa dang / du ba mthong ba dang mer shes so lta bu rgyu mtshan nyid kyi don dang / nyi ma phyed pa dang chos ston drangs lta bu dus brjod pa tshe skabs kyi don dang / yid la gzungs dang / lta bu gzhan la gdams ngag brjod pa'i don te/ don lnga la 'jug go/ zhes so/ /

This is saying, “At the places between whatever names or phrases, the third suffix, letter ད་, has the second one, letter ང་, connected to it. The resulting “དང་” is used for five meanings as follows. It brings together prior and later wordings as in མིག་དང་། རྣ་བ་དང་། སྣ་དང་། ལྕེ་དང་། ལུས་རྣམས་ནི་དབང་པོའོ། “eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and body are sense faculties”. It separates out into individual items as in དབང་པོ་རྣམས་ནི། མིག་དང་། རྣ་བ་དང་། སྣ་དང་། ལྕེ་དང་། ལུས་སོ། “the five sense faculties of eyes, ears, nose, tongue, and body”. It has the meaning of a reason as in དུ་བ་མཐོང་བ་དང་མེར་ཤེས་སོ། “seeing smoke so knowing there is fire”. It has the meaning of a timing, the expressing of time as in ཉི་མ་ཕྱེད་པ་དང་ཆོས་སྟོན་དྲངས། “the sunrise brings with it the dharma teaching”. It has the meaning of giving a verbal instruction to another as in ཡིད་ལ་གཟུངས་དང་། “Keep that in mind!”
gsum pa de sgra bshad pa ni/
(c) The དེ་ term
The text says:
gang ming gi ni ya mtha' ru/ / gsum pa la ni e sbyar ba/ / tha snyad dbang du gsum yin te/ / dngos po'i dbang du bzhi ru 'gyur/ / dus kyi dbang du gnyis yin no/ /
“At upper end of some name The third having ཨེ་ connected to it From the standpoint of convention is three; From the standpoint of thing becomes four; and From the standpoint of time is two.”

zhes pa ste/ gang yang rung ba'i ming gi ya mtha' ste thog mar rjes 'jug gsum pa da yig la dbyangs e ste 'greng bu sbyar bas/ de zhes grub pa ni/ sngar med par gsar du nan gyis btags pa'i tha snyad tsam gyi dbang du byas nas dbye na/ dbye gzhi ka ba ring po'o/ / de phra'o/ / de la zur yod do/ / lta bu brjod bya spyi'i don la ma dpyad par brjod tshul de nyid la thad kar brtags pa'i dus 'das pa dang / de las dbye ba'i ya gyal/ de la yi ge bris shig/ lta bu 'dri gzhi dngos su mi gsal yang de sgra'i shul du shog bu lta bu don gyi rnam grangs gzhan zhig sbyor rgyu yod par ston pa'i don can dang / shing bcad de me la 'bud/ lta bu rang nyid kyi shul du don gzhan mi mtshon kyang brjod bya lhag ma 'dren pa tsam ste gsum la 'jug cing / dbye tshul des de sgra'i 'jug pa thams cad la khyab pa yin no/ /

At the upper end, that is, before, some name whatever it might be the third suffix, letter ད་, has vowel ཨེ་, that is, the ’greng bu, connected to it. The resulting དེ་ is as follows. When looked at from the perspective of being a mere convention that is a newly placed designation where there was none before, it has three usages. The basis for this perspective is its use to represent past time which is direct examination of the expression itself not an analysis of the generic image of what is being expressed, for example, in ཀ་བ་རིང་པོའོ། །དེ་ཕྲའོ། །དེ་ལ་ཟུར་ཡོད་དོ། “A pillar is tall. It is thin. It has corners”. The derivatives of that are as follows. The དེ་ term has the meaning of showing that there is another item of meaning that is to be connected in its place, even if the item is not explicitly shown in the basis of discussion, for example, in དེ་ལ་ཡི་གེ་བྲིས་ཤིག “please write a letter on that”, the that is substituting for paper. And, it is not demonstrating another meaning that it stands in for but is simply leading onto more of what is to be expressed, for example, in ཤིང་བཅད་དེ་མེ་ལ་འབུད། “the wood was cut and put into the fire”. This perspective applies to every usage of the དེ་ term.

yang chos spyi'i dngos po'i don gtso che ba'i dbang du byas nas dbye na/ de rang yin no/ /lta bu bden pa'i dngos po dang / de ma ston cig/ lta bu gsang ba'i dngos po dang / kho bo'i glegs bam de klogs shig/ lta bu bdag gi ba'i dngos po dang / rdo ba de 'degs nus sam/ lta bu bdag gi ba las gzhan pa pha rol po'i dngos po ste bzhi la dus gsum gar 'jug par 'gyur zhing / dbye tshul des lhag bcas las gzhan pa'i de sgra'i 'jug pa thams cad la khyab bo/ / yang dus nyid kyi dbang du byas nas dbye na/ na ning gi lo de la/ lta bu 'das pa dang / sang nyi ma shar ba'i dus der 'gro'o/ / lta bu ma 'ongs pa gnyis la 'jug pa yin cing / dbye tshul des dus kho na brjod pa dang 'brel ba'i de sgra'i 'jug pa tsam la khyab pa yin no/ /

When looked at from the perspective of its being a general phenomenon that is a thing of principal meaning, it is used in four ways in all three times. It is used for true things as in དེ་རང་ཡིན་ནོ། “Yes, that is exactly it!”; for hidden things as in དེ་མ་སྟོན་ཅིག “Please do not show that!”; for owned things as in ཁོ་བོའི་གླེགས་བམ་དེ་ཀློགས་ཤིག “Please read that book of his!”; and for things other than owned, of the other side, as in རྡོ་བ་དེ་འདེགས་ནུས་སམ། “Are you able to lift that boulder?”. This perspective applies to every usage of the དེ་ term other than use as a continuative.
When looked at from the perspective of time itself, it is used in two ways. It is placed for the past as in ན་ནིང་གི་ལོ་དེ་ལ། “in the previous year” and for the future as in སང་ཉི་མ་ཤར་བའི་དུས་དེར་འགྲོའོ། “we will go tomorrow, at the time of sunrise. This perspective applies only to those uses of དེ་ terms that are connected with the expression only of time.
bzhi pa gang sgra bshad pa ni/
(d) The གང་ term
The text says:
gang ming brjod pa'i dang po ru/ / dang po la ni gnyis pa sbyar/ / spyi la khyab pa nyid du 'gyur/ /
“Initial to the expression of some name The first having the second connected Becomes the encompassing generality itself.”

zhes pa ste/ gang yang rung ba'i ming brjod pa'i dang por rjes 'jug dang po ga la gnyis pa nga sbyar bas/ gang zhes grub pa de ni/ gang zhig dang / gang dag dang / gang byed/ lta bu gtso bor don gyi bye brag dmigs su mi 'dzin par spyi la khyab pa'i don can gyi sgra nyid du 'gyur te/ ci dang ji dang su'i sgra rnams dang yang 'jug pa phal cher mthun no/ /

Initial to the expression of some name whatever it might be, the first suffix, ག་, has the second, ང་, connected to it. The resulting གང་, as in གང་ཞིག་ meaning “something, which one, one which” etcetera, and གང་དག་ meaning “which ones, ones which”, etcetera, and གང་བྱེད་ meaning “which is done, what does it” etcetera, and so on becomes the term which itself, not standing for a specific meaning that is being picked out of the main meaning, has the meaning of encompassing the general situation. The use of ཅི་ and ཇི་ and སུ་ terms mostly conforms with the usage of གང་.
lnga pa bdag sgra bshad pa ni/
(e) The owner term
The text says:
gang ming gi ni ma mtha' na/ / pu ling+ga yi sgra med pa/ / de la pu ling+ga sbyar na/ / bdag po'i sar ni shes par bya/ /
“When to the lower end of some name Without pulinga term A pulinga is connected, that Is to be known as “the site of the owner”.”

zhes pa ste/ gang yang rung ba'i ming gi ma mtha' rnams su tsan+d+ra pa las/ uta kyi sde dang bcas pa'o/ / zhes pa ltar/ pu zhes pa pa sde dang / ling+ga zhes pa rtags te/ pa sde nas 'byung ba'i pho rtags pa dang / mo rtags ma dang / ma ning gi rtags ba gsum gyi sgra sngar med pa de la gsar du pu ling+ga'i sgra gsum po gang rung sbyar ba na/ de ni bdag po'i don gsal bar byed pa'i sar ni shes par bya ste/ dper na/ ja pa/ chang ma/ kha lo ba lta bu dang / gzhan yang / gyos po/ sgyug mo/ zla bo zhes pa rnams kyang rtags gsum ston pa'i bdag sgra yin la/ blo can dang / shes ldan lta bu ni gang zhig gang la yod par ston pa'i cha nas bdag sgra dang 'dra bar snang yang / sgra de gnyis bem po la'ang 'jug pas bdag sgra dngos ni ma yin no/ / 'o na pa dang ma gnyis pho mo'i rtags yin par grub kyang / ba yig ma ning gi rtags yin pa gang gis sgrub ce na/ smra sgo las/ ba ni spyi ru bzhag pa ste/ yul dus nges par ma bzung ba'o/ / za ba bza' dang za bo bzhin/ / ma ning dag tu bzhag par bya/ / zhes pas so/ /

The meaning of “pulinga” follows from Chandra’s statement “is together with the ut section”. “Pu” means “pa section” and “linga” means “gender sign” thus the pulinga are the “gender signs coming from the pa section”; they are the male gender sign པ་ pa, female gender sign མ་ ma, and neutral gender sign བ་ ba. When any of these three pulinga terms is connected to the lower end of any name no matter what it is which was previously without one of the three pulinga terms, that term will be known as the site which indicates the meaning of the owner. For example, ཇ་པ་། “teaman”, ཆང་མ། “beermaid, barmaid”, ཁ་ལོ་བསྒྱུར་བ། “driver (either gender)” and also གྱོས་པོ། “father of husband or wife”, སྒྱུག་མོ། “mother of husband or wife” and ཟླ་བོ། “spouse (either gender)” have terms of the owner that show the three gender signs.
The two terms ཅན་ and ལྡན་ in constructions such as བློ་ཅན། “one having intelligence” and ཤེས་ལྡན། “one possessing knowledge” seem to be terms of the owner because of their feature of showing something to be present for something but these two terms are also used with material things so they are not actual terms of the owner.
You might ask, “The པ་ pa and མ་ ma letters are established as the male and female gender signs but what establishes the letter as the neutral gender sign?” The Speech Door Weapon says, “The བ་ is posited as general; It does not especially signify object or tense. As in ཟ་བ་ “to eat”, བཟའ་མ་ “food”, and ཟ་བོ་ "eater" It is to be posited with the neutrals.”
drug pa dgag sgra bshad pa ni/
(f) The negation term
The text says:
gang ming brjod pa'i ya mtha' na/ / s+t+rI ling+ga yi sgra med pa/ / de la s+t+rI ling+ga sbyar na/ / dgag pa'i gnas su shes par bya/ /
“When to the upper end of some name Without strīlinga term A strīlinga is connected, that Is to be known as “the position of negation”.”

zhes pa ste/ gang yang rung ba'i ming brjod pa'i ya mtha' ste thog mar s+t+rI ling+ga ste/ mo rtags kyi sgra sngar bshad zin pa ma yig dang zhar gyis thob pa mi yig gnyis sngar med pa de la gsar du s+t+rI ling+ga sbyar na sbyor yul gyi don de ma yin pa'am med par ston pas dgag pa'i gnas su shes par bya ste/ dper na/ ma mthong / mi rigs/ zhes pa lta bu'o/ /

This is saying, “When a term of the strīlinga—either the མ་ ma letter that was explained previously as the term of the female gender sign or the མི་ letter incidentally obtained from it—is newly connected to the upper end, that is, before, the expression of any name no matter what it is that was previously without a strīlinga, the term shows the meaning of “is not” or “does not exist” in relation to that to which it has been connected. For example, མ་ མཐོང་། “not see” and མི་རིགས། “not tenable”. Therefore, it is to be known as the position of negation.”
gnyis pa gdams ngag brjod pas mjug bsdu ba
2. Drawing to a conclusion by giving advice
['di] la bzhi/ tshigs bcad 'grol tshul la 'doms pa/ nyan pa po spro bsring ba'i sgo nas 'doms pa/ bslab tshul go rim la 'doms pa/ gdams ngag snod rung la bstan dgos par 'doms pa'o/ /
dang po [tshigs bcad 'grol tshul la 'doms pa] ni/
a. Advice on how to understand the verses
The text says:
tshigs su bcad pa'i mtshams sbyor rnams/ / cung zad bsdus pa yod na yang / / de ni de bzhin sbyar bar bya/ /
“The junctures contained In the verses are few however It is how they are to be connected.”

zhes pa ste/ rgyal ba'i bka' bstan yan lag dang bcas pa rnams la tshigs su bcad pa yang dag par sbyar ba'i tshe tshig sdud mang ba yin pas rnam dbye dang tshig phrad la sogs pa'i mtshams sbyor mang du bsdus pa yod na lta ci smos/ cung zad bsdus par gyur pa yod na yang / de ni 'dir sngon du bstan pa'i slar bsdu la sogs pa ji skad bshad pa de bzhin du bsnan cing sbyar te bshad pa'i don khong du chud par bya ste/ dper na/ zag bcas zag pa med chos rnams/ / zhes pa lta bur/ zag pa dang bcas pa'i chos rnams dang / zag pa med pa'i chos rnams/ zhes sdud pa'i sgra dang 'brel sgra sogs bsnan nas don rang gis bsam pa dang gzhan la 'chad dgos pa bzhin no/ /

The junctures incorporated in the verse here are few and can hardly be mentioned compared to the many junctures of cases, phrase linkers, and so on contained in the translated Buddha- word, its śhāstras, and their ancillaries whose verses made with correct composition includes many phrases. Nonetheless, they have been added and connected just as was explained for the concluders and others shown earlier in here so that the meaning of the explanation could be fully comprehended. It is just like, for example, the phrase ཟག་བཅས་ཟག་པ་མེད་ཆོས་རྣམས། “with outflows, without outflows dharmas” must have gathering terms, connective terms, and so on added to it to become ཟག་པ་དང་བཅས་པའི་ཆོས་རྣམས་དང་ཟག་པ་མེད་པའི་ཆོས་རྣམས། “dharmas which are with outflows and dharmas which are without outflows” which can then be compre- hended for oneself and explained to others.
gnyis pa nyan pa po spro bsring ba'i sgo nas 'doms pa
b. Advice for extending the listener’s interest
['di] la gsum/ rjes 'jug med mi rung du bstan pa/ rjes 'jug shes pa'i dgos pa bstan pa/ de don la dbab pa'i tshul bstan pa'o/ /
dang po [rjes 'jug med mi rung du bstan pa] ni/
(1) Showing that not having suffixes would not be suitable
The text says:

sngon 'jug yod dam med kyang rung / / ming gzhi'i yi ge gang yin la/ / nyis 'brel yod dam gsum 'brel yod/ / A li bzhi las gang ldan yang / / rjes 'jug bcu po ma zhugs na/ / ming gzhan sbyor ba yod mi srid/ /

“Whether there are prefixes or not, A name-base letter whatever it is Might be in double or triple relationship And might have any one of the four āli but Unless one of the ten suffixes is in place, Connection to another name will not be possible.”

ces pa ste/ ming tshig gi sbyor ba rnams la gong du bshad pa'i sngon 'jug gi yi ge rnams sngon du zhugs yod dam med kyang rung ste/ dper na/ bka dang ka lta bu dang / 'phul rten gyi 'jug yul ming gzhi'i yi ge gang yin pa rnams la ska lta bu nyis 'brel yod dam/ skya lta bu gsum 'brel yod pa dang / de dag la A li bzhi las gang yang rung ba dang ldan pa/ bki/ ku/ ske/ skyo/ lta bu rnams la'ang rjes 'jug bcu po gang yang rung ba zhig ma zhugs na yi ge'i gzugs de nyid las ming don gzhan la 'jug cing sbyor ba ni tshul 'di la nam yang srid pa ma yin te/ da lta skyo lta bus don la 'jug par snang yang skyo' zhes pa'i 'a mtha' skad gsar bcad kyi tshe yi ge zor yang ba'i ched du phyis pa yin gyi don la thob thang med pa ni ma yin no/ /

For names and phrases that have their letters connected, whether one of the five, previously explained prefix letters has been put in place or not is, either way, acceptable for example, བཀ་ and ཀ་. However, the recipients of such fronting letters—the name-base letters whatever they are—might be in double relationship as in སྐ་ or triple relationship as in སྐྱ་ and those might have any one of the four āli associated as in བཀི་, ཀུ་, སྐེ་, and སྐྱོ་ but, unless at least one of the ten suffixes is in place, placement of that particular letter-form with and connection to another name-equivalent will not ever be possible in this system.
The སྐྱོ་ in the example just now is actually seen as something that is placed for meaning but this is because the འ་ ending on སྐྱོའ་ is erased in the revised language system in order to reduce the burden of lettering, it does not mean that it is actually not supposed to get it.
gnyis pa rjes 'jug shes pa'i dgos pa bstan pa ni/
(2) Showing the need for knowing the suffixes
The text says:

rjes 'jug bcu yi don shes na/ / 'dri dang klog dang bshad rnams kyi/ / mtshams sbyor sgra la thogs med cing / / 'brel pa smra ba'i mchog tu 'gyur/ / gzhan yang rjes 'jug shes pa yis/ / don gyi sbyor ba ma mthong yang / / don dang mthun pa'i sbyor ba shes/ /

“If the meaning of the ten suffixes is known, When writing, reading, and explaining, There will not be any hindrance to juncture’s terms and There will be the excellence of related exposition. Furthermore, by knowledge of the suffixes, Though connections of the meaning have not been seen Connections according to the meaning will be known.”

zhes pa ste/ de ltar rjes 'jug bcu'i bya ba dang gtso bor 'brel ba'i phrad dang rnam dbye la sogs pa'i sgra don gyi 'jug tshul legs par shes na mdo rgyud bstan bcos rnams yi ger 'dri ba dang / bris zin pa rnams brjod pa dag par klog pa dang / tshig don rgya cher bkrol nas bshad pa byed pa dang / der ma zad bstan bcos sogs rtsom pa dang / gzhan gyis rgol ba tshar gcod pa'i phyir rtsod pa byed pa la sogs pa'i tshe tshig don snga phyi mtshams sbyor ba'i sgra don rnams la blo gros kyi snang ba 'jug par thogs pa med cing / tshig don snga phyi go log pa dang / mi 'brel ba dang / 'gal ba la sogs pa'i skyon med par 'thad pa dang ldan cing 'brel chags pa kho na smra ba'i mchog tu 'gyur ba dang / gzhan yang rjes 'jug gi don tshul bzhin shes pa des bstan bcos la sogs pa'i don rnam par 'byed pa'i sbyor ba ste/ de'i 'grel bshad sogs sngon chad ma mthong yang / 'grel bshad sogs kyi don dang mthun pa'i tshig gi sbyor ba rjes su dpags te shes par 'gyur ro/ / zhes so/ /

If the functions of such ten suffix letters and principally, the ways to place their transformations—the terms of the relation- making linkers, cases, and so on—is well known, then, when one is writing out the sūtras, tantras, and śhāstras, when one is reading such written material correctly, when one is giving explanations to others—something that entails extensive explanation of phrase equivalents, and not only that but when one is composing śhāstras and so on, and when one is arguing to negate other’s argument and so on—the light of one’s intellect will, without hindrance, penetrate the transformations of the ten suffixes, the terms themselves that create the junctures between successive phrase equivalents. And, there will the excellence of exposition in which successive phrase-equivalents are always related and always have internal consistency and are free of the faults of being out of order, not being properly related, or being at variance with one another.
Furthermore, this sort of correct knowledge of the transforma- tions of the suffixes will enable one to surmise the connections that will decide the meaning of śhāstras, and so on, even when commentaries to the śhāstras and the like have not been seen. This is so because one will be able to correctly infer the connec- tions intended for the phrases in accordance with the meaning of their commentaries, and so on.
gsum pa de don la dbab pa'i tshul bstan pa ni/
(3) Showing how to arrive at the meaning
The text says:
rjes 'jug sbyor ba mkhas pa na/ / lung gi don dang sbyor ba dang / / bla ma'i man ngag gsum sbyar nas/ / don gyi thog tu dbab par bya/ /

“Having become expert in the connections of suffixes, The meaning of scripture and connection and The guru’s foremost instructions will, all three, come together; You should thus arrive right on the meaning.”

zhes pa ste/ rjes 'jug gi sbyor ba rnams la mkhas par gyur cing / mthun mong dang mthun mong min pa'i rig gnas la slob par 'dod pa de'i tshe na rig gnas mthun mong ba drang song dang paN+Di tas byas pa'i sgra tshad bzo gso rtsis snyan mngon sdeb zlos gar gyi bstan bcos dang / mthun mong min pa bcom ldan 'das kyi gsung rab dgongs 'grel dang bcas pa'i lung gi don dang / rjes 'jug gi sbyor ba la mkhas pa'i rigs pa dang / bslab bya'i don la mkhas pa'i bla ma'i man ngag legs par mnyan pa ste gsum po de phyogs gcig tu legs par sbyar te shes par 'dod pa'i gzhung don gang yin pa de'i steng du dbab pa ste bde blag tu rtogs par 'gyur ba de ltar bya'o/ / zhes so/ / de'ang gzhung don rtogs dka' zhing 'khrul gzhi yod pa rnams lung don dang sbyor dgos pa dang / lung don zab cing rgya che ba rnams man ngag gis 'grol dgos pa'i don te/ tshig sbyor phra mo re la'ang gsum ga tshogs dgos pa ni ma yin no/ /

When you have become skilled at connections of the suffixes and want to study the ordinary and extraordinary fields of knowledge, there is the following process. The meaning of the scriptures of the ordinary fields of knowledge found in the treatises made by the ôiṣhis and paṇḍits on the topics of crafts, healing, astrology, poetry, synonymy, composition, and drama or the meaning of the scriptures of the extraordinary topic of knowledge found in the recorded words of the Bhagavat and commentaries on their intent, and the cause of one’s expertise in the connection of suffixes, and the hearing of the foremost instructions of the guru, the one who is expert in the meanings of the training involved will, all three, nicely come together as one. Thus, you will arrive right on the meaning conveyed by whichever textual tradition it is that you wished to understand and so will easily become realized in that subject. Thus, that is the way to do it.
Now, taking the words “needing to take scriptural understanding and join it with texts that are difficult to understand and confus- ing” and “needing to use foremost instructions to unravel the profound and vast scriptures”, and then saying that these need to be put with each subtle “connection” of phrases or that all three need to be brought together is not what is being said.
gsum pa bslab tshul go rim la 'doms pa ni/
c. Advice on the sequence of the ways of training
The text says:

bslab la brtson pa'i gang zag gis/ / dang por nga ro rnams la sbyang / / sngon 'jug ming gzhi rjes 'jug gsum/ / klog gi ched du bslab pa yin/ / rjes 'jug bzhi yi sbyor ba ni/ / mnyan bsam bstan pa'i don du sbyar/ / yan lag de dag mthu yis ni/ / 'bras bu'i ched du don la dbab/ / bslab pa'i rim pa 'di yis ni/ / gang zhig 'bad pa chung ngus kyang / / shes rab myur du grol bar 'gyur/ / de phyir dang por 'di nyid bslab/ / de nas rgyas pa'ang mnyan byas te/ / bslab pa gang la dad pa yi/ / gzhung nyid bla ma dag las mnyan/ /

“Persons wanting to put effort into a discipline First must learn the tones then The threefold prefixes, name-bases, and suffixes Will be their training for reading. The four connections of suffixes will connect Them to listening, contemplating, and teaching. By means of those branches and for the sake Of the fruit, they will seek the meaning. Through this sequence of the trainings Someone of even small effort will Quickly have his understanding opened. Therefore, first train in this one Then, having listened also to extensive ones, For the training in which you have faith, Hear its main texts from the gurus.”

zhes pa ste/ rig pa'i gnas gang zhig bslab par bya ba la brtson pas 'jug par byed pa'i gang zag las dang po ba des ni/ thog ma nyid du nga ro zhes bya ba yi ge rkyang pa rnams yi ge'i mdo las 'byung ba ltar rang rang gi skyes gnas dang / byed pa dang / phyi nang gi rtsol ba rnams dang mthun pa dang / dbyangs ldan rnams kyang so so'i nga ro dbyung tshul dang bcas re re nas klog pa'i sgra gdangs la sbyang bar bya zhing / de nas sngon 'jug lnga dang / 'phul rten gyi 'jug yul ming gzhi sum cu dang / rjes 'jug bcu ste/ de gsum ci rigs pa tsheg bar gcig tu sbyor ba'i tshul yang byis pa bde 'jug nas 'byung ba ltar klog legs par shes pa'i ched du bslab par bya ba yin pa dang / klog la byang nas rjes 'jug ste der sngon 'jug kyang 'dus pas de dag rtags 'jug nas bshad pa ltar/ sgra don gang la 'jug pa dang / yi ge gang gis 'jug pa dang / tshul ji ltar 'jug pa dang / dgos pa ci'i phyir 'jug pa ste rnam pa bzhi'i sbyor ba rnams ni bla ma las legs par bshad pa mnyan pa dang / de'i don rang nyid kyis tshul bzhin du bsam pa dang / rang gi khong du chud nas gzhan la bstan pa rnams kyi don du sbyar te mkhas par bslab par bya'o/ /

klog dang brda dag gi yan lag de nyid kyi mthus ni/ gang bslab par bya ba de shes pa'i 'bras bu thob par bya ba'i slad du don la dbab nas nyams su bstar bar bya'o/ / de ltar bslab pa'i rim pa 'dis ni skyes bu gang zhig thos bsam la brtson 'grus chen po dang ldan pa rnams smos ci dgos te/ 'bad pa chung ngu tsam byas pas kyang tshig don la rmongs pa med pa'i shes rab myur du grol bar 'gyur ro/ / rgyu mtshan de'i phyir mkhas par 'dod pa rnams kyis thog mar sum cu pa'i gzhung 'di nyid bslab par bya zhing / 'di shes nas rtags 'jug la sogs pa 'di'i skabs phyi ma rnams dang / de nas brda sprod pa'i gzhung rgyas pa gzhan dang gzhan rnams kyang mnyan par byas nas khong du chud pa na/ theg pa gsum gyi gzhir gyur pa'i bslab pa gang la dad cing slob par 'dod pa de'i gzhung lugs yan lag dang bcas pa nyid bla ma rnams las mnyan par bya'o/ / zhes so/ /

These persons will, using the power of those two topics of reading and grammar, seek out the meaning in order to obtain the fruit, final mastery of the training they have undertaken. When they have found the meaning, they must cultivate the experience of it.
By training in this sort of sequence, even persons who make a small effort let alone those who put forth great exertion at hearing and thinking, will quickly have an un-obscured understanding of the words opened up. For that reason, those who wish to become expert must begin with training in this text itself, The Thirty. Having understood it, they must then listen to and absorb its later parts, the Application of Gender Signs and so on, and then other extensive texts on grammar, and then others further still. Then, they should hear the main and subsidiary texts from gurus for those trainings that form the basis of the three vehicles in which they have faith and want to train.
bzhi pa gdams ngag snod rung la bstan dgos par 'doms pa ni/
d. Advice on the need to give instruction to a suitable vessel
The text says:
slob dpon de nyid du 'dzin cing / / le lo g.yeng ba rnam par spangs/ / zo bzang dad pa la brten pa/ / skyes bu des ni myur rtogs te/ / de la dus su 'doms par bya/ / cig shos de las ldog pa'o/ /

“A being who accepts the āchārya as such, Who completely abandons laziness and distraction, And who depends on fine, good character and faith Does thereby become quickly realized so He should be instructed over time; The opposite one is the reverse.”

zhes pa ste/ bstan bcos 'di nyid kyi gdams ngag bstan du rung ba'i snod ni/ gdams ngag ston mkhan gyi slob dpon de la slob dpon du 'dzin cing / zhe sa dang bcas pas drin du gzo ba dang / 'gal rkyen bslab par bya ba'i gnas de la spro ba zhan pa'i le lo dang / bya ba gzhan la 'jug pa'i g.yeng ba gnyis spangs pa ste/ skyon de dag gis kyang glags mi rnyed pa'i rtag sbyor gyi brtson 'grus dang ldan pa dang / mthun rkyen zo ste rang bzhin bzang zhing / bslab bya'i gnas la mchog tu dad pa la brten pa'i gus sbyor gyi brtson 'grus dang ldan pa ste/ mtshan nyid gsum dang ldan pa'i skyes bu des ni bslab par bya ba gang yin pa de myur du rtogs par 'gyur bas de la dus shes par byas nas dus su 'doms par bya zhing / gong du bshad pa'i snod ldan gyi cig shos slob dpon la mi gus pa dang / le lo dang g.yeng ba can dang / rang bzhin ngan cing dad pa med pa rnams ni snod dang mi ldan pas/ dus su 'doms pa de las go ldog ste re zhig 'doms par bya ba ma yin mod/ 'on kyang phyi nas don du gnyer zhing 'dun par gyur na legs par rjes su bstan par yang bya'o zhes so/ /

This is saying, “The vessel suitable to be taught the instruction of this śhāstra: accepts the āchārya providing the instruction as the āchārya and through honouring him shows gratitude; concerning adverse circumstances has the persistent perseverance which abandons remains unaffected by the faults of laziness due to little interest in the subject to be trained in and of distraction to other activities; and, concerning conducive circumstances, has the respectful perseverance that depends on fine character, that is, a good nature, and faith in the superior value of the subject being trained in. A being who has those three characteristics does, through those qualities become quickly realized in his particular training. When such a person has been identified, he should be instructed over time. The opposite of the vessel explained above—someone who does not respect the āchārya, who has laziness and distraction, and who has a bad nature and is without faith—is not a suitable vessel. For people like that, “being in- structed in time” is reversed and for now they should not be instructed. Still, if they later become seekers who are motivated, they also must be taught nicely as followers”.

smras pa/
a 'dus rig byed srad bu la brgyus pa'i/ / ka 'phreng mkha' me'i grangs 'khyud ak+sha ra/ / ming gzhi'i sngon rjes 'jug pa'i rnam 'gyur can/ / tshig phrad rnam dbye'i mgul rgyan spel zin nas/ / spyi dang bye brag rtags kyi dbye ba yis/ / dus gsum bdag gzhan bya byed sgra don la/ / 'jug tshul sngon med legs bshad ma Ni ka'i/ / do shal gzur gnas skye bo'i rgyan du dgod/ /

For my part, I say,
Threaded on the A-containing Veda’s string Consonants holding the count of the space-fire ka string Have the manifestation of prefixes and suffixes of the name-bases, Which, having been developed into the necklace of phrase linkers and cases, Do, through the differentiation into general and particular gender signs, Become the terms and meanings of the three tenses and transitive-intransitive actor and action. Their previously unexplained mode of placement now nicely explained, is jewellery Of crystal arranged as an ornament for upright beings.
ƒ ƒ ƒ
gnyis pa rtags kyi 'jug pa bshad pa

d.crumb: II. the application of gender signs

f.d: PART II: THE EXPLANATION OF THE APPLICATION OF GENDER SIGNS
[rtags kyi 'jug pa bshad pa] la gsum/ ming gzhi'i yi ge spyi'i rtags kyi dbye ba bshad pa/ sngon 'jug gi rtags kyi 'jug pa bshad pa/ rjes 'jug gi rtags kyi 'jug pa bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [ming gzhi'i yi ge spyi'i rtags kyi dbye ba bshad pa] ni/
I. Explanation of the divisions of the general gender of the name-base letters

pho yi yi ge 'ba' zhig la/ / sde pa phyed dang brgyad gnas pa'ang / / sde tshan lnga ru dril byas nas/ / pho dang ma ning mo dang ni/ / shin tu mo dang bzhi bzhi ru/ / sde pa bzhi pa yan chad dbye/ / lhag ma bcu bzhi gnas pa la/ / tsa sogs gsum ni ca sogs sbyar/ / wa ni ba dang sbyar bar bya/ / lhag ma drug ni mo ru sbyar/ / ra la ha ni mo gsham ste/ / a ni mtshan med ces kyang bya/ /

“The male letters only allocated into Eight sections, one a half, also Having been condensed into five groups, Are divided into fours of the four Male, neutral, female, and extremely female Up to the end of the fourth section; For the fourteen left as the remainder, The three ཙ་, and so on, are connected with ཅ་, and so on, The ཝ་ is connected with བ་, Six of the rest are connected to female, The ར་, ལ་, and ཧ་ are called “barren”, And ཨ་ is also called “characterless”.”

zhes pa ste/ spyir bod kyi yi ge rnams la pho mo gnyis su dbye ba'i dbang du byas na/ dbyangs yig mtshon byed i u e o bzhi ni shes rab kyi rang bzhin mo dang / ka nas a'i mthar thug pa'i gsal byed sum cu po rnams ni thabs kyi rang bzhin phor shes par bya'o/ / des na pho'i yi ge 'ba' zhig ste gsal byed sum cu po kho na la sde pa phyed dang brgyad du gnas te/ sde pa dang po/ ka kha ga nga / gnyis pa/ ca cha ja nya/ gsum pa/ ta tha da na/ bzhi pa/ pa pha ba ma/ lnga pa/ tsa tsha dza wa/ drug pa/ zha za 'a ya/ bdun pa/ ra la sha sa/ phyed pa/ ha a rnams so/ / de rnams sde tshan lnga ru dril ba ni/ sgra drag pa pho dang / ran pa ma ning dang / cung zad zhan pa mo dang / de las kyang cung zad zhan pa shin tu mo dang / shin tu zhan pa mo gsham ste rnam pa lnga'o/ / de'ang sde pa dang po bzhi po rnams kyi dang po/ ka ca ta pa rnams pho dang / gnyis pa/ kha cha tha pha rnams ma ning dang / gsum pa/ ga ja da ba rnams mo dang / bzhi pa/ nga nya na ma rnams shin tu mor dbye bar bya'o/ / der ma phye ba'i lhag ma tsa sde phyin/ yi ge bcu bzhi gnas pa la/ tsa la sogs pa ste tsa tsha dza gsum ni rim bzhin sngar bstan pa'i ca la sogs pa gsum dang sbyar bar bya ste/ tsa pho dang / tsha ma ning dang / dza mor shes par bya'o/ / de bzhin du wa ni ba dang sbyar bas mo dang / lhag ma zha za 'a ya sha sa drug kyang mo'i yi ger sbyar bar bya'o/ / ra la ha gsum ni mo gsham gyi yi ge zhes bya zhing / a yig ni mo gsham gyi yi ge yin par ma zad ra la ha gsum las kyang rtsol ba shin tu zhan pa'i phyir na mtshan med kyi yi ge zhes kyang bya'o/ / zhes so/ / de yang gzhung phal mo cher/ ma ning mtshan med ces kyang bya/ / zhes 'byung ba ni yi ge nyams pa'o/ /

This is saying, “Overall, Tibetan letters are divided into two, male and female, and within that perspective the four vowel letter indicators ཨི་, ཨུ་, ཨེ་, and ཨོ་ are understood to be prajñā-natured female and the thirty consonants from ཀ་ through to the last one ཨ་ are upāya-natured male.
“Then, when the male letters only, that is, the thirty consonants exclusively, are considered, they have an allocation into eight sections, one a half. The first section is ཀ་ཁ་ག་ང།།; the second ཅ་ཆ་ཇ་ཉ།; the third ཏ་ཐ་ད་ན།; the fourth པ་ཕ་བ་མ།; the fifth ཙ་ཚ་ཛ་ཝ།; the sixth ཞ་ཟ་འ་ཡ།; the seventh ར་ལ་ཤ་ས།; and the half ཧ་ཨ།. “Condensed into five sections, they are of five types: the ones of stronger sound are male; the ones of moderate sound are neutral; the ones a little weaker are female; the ones a little weaker than that again are extremely female; and the extremely weak ones are barren.
“Then they are divided up so that the first ones of sections one to four—ཀ་ཅ་ཏ་པ་—are male; the second ones—ཁ་ཆ་ཐ་ཕ་—are neutral; the third ones—ག་ཇ་ད་བ་—are female; and the fourth ones—ང་ཉ་ན་མ་—are extremely female. The remainder, the ones not allocated there, start at the ཙ་ tsa section. In the fourteen letters left, ཙ་ tsa and so on—meaning the three ཙ་ tsa, ཚ་ tsha, and ཛ་ dza—are connected in sequence with the three ཅ་ ca, and so on already shown: ཙ་ tsa is understood to be male; ཚ་ tsha to be neutral; and ཛ་ dza to be female. Similarly, ཝ་ wa is connected with བ་ ba to become female, and of the rest, the six letters ཞ་ཟ་འ་ཡ་ཤ་ ་ also are connected to female letters. The three letters ར་ ་ཧ་ are named “barren letters” and the letter ཨ་ is a barren letter and not only that but, because it has an effort that is extremely weak compared with the three ར་ ་ཧ་ it is also named a “characterless letter”.”
Also, the wording “is also named neutral characterless” commonly appears in texts but this is a corrupted spelling.
gnyis pa sngon 'jug gi rtags kyi 'jug pa bshad pa
II. Explanation of the application of the gender of prefix letters
['di] la gsum/ ming gzhi las sngon rjes dbyung tshul bshad pa/ sngon 'jug gi rtags kyi dbye ba bshad pa/ sngon 'jug gi rtags kyi 'jug tshul bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [ming gzhi las sngon rjes dbyung tshul bshad pa] ni/
A. Explanation of how the prefixes and suffixes are selected from the name-bases
mo yi yi ge'i nang nas ni/ / 'jug pa'i yi ge bcu dbyung bya/ / 'jug pa bcu yi nang nas ni/ / sngon 'jug yi ge lnga dbyung bya/ /
“The ten letters for suffixing will be Drawn from the female letters And the five prefix letters will be Drawn from the ten suffixes.”

zhes pa ste/ mo'i yi ge la bshad ma thag pa ltar mo tsam dang / shin tu mo dang / mo gsham ste gsum du gnas pa so sor ma phye ba'i nang nas sngar sum cu par bshad pa ltar rjes 'jug gi yi ge ga nga da na ba ma 'a ra la sa ste bcu po rnams dbyung bar bya zhing / de'i nang nas kyang sngon 'jug gi yi ge ga da ba ma 'a ste lnga po rnams dbyung bar bya'o/ / zhes so/ /

This is saying, “The ten suffix letters, which were explained previously in the The Thirty as ག་ང་ད་ན་བ་མ་འ་ར་ལ་ས་, will be drawn from among the letters that would be allocated to the female itself, extremely female, and barren categories laid out in the explanation just given of female letters. And, then the five prefix letters ག་ད་བ་མ་འ་ will be drawn from among those again.”
gnyis pa sngon 'jug gi rtags kyi dbye ba bshad pa ni/
B. Explanation of the divisions of prefix genders
sngon 'jug yi ge lnga po la/ / pho dang ma ning mo dang ni/ / shin tu mo dang bzhi ru dbye/ /
“The five prefix letters Are divided into four: Male, neutral, female, and extremely female.”

zhes pa ste/ bshad ma thag pa'i sngon 'jug gi yi ge lnga po de la/ ming gzhi dang sbyar nas klog pa'i tshe sgra gdangs drag zhan du 'gyur ba'i cha nas pho ba yig dang / ma ning ga da gnyis dang / mo 'a yig dang / shin tu mo ma yig ste bzhir dbye bar bya'o/ / zhes so/ /

This is saying, “When the five prefix letters just explained are connected to a name base and read out loud with it, their pronounced sound changes, becoming stronger or weaker. They are divided into four categories according to the degree of change: male letter བ་ ba; neutral the two letters ག་ ga and ད་ da; female the letter འ་ ’a; and extremely female the letter མ་ ma.”
gsum pa sngon 'jug gi rtags kyi 'jug tshul bshad pa
C. Explanations of how the prefix genders are applied
['di] la gnyis/ mdor bstan pa dang / rgyas par bshad pa'o/ /
dang po ni/
1. Synopsis
de dag re re'ang bzhi byed de/ / gang la 'jug byed gang gis byed/ / ji ltar 'jug byed ci phyir byed/ /

ces pa ste/ sngon 'jug gi yi ge pho sogs de dag re re'i 'jug tshul la'ang rnam pa bzhi byed pa ste byed pa bzhi bzhi'i sgo nas rtogs dgos te/ 'jug yul ming gzhi'i yi ge gang la 'jug par byed pa dang / 'jug pa po sngon 'jug gi yi ge gang gis 'jug par byed pa dang / sgra'i 'jug tshul ji lta bus 'jug par byed pa dang / dgos pa ci'i phyir 'jug par byed pa rnams so/ / zhes pa'o/ /

This is saying, “The way that each of those male and so on prefix letters has its affixing done also has four aspects to it, so the affixing of the four should be understood through the four do’s: to which recipient name-base letter does it get affixed; which affix prefix letter does the affixing; how does it affix in relation to sound; and what is the necessity, why is the affixing done?”
gnyis pa rgyas par bshad pa
2. Extended explanation
['di] la gsum/ gang la 'jug pa dang gang gis 'jug pa mthun mong du bshad pa/ ji ltar 'jug pa bshad pa/ ci phyir 'jug pa bshad pa'o/ /
['jug tshul]
a. Explanation of how it is affixed
dang po [gang la 'jug pa dang gang gis 'jug pa mthun mong du bshad pa]
(1) Where and what is affixed, the explanation in common
['di] la gnyis/ dri bas mtshams sbyar ba dang / lan gyis bsnyad pa'o/ /
dang po [dri bas mtshams sbyar ba] ni/
(a) The question to start with
gang la 'jug par byed ce na/ /
“If you ask, “To which does it affix?””
zhes pa'o/ /
gnyis pa lan gyis bsnyad pa
i) The answer following
['di] la gnyis/ lan gyis bsnyad pa dngos dang / zhar byung mi 'jug pa bshad pa'o/ /
dang po ni/
a) The main part
pho ni pho dang mo la 'jug/ mo ni mo dang ma ning la/ / ma ning yang ni pho mo la'o/ / shin tu mo ni ma ning dang / / mo dang shin tu mo nyid la'o/ /
“Male is affixed to male and female; Female to female and neutral; and Neutral also to male and female. Extremely female is affixed to neutral, Female, and extremely female itself.”

zhes pa ste/ de la gang gis 'jug par byed pa po pho'i yi ge ba ni rang gi sde pa ma yin pa'i ming gzhi'i pho yig ka ca ta tsa bzhi dang / mo yig ga nga ja nya da na dza zha za ra sha sa bcu gnyis te bcu drug la 'jug go/ de bzhin du/ sngon 'jug gi mo 'a yig ni ming gzhi'i mo yig ga ja da ba dza lnga dang / ma ning kha cha tha pha tsha lnga ste bcu la 'jug go/ sngon 'jug gi ma ning ga yig ni ming gzhi'i pho yig ca ta tsa gsum dang / mo yig nya da na zha za ya sha sa brgyad de bcu gcig la 'jug cing / da yig ni ming gzhi'i pho yig ka pa gnyis dang / mo yig ga nga ba ma bzhi ste drug la 'jug go/ sngon 'jug gi shin tu mo ma yig ni ming gzhi'i ma ning kha cha tha tsha bzhi dang / mo yig ga ja da dza bzhi dang / shin tu mo nga nya na gsum ste bcu gcig la 'jug go/ zhes so/ / de'ang bskyed ces pa lta bu'i 'phul rten gyi ba dang da'i 'jug yul spyir sa ka ya gsum ga yin kyang 'jug yul gtso bo ni ka yig nyid yin pas skabs 'dir yang gang la 'jug pa de 'jug yul gtso bo de la byed dgos te/ de lta ma yin na 'gyed ces pa lta bu'i tshe 'a yig rang sde'i ya yig la 'jug par khas len dgos pas so/ /

This is saying, “Which affix is put on it is as follows. The male བ་ ba is affixed to sixteen letters: to the four male letters that are name-base letters not of its own section ཀ་ཅ་ཏ་ཙ་; and to the twelve female letters ག་ང་ཇ་ཉ་ད་ན་ཛ་ཞ་ཟ་ར་ཤ་ས་. In a similar way, the female prefix འ་ ’a letter is affixed to ten letters: to the five name-base female letters ག་ཇ་ད་བ་ཛ་; and to the five neutral ones ཁ་ཆ་ཐ་ཕ་ཚ་. The neutral prefix ག་ ga letter is affixed to eleven letters: to the three name-base male letters ཅ་ཏ་ཙ་; and to the eight female ones ཉ་ད་ན་ཞ་ཟ་ཡ་ཤ་ས་. And the ད་ da letter to six letters: to the two name-base male letters ཀ་པ་; and the four female ones ག་ང་བ་མ་. The extremely female prefix མ་ ma letter is affixed to eleven letters: to the four name-base neutrals ཁ་ཆ་ཐ་ཚ; to the four female letters ག་ཇ་ད་ཛ་; and to the three extremely females ང་ཉ་ན་.” In addition, for a recipient of བ་ ba or ད་ da fronting like in “བསྐྱེད་” there are in general three letters ས་ sa ཀ་ ka and ཡ་ ya but the principal recipient is the ཀ་ ka letter so in this case when the question “to which does the affixing get done?” is put forward, the answer has to be that it is done to the principal recipient. And for the case not like that, when there is something like “འགྱེད་”, it has to be asserted that the འ་ ’a letter is affixed to the letter ཡ་ ya of its own section.
gnyis pa zhar byung mi 'jug pa bshad pa ni/
b) Ancillary explanation of what is not affixed
pho ni ma ning la mi 'jug/ mo ni pho la 'jug pa min/ / ma ning rang la rang mi 'jug/ rang gi sde dang phrad pa na/ / pho yang mo la 'jug mi 'gyur/ / ma ning mo yang de bzhin no/ /

zhes pa ste/ sngon 'jug gi pho ba yig ni/ ming gzhi'i ma ning kha cha tha pha tsha rnams la mi 'jug cing / sngon 'jug gi mo 'a yig dang / de'i shugs bstan shin tu mo ma yig dag ni ming gzhi'i pho ka ca ta pa tsa rnams la mi 'jug pa dang/ sngon 'jug gi ma ning ga da gnyis ni ming gzhi'i yang ma ning kha cha tha pha tsha rnams la mi 'jug go/ yang sngar/ pho ni pho dang mo la 'jug/ ces sogs kyi dmigs bsal sngon 'jug rnams bzhi tshan du phye ba'i rang rang gi sde pa'i ming gzhi rnams dang phrad pa'i tshe na sngon 'jug gi pho ba yig ni ming gzhi'i mo ba ma dag la mi 'jug cing / yang sgras pho yig pa la'ang mi 'jug par bstan pa dang / de bzhin du sngon 'jug gi ma ning ga da gnyis kyang rang sde'i pho mo dag la mi 'jug pas ga yig ming gzhi'i ka ga nga rnams dang / da yig ming gzhi'i ta da na rnams la mi 'jug cing / sngon 'jug gi mo yig 'a ni rang sde'i ming gzhi'i mo zha za 'a ya rnams la mi 'jug pa dang / yang sgras sngon 'jug gi shin tu mo ma yig ni rang sde'i ming gzhi'i ma ning pha dang / mo ba dang / shin tu mo ma rnams la 'jug pa ma yin no/ / zhes so/ /

This is saying, “The prefix male བ་ ba letter is not affixed to name- base neutrals ཁ་ཆ་ཐ་ཕ་ཚ་. Prefix female འ་ ’a letter and, implied by that, extremely female letter མ་ ma are not affixed to male name- bases ཀ་ཅ་ཏ་པ་ཙ་. The two prefix neutrals ག་ ga and ད་ da are not affixed to the name-bases also neutral ཁ་ཆ་ཐ་ཕ་ཚ་. Also, there are the special cases related to the previous statement “male is affixed to male and female”, and so forth. The prefixes, when in contact with name-bases of their own section of four are treated as follows. The prefix male letter བ་ ba is not affixed to female name-bases བ་ ba and མ་ ma and in addition, it is taught that sound-wise it is also not affixed to male letter པ་ pa. Similarly the two prefix neutrals ག་ ga and ད་ da also are not affixed to the males and females of their own section, hence letter ག་ ga is not affixed to name-bases ཀ་ ka, བ་ ga, ང་ nga and letter ད་ da is not affixed to name-bases ཏ་ ta, ད་ da, and ན་ na.
