Prefix female letter འ་ ’a is not affixed to the female name-bases its own section ཞ་ zha, ཟ་ za, འ་ ’a, and ཡ་ ya and in addition, the prefix extremely female མ་ ma letter is not affixed to the neutral name-base ཕ་ pha, the female བ་ ba, or the extremely female མ་ ma of its own section.”
gnyis pa ji ltar 'jug pa bshad pa
(2) The explanation of how it is affixed
['di] la gnyis/ dri bas mtshams sbyar ba dang / lan gyis bsnyad pa'o/ /
dang po [dri bas mtshams sbyar ba] ni/
(a) The question to start with
ji ltar 'jug par byed ce na/ /
“If you ask, ‘How does it affix?’”
zhes pa'o/ /
gnyis pa lan gyis bsnyad pa ni/
(b) The answer following
pho ni drag pa'i tshul gyis te/ / ma ning ran par 'jug pa yin/ / mo ni zhan pa'i tshul gyis te/ / shin tu mo ni mnyam pas so/ /
“Male is via a stronger way and Neutral is moderate affixation. Female is via a weaker way and Extremely female is via a flat one.”

zhes pa ste/ sngon 'jug gi pho yig ba ni ming gzhi'i yi ge rang gi 'jug yul du gyur pa rnams la sgra dang byed rtsol drag pa'i sgo nas 'jug pa dang / ma ning ga da gnyis ni sgra rtsol ran par 'jug pa dang / mo yig 'a ni sgra rtsol zhan pas 'jug pa dang / shin tu mo ma ni sgra rtsol mnyam pa ste shin tu lhod cing nyam chung ba'i tshul gyis 'jug par byed do zhes so/ /

This is saying, “Prefix male letter བ་ ba is affixed to those name-base letters which have become its own recipients via a stronger sound and production effort and neutral ག་ ga and ད་ da both are moderate sound effort affixations. Female letter འ་ ’a is affixed via a weaker sound effort and extremely female མ་ ma has its affixation done via a sound effort which is flat that is, which is extremely relaxed and meek.”
gsum pa ci phyir 'jug pa bshad pa
(3) Explanation of why it is affixed
['di] la gnyis/ dri bas mtshams sbyar ba dang / lan gyis bsnyad pa'o/ /
dang po [dri bas mtshams sbyar ba] ni/
(a) The question to start with
ci phyir 'jug par byed ce na/ /
“If you ask, “Why is the affixing done?””
zhes pa'o/ /
gnyis pa lan gyis bsnyad pa ni/
(b) The answer following
pho ni 'das dang gzhan bsgrub phyir/ / ma ning gnyis ka da ltar ched/ / mo ni bdag da ma 'ongs phyir/ / shin tu mo ni mnyam phyir ro/ /

zhes pa ste/ sngon 'jug gi pho yig ba ni dgos pa dus gsum las/ lha bsgrubs so/ / lcags gser du bsgyurd to/ / lta bu byed pa po gzhan dang dngos su 'brel ba'i bya ba byas zin pa 'das pa bsgrub pa'i phyir dang / dngos po bdag gzhan gnyis las/ gzhan te/ btung ba/ bdug pa/ bsgrub bya/ bsgrub par bya ba/ bsgrub bya'i lha/ bsgyur bya/ bsgyur bar bya ba/ bsgyur bya'i lcags lta bu byed pa po gzhan dang dngos su 'brel ba'i bya ba'i yul gyi dngos po dang / bsgrub par bya/ bsgrub bo/ / bsgyur bar bya/ bsgyur ro/ / lta bu bya ba'i yul dang 'brel ba'i bya ba gsal byed kyi sgra nyid bsgrub pa'i phyir 'jug go/ sngon 'jug gi ma ning ga da dag ni shing gcod pa po/ gcod byed/ skyon dgag pa po/ dgag byed lta bu byed pa po'i dngos po dang / gcod par byed/ gcod do/ / dgag par byed/ dgag go/ lta bu byed pa po dang 'brel ba'i byed las gsal byed kyi sgra gnyis bdag gi dngos po dang / gdam pa/ gzung ba/ gcad bya/ gcad par bya ba/ gcad bya'i shing / dgag bya/ dgag par bya ba/ dgag bya'i skyon lta bu byed pa po gzhan dang dngos su 'brel ba'i bya ba'i yul gyi dngos po dang / gcad par bya/ gcad do/ / dgag par bya/ dgag go/ lta bu bya ba'i yul dang 'brel ba'i bya ba gsal byed kyi sgra gnyis gzhan gyi dngos po ste/ dngos po bdag dang gzhan gnyis ka bsgrub pa'i phyir 'jug pa dang / der ma gtogs pa'i dus gsum las/ gcod kyin 'dug/ gcod bzhin pa'o/ / dgag gin 'dug/ dgag bzhin pa'o/ / lta bu byed pa po gzhan dang dngos su 'brel ba'i bya ba byed bzhin pa da ltar ba bsgrub pa'i ched du 'jug ste/ da ltar ba ni byed las gsal byed kyi sgra nyid tshig grogs kyis bsgyur ba'o/ /

This is saying, “In relation to the needs of the three tenses, prefix male letter བ་ ba is affixed to make the past, the completed action of an agent in actual relationship with other as in ལྷ་བསྒྲུབས་སོ། and ལྕགས་གསེར་དུ་བསྒྱུརད་ཏོ།. In relation to the needs of the two of self and other thing, it is affixed to make other both because of making a term that distinguishes the thing which is the place of action of an agent in actual relationship with other as in བཏུང་བ། བདུག་པ། བསྒྲུབ་བྱ། བསྒྲུབ་པར་བྱ་བ། བསྒྲུབ་བྱའི་ལྷ། བསྒྱུར་བྱ། བསྒྱུར་བར་བྱ་བ། བསྒྱུར་བྱའི་ལྕགས། and because of making a term that distinguishes the action related to the place of the action as in བསྒྲུབ་པར་བྱ། བསྒྲུབ་བོ། །བསྒྱུར་བར་བྱ། བསྒྱུར་རོ།. “Prefix neutrals ག་ ga and ད་ da are affixed because of making both self and other things as follows: for the self thing, terms that distinguish both the agent thing as in ཤིང་གཅོད་པ་པོ། གཅོད་བྱེད། སྐྱོན་དགག་པ་པོ། དགག་བྱེད། and the verb action connected with the agent as in གཅོད་པར་བྱེད། གཅོད་དོ། དགག་པར་བྱེད། དགག་གོ; and for the other thing, terms that distinguish both the place of the action thing of action where the an agent in actual relationship with other as in གདམ་པ། གཟུང་བ། གཅད་བྱ། གཅད་པར་བྱ་བ། གཅད་བྱའི་ཤིང།། དགག་བྱ། དགག་པར་བྱ་བ། དགག་བྱའི་སྐྱོན། and the action connected with the place the action as in གཅད་པར་བྱ། གཅོད་དོ། །དགག་པར་བྱ། དགག་གོ. And, of the three tenses not incorporated there, they are affixed on account of making the present which is the continued doing of an action of an agent in actual relationship with other as in གཅོད་ཀྱིན་འདུག །གཅོད་བཞིན་པའོ། །དགག་གིན་འདུག །དགག་བཞིན་པའོ།, where the present is the distinguishing term of the verb itself modified by a phrase assistive.

sngon 'jug gi mo yig 'a ni mdud pa 'grol pa po/ 'grol byed/ yos 'thag pa po/ 'thag byed lta bu bya byed tha dad du snang ba'i byed pa po'i dngos po dang / mdud pa 'grol bar byed/ 'grol lo/ / yos 'thag par byed/ 'thag go/ lta bu byed pa po dang 'brel ba'i byed las gsal byed kyi sgra ste/ de rnams dngos po bdag yin pas de bsgrub pa'i phyir dang / 'grol gyin 'dug/ 'thag bzhin pa'o/ / 'gyur gyin 'duga'agrub bzhin pa'o/ /lta bu bdag gzhan gyi dbye bas ma bsdus pa'i dus da ltar ba bsgrub pa'i phyir dang / 'khor lo 'khor bar 'gyur/ don 'grub par 'gyur/ lta bu/ byed pa po gzhan dngos su med par bya byed tha mi dad pa lta bur snang ba'i bya ba byed 'gyur ma 'ongs pa'i dus bsgrub pa rnams kyi phyir 'jug go/ sngon 'jug gi shin tu mo ma yig ni mkhas par byas/ mkhas pa/ mkhas par byed/ mkhas bya/ mkhas par bya/ mkhas par gyur/ mkhas bzhin pa/ mkhas par 'gyur/ lta bu sngar bshad pa'i bdag gzhan dang / dus gsum gyi bye brag med par thams cad la mnyam pa ste mtshungs pa nyid bsgrub pa'i phyir 'jug go/

Prefix female letter འ་ ’a is affixed to make the distinguishing terms of the agent thing where the action and agent are seen to be different as in མདུད་པ། འགྲོལ་བ་པོ། འགྲོལ་བྱེད། ཡོས་འཐག་པ་པོ། འཐག་བྱེད། and of the verb action connected with the agent as in མདུད་པ་འགྲོལ་བར་བྱེད། འགྲོལ་ལོ། །ཡོས་འཐག་པར་བྱེད། འཐག་གོ. Those are self thing so, it is affixed because of making that. And, it is affixed because of making the present tense that the self-other distinction does not include as in འགྲོལ་གྱིན་འདུག །འཐག་བཞིན་པའོ། འགྱུར་གྱིན་འདུག །འགྲུབ་བཞིན་པའོ།. And, it is affixed because of making the future tense, an action that will be done, where the action appears not to have a different action and agent in that the agent is not in actual relationship with other as in འཁོར་ལོ་འཁོར་བར་འགྱུར། དོན་འགྲུབ་པར་འགྱུར།. Prefix extremely female letter མ་ ma is affixed because of equally that is, equivalently, making every one, without special cases, of the previously mentioned self-other and the three tenses as in མཁས་པར་བྱས། མཁས་པ། མཁས་པར་བྱེད། མཁས་བྱ། མཁས་པར་བྱ། མཁས་པར་གྱུར། མཁས་བཞིན་པ། མཁས་པར་འགྱུར།.

de yang dus gsum gyi dbye bas ni bya byed kyi las dang 'brel ba'i ngag gi sbyor ba thams cad la khyab ste/ bya ba'i las thams cad ma 'ongs pa dang / byed pa'i las thams cad da ltar ba yin pas so/ / bdag gzhan gyi dbye bas ni bya byed kyi las thams cad la ma khyab ste/ byed pa po gzhan dang dngos su ma 'brel ba'i bya byed kyi las rnams la ma khyab pa'i phyir ro/ / des na bdag gzhan gyi dbye ba mdzad pa ni byed pa po dang / bya ba'i yul gyi sgra rnams bsdu ba'i phyir du yin cing / de'i zhor la bdag gzhan dang 'brel ba'i bya byed kyi sgra phan tshun shed mtshungs pa rnams kyang bsdus pa yin la/ dus gsum gyi dbye ba mdzad pa ni bdag gzhan gyi dbye bas ma khyab pa'i bya byed kyi sgra lhag ma rnams bsdu ba'i phyir du yin no/ /

In addition to that, the distinction of three tenses runs throughout all spoken constructs connected with verb activity because every verb activity in relation to the action is the future and every verb activity in relation to the agent is the present. The distinction of self-other does not run throughout all verb activity because it does not pervade the verb activities of action and agent where agent is not in actual relationship with other. Therefore, the self-other distinction is made because of including the terms of the agent and of the place of action and, appended to that, including as well the terms of action and agent where self is in relation to other, terms which are of mutually equivalent force. The three tense distinction is made because of including the remaining terms of action and agent which are not pervaded by the self-other distinction.

'o na byed pa po med pa'i bya byed tha mi dad pa de gang yin zhe na/ bya ba byed pa'i gnas skabs su byed pa po gzhan dngos su mi snang ba zhig ste/ de yang byed pa po gzhan mi snang zhes pas/ dper na/ bdag 'gro'o/ / lta bu'i tshe/ 'gro ba de bya tshig yin kyang / 'gro bya 'gro byed gnyis ka bdag yin pas 'gro bya las gzhan pa'i 'gro byed med pas na 'di la bdag gzhan gyi dbye ba'ang mi byed pa yin no/ /

You might ask, “Well then, what about the intransitive action and agent where there is no agent?” When there is an action being done but agent-other is not actually apparent—which is also called “no apparent agent-other”—for example in བདག་འགྲོའོ། —the འགྲོ་བ་ is the verb but since the འགྲོ་བྱ་ action of going and འགྲོ་བྱེད་ the goer both are self then there is no goer other than the action of going. Therefore, in this case the self-other distinction is not made.

yang bya ba byed pa'i gnas skabs su byed pa po gzhan mi snang zhes pas/ dper na/ rdza mkhan gyi 'khor lo 'khor ro/ / lta bu'i tshe/ dang por skor byed gzhan yod kyang / 'khor bzhin pa'i gnas skabs su skor byed gzhan med par rang nyid ngang gis 'khor bas gnas skabs der bya byed tha mi dad pa'i cha nas bskor zhes mi brjod par 'khor zhes brjod pa yin no/ /

Further, when an action being done is one of “no apparent agent-other”, for example in རྫ་མཁན་གྱི་འཁོར་ལོ་འཁོར་རོ། “the potter’s wheel turning”, initially there is སྐོར་བྱེད་གཞན་ a turner and an other from it but once the wheel འཁོར་བཞིན་པའི་ is turning, that is, when it is just turning of itself without turner who is other, given that the situation has a non-separate action and agent, it is not expressed with “བསྐོར་” but expressed with “འཁོར་”.

yang byed pa po gzhan dngos su mi snang zhes pas/ dper na/ skyes bu zhig gi mdun du lcags shig rang bzhin gyis gser du gyur pa'i tshe/ skyes bu de'i bsod nams nyid byed pa po gzhan yin mod kyi de dngos su mi snang ba dang lcags rang nyid kyi 'byung ba rnams kyi byed pas 'gyur ba'i cha nas lcags gser du bsgyur ces mi brjod par gyur ces brjod pa ste/ de yang zhib tu dpyod pa'i tshe dngos po'i rang mtshan so so nas rang gis rang la bya ba byed pa 'gal yang / spyi ldog rags pa'i tha snyad tsam la 'gal ba med do/ /

Further, when agent-other is not actually apparent, for example in སྐྱེས་བུ་ཞིག་གི་མདུན་དུ་ལྕགས་ཤིག་རང་བཞིན་གྱིས་གསེར་དུ་གྱུར་པ་ “right before a person iron turned to gold by itself” the merit of that person is indeed the agent-other nonetheless that merit is not actually apparent and given that change occurs by the iron itself acting this is not expressed as iron turned into gold with “བསྒྱུར་” but with “གྱུར་”. Moreover, when this is analysed very closely, from the stance of the self-character of each thing involved, “something of itself to itself” transgresses action-agent but generally, from the stance of a rough take on it, merely in convention there is no transgression.
de dag gis mtshon nas skabs 'dir phra zhing zhib pa'i blos brtag dgos pa mang du snang ngo/ /
At this point these disclosures have revealed many items that need to be examined very closely and carefully.
gsum pa rjes 'jug gi rtags kyi 'jug pa bshad pa
III. Explanation of the application of the suffix genders
['di] la gnyis/ rjes 'jug gi rtags kyi dbye ba bshad pa dang / rjes 'jug gi rtags kyi 'jug tshul bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [rjes 'jug gi rtags kyi dbye ba bshad pa]
A. Explanation of the divisions of the suffix genders
['di] la gnyis/ spyir rtags gsum du dbye ba dang / nang gses brgyad du dbye ba'o/ /
dang po [spyir rtags gsum du dbye ba] ni/
1. General division into three genders
rjes 'jug yi ge bcu po la/ / pho mo ma ning gsum du dbye/ /
“The ten suffix letters are divided into three: Male, female, and neutral.”

zhes pa ste/ rjes 'jug gi yi ge ga nga da na ba ma 'a ra la sa ste bcu po de rnams la/ pho yig ga da ba sa bzhi dang / mo yig nga ma 'a gsum dang / ma ning na ra la gsum ste gsum du dbye bar bya'o/ / zhes so/ /

This is saying, “The ten suffix letters ག་ང་ད་ན་བ་མ་འ་ར་ལ་ས་ are divided into three: male letters which are the four ག་ད་བ་ས་; female letters which are the three ང་མ་འ་; and neutral letters which are the three ན་ར་ལ་.”
gnyis pa nang gses brgyad du dbye ba ni/
2. Sub-division into eight
pho la skyes bu rab 'bring gsum/ / mo la mo dang shin tu mo/ / ma ning 'gyur dang mtshan gnyis dang / / mtshan med dag dang gsum du 'dod/ /

ces pa ste/ rjes 'jug la rtags gsum du phyes pa de la slar yang nang gses kyis brgyad du dbye ste pho yig bzhi la ga mtha' sa'i yang 'jug can skyes bu rab dang / ba mtha' sa'i yang 'jug can skyes bu 'bring dang / ga da ba sa'i mtha' can yang 'jug med pa skyes bu tha ma ste gsum du 'dod pa dang / mo yig gsum la nga ma sa'i yang 'jug can mo tsam dang / nga ma 'a'i mtha' can yang 'jug med pa shin tu mo ste gnyis su 'dod pa dang / ma ning gsum ni/ ming gzhi'i pho yig gi mthar da'i yang 'jug yod med gnyis ka dang / mo yig gi mthar yang 'jug med pa kho na dang / ma ning mthar yang 'jug yod pa kho na ste/ gsum ni 'gyur ba ma ning dang / ming gzhi'i mo yig gi mthar yang 'jug yod pa ni mtshan gnyis ma ning dang / ming gzhi'i ma ning gi mthar yang 'jug med pa ni mtshan med ma ning ste gsum du dbye bar 'dod do/ / zhes so/ /

This is saying, “That division of the suffixes into three genders is divided again into eight sub-divisions. In the four male letters there are held to three sub-divisions: ག་ ga ending having re-suffix ས་ sa is “strongest being”; བ་ ba ending having re-suffix ས་ sa is “middling being”; and ག་ ga, ད་ da, བ་ ba, and ས་ sa endings without re-suffix are “weakest being”. In the three female letters there are held to be two sub-divisions: ང་ nga and མ་ ma having ས་ sa re-suffix are just female; ང་ nga and མ་ ma and འ་ ’a endings without re-suffix are extremely female. In the three neutrals there are held to be three sub-divisions as follows. Changeable neutral is threefold: as the ending on a male name-base with ད་ da re-suffix present or not, both; as the ending on a female letter without re-suffix only; and as the ending on a neutral with re-suffix only. Dual-character neutral is: as the ending on a female name-base with re-suffix. Characterless neutral is: as the ending on a neutral name-base without re-suffix.”
gnyis pa rjes 'jug gi rtags kyi 'jug tshul bshad pa
B. Explanation of how the suffix genders are applied
['di] la gnyis/ mdor bstan pa dang / rgyas par bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [mdor bstan pa] ni/
1. Synopsis
de yang byed pa bzhi byed de/ / gang la 'jug byed gang gis byed/ / ji ltar 'jug byed ci phyir byed/ /

ces pa ste/ de'ang rjes 'jug pho mo ma ning gsum po re re la'ang byed pa bzhi bzhi'i sgo nas 'jug tshul shes par bya ste/ 'jug yul yi ge gang la 'jug par byed pa dang / 'jug pa po gang gis 'jug par byed pa dang / tshul ji ltar 'jug par byed pa dang / dgos pa ci'i phyir 'jug par byed pa rnams kyis so/ / zhes pa'o/ /

This is saying, “Further to that, each of three suffixes—male, female, and neutral—additionally has four ways of being done and the way they are applied is to be known via these four: to which recipient letter does it affix; which affix does the affixing; how or in what manner does it affix; and what is the necessity for or why is the affixing done?”
gnyis pa rgyas par bshad pa
2. Extended explanation
['di] la bzhi/ gang la 'jug pa bshad pa/ gang gis 'jug pa bshad pa/ ji ltar 'jug pa bshad pa/ ci phyir 'jug pa bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [gang la 'jug pa bshad pa] ni/
a. The explanation of which it is affixed to
gang la yi ge thams cad la/ /
“To which? To all letters.”

zhes pa ste/ rjes 'jug gi yi ge bcu po de dag 'jug yul gyi yi ge gang la 'jug ce na/ ka nas a'i bar gyi ming gzhi'i yi ge thams cad la bye brag med par 'jug go/ 'o na rjes 'jug gi 'jug yul yin na 'dir bstan ming gzhi'i yi ge yin pas khyab bam zhe na/ ma khyab ste/ chos rje sa paN gyis/ mkhas pa'i kha rgyan du/ da sa dag ni yang 'jug pa dag go/ da ni na ra la rnams kyi'o/ / sa ni ga nga ba ma rnams kyi'o/ /zhes gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ /

This is saying, “To which recipient letters are those ten suffix letters affixed? They are affixed without caveat to every name-base letter from ka through a”.
“Well”, someone says, “If it is a suffix recipient letter, is it necessarily a name-base letter taught here?” No, because of what the Dharma Lord Sa Paṇ said in his Mouth Ornament of the Learned: “Both ད་ da and ་ sa are the re-suffixes. Da goes with ན་ na, ར་ ra, and ལ་ la. Sa goes with ག་ ga, ང་ nga, བ་ ba, མ་ ma.”
gnyis pa gang gis 'jug pa bshad pa ni/
b. The explanation of what is affixed
gang gis bcu po de dag gis/ /
“By what? Those ten.”
zhes pa ste/ yi ge thams cad kyi rjes su 'jug pa po yi ge gang dang gang zhig gis 'jug par byed ce na/ sngar bshad pa'i rjes 'jug gi yi ge bcu po de dag gis 'jug go/ zhes so/ /
This is saying, “Which of the letters that are suffixes to all of the letters is affixed?” Those previously-explained ten suffix letters are what is affixed.”
gsum pa ji ltar 'jug pa bshad pa
c. The explanation of how it affixes
['di] la gnyis/ mdor bstan pa dang / rgyas par bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [mdor bstan pa] ni/
(1) Synopsis
ji ltar rnam pa gnyis yin te/ / sgra yi 'jug tshul don gyi tshul/ /
“How has two aspects; Way of affixation by sound and way by meaning.”

zhes pa ste/ rjes 'jug rnams tshul ji ltar 'jug pa'ang rnam pa gnyis kyi sgo nas shes par bya ste/ rjes 'jug zhugs tshul gyi sgra drag zhan du 'gyur ba sgra'i 'jug tshul dang / de ltar zhugs pas don ci zhig ston pa don gyi 'jug tshul lo/ / zhes so/ /

This is saying, “How the suffixes are affixed is additionally to be known via two aspects: the way they are affixed in relation to sound, which is the change of sound to stronger or weaker that occurs in relation to their affixation; and the way they are affixed in relation to meaning, which is the particular meaning that is shown by them due to their affixation.”
gnyis pa rgyas par bshad pa
(2) Extended explanation
['di] la gnyis/ sgra'i 'jug tshul bshad pa dang / don gyi 'jug tshul bshad pa'o/ /
dang po
(a) Explanation of how they are affixed by way of sound
['di] la gnyis/ drag zhan spyir 'jug tshul bshad pa dang / nang gses zhib tu 'jug tshul bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [drag zhan spyir 'jug tshul bshad pa] ni/
i) The explanation of how they are affixed overall, stronger and weaker
pho gsum mo gnyis ma ning gsum/ / drag zhan bar ma gsum du 'jug/
“Three male, two female, and three neutral Are affixed as three—stronger, weaker, and moderate.”

ces pa ste/ rjes 'jug gi yi ge bcu las/ pho skyes bu rab 'bring tha gsum ming gzhi'i yi ge gang la zhugs kyang brjod pa'i sgra gdangs drag par dang / de bzhin du mo tsam dang shin tu mo gnyis zhugs na zhan par dang / 'gyur ba dang mtshan gnyis dang mtshan med ma ning gsum zhugs na bar ma ste ran par 'jug pa yin no/ / zhes so/ /

This is saying, “Of the ten suffix letters, the males of strongest, middling, and weakest being, no matter which name-base letter they are affixed to, cause an expressed sound that is stronger. If either the simply female or extremely female are affixed, it causes a weaker expression of sound. If one of the three neutrals—changeable, dual-character, or characterless—are affixed, it causes a medium, that is moderate, expression of sound.”
gnyis pa nang gses zhib tu 'jug tshul bshad pa ni/
ii) The explanation of how they are affixed in detail, with their internal divisions

drag pa gsum nyid nang phrad dam/ / gal te zhan pa nang phrad na/ / de la'ang nang gi cha shas kyis/ / de yang drag zhan gnyis su dbye/ / ma ning gsum du gang gtogs pa/ / drag dang phrad na drag par 'gyur/ / zhan dang phrad na zhan par 'gyur/ / gnyis ka dag dang phrad gyur na/ / de ni gnyis ka can du 'gyur/ / gnyis ka dag dang ma phrad na/ / gang du yang ni mi 'gyur ro/ / des na 'gyur dang mtshan gnyis dang / / mtshan med dag dang gsum du 'dod/ / de ni sgra yi 'jug tshul lo/ /

“For the stronger three, internal contact, and For the weaker, if there is internal contact, In addition the internal factor is used To divide them further into two, stronger and weaker. What has been incorporated in the three neutrals is: If contact is with stronger, it changes to stronger; If contact is with weaker, it changes to weaker; If contact is with both, It changes to something that has both; and If it has not contacted either, It does not change to either at all. Therefore, it is held to be three: changeable, Dual-character, and characterless. That is the way of affixation of sound.”

zhes pa ste/ gong du bshad pa ltar sgra gdangs drag pa rjes 'jug pho yig la skyes bu rab 'bring tha gsum nyid du dbye ba ni rjes 'jug phan tshun nang 'phrad ma 'phrad kyis yin te/ / dam zhes pa sdud pa'i tshig yin pas gang sdud ce na nang gi cha shas drag zhan gnyis su dbye ba sdud pa yin no/ / dbye tshul ni/ skyes bu rab 'bring gnyis la nang 'phrad yod pas sgra drag pa'i drag pa dang / skyes bu tha ma la nang 'phrad med pas sgra drag pa'i zhan pa gnyis su dbye zhing / dang po la'ang skyes bu rab sgra shin tu drag pa dang / 'bring de las cung zad zhan pa gnyis su dbye bas nang gses gsum du 'gyur te/ dper na/ skyogs/ skyabs/ skas/ skad/ bkag/ bkab/ lta bu'o/ /

This is saying, “As explained above, the division of the male suffixes with their stronger pronounced sound into three categories of strongest, middling, and weakest being is based on whether the suffixes are in mutual internal contact or not. The term “and” is a term of inclusion so what does it include? It gathers in the usage of the internal factor to make the division into two, stronger and weaker. The way that the division is made is like this. First, both the strongest and middling beings do have internal contact so they are stronger of stronger sound whereas the weakest being has no internal contact so it is weaker of stronger sound; in this way there is a division into two. And then, the first of those divisions is divided further into two: the best being of extremely strong sound and middling one a little weaker than that. Thus they come to have three sub-divisions, for example, སྐྱོགས། སྐྱབས། སྐས། སྐད། བཀག བཀབ།.

de bzhin du gal te sgra gdangs zhan pa rjes 'jug mo yig la mo tsam dang / shin tu mo gnyis su dbye ba'ang rjes 'jug phan tshun nang phrad na ste phrad ma phrad kyis yin pas de la'ang nang gi cha shas kyis mo tsam la nang 'phrad yod pas sgra zhan pa'i drag pa dang / shin tu mo la nang 'phrad med pas sgra zhan pa'i zhan pa gnyis su dbye ste/ dper na/ bskangs/ bskums/ skong / skom/ bka'/ lta bu'o/ /

“Similarly, for the female suffix letters with their weaker pronounced sound, there is a division into two: just female and extremely female. “For the weaker ones, if there is internal contact” means that the division is made on the basis of whether there is mutual internal contact of the suffixes or not. Thus, in addition, the internal factor is used to divide them into two: the just females have internal contact so there is stronger weaker sound; and the extremely weak females do not have internal contact so there is weaker of weaker sound. For example, བསྐང ། བསྐུམ ། སྐོང་། སྐོམ། བཀའ།.

sgra gdangs bar ma rjes 'jug ma ning la 'gyur ba dang / mtshan gnyis dang / mtshan med gsum du gang gtogs pa'i dbye ba byas pa ni ming gzhir 'jug tshul dang / rjes 'jug phan tshun nang 'phrad ma 'phrad gnyis ka'i sgo nas yin te/ bstand/ bskord/ stsald/ rkun/ bstar/ btsal/ lta bu ming gzhi pho yig gi mthar yang 'jug yod med gnyis ka dang / phyind/ thard/ 'phruld/ lta bu ma ning gi mthar yang 'jug yod pa gnyis ni sgra gdangs drag pa dang 'phrad pa'i dbang gis drag par 'gyur ba dang / 'gran/ 'gor/ 'gul/ lta bu mo yig gi mthar yang 'jug med pa ni/ sgra gdangs zhan pa dang phrad pa'i dbang gis zhan par 'gyur ba ste/ des na de gnyis ni 'gyur ba ma ning dang / 'dzind/ 'byord/ bsald/ lta bu mo yig gi mthar yang 'jug yod pa ni sgra gdangs drag zhan gnyis ka dang 'phrad pa'i dbang gis drag zhan gnyis ka can du 'gyur bas mtshan gnyis ma ning dang / mthun/ 'thor/ 'khrul/ lta bu ma ning gi mthar yang 'jug med pa ni sgra gdangs drag zhan gnyis ka dang ma phrad pa'i dbang gis drag zhan gang du'ang mi 'gyur bar sgra gdangs mnyam par gnas pas mtshan med ma ning ste dbye ba gsum du 'dod de/ de dag ni sgra gdangs drag zhan bar ma gsum du 'jug tshul gyi dbye ba yin no/ / zhes so/ /

“The neutral suffix letters with their intermediate pronounced sound have been divided into three. This division, which incorporates changeable, dual character, and characterless is done via both the way of affixation to the name-base and whether there is mutual internal contact of suffixes or not. They are held to be in three divisions as follows. In the two situations of being at the end of a male letter and either having or not having a re-suffix as in བསྟནད། བསྐོརད། སྩལད། རྐུན། བསྟར། བཙལ། and of being at the end of a neutral letter and having re-suffix as in ཕྱིནད། ཐརད། འཕྲུལད།, they change due to contact with a stronger pronounced sound to stronger. At the end of a female letter without re-suffix, they change due to contact with a weaker pronounced sound to weaker as in འགྲན། འགོར། འགུལ།. Therefore, those two are changeable neutral. At the end of a female letter and having re-suffix, they change due to contact with both stronger and weaker pronounced sounds to having both stronger and weaker, hence are dual character neutral as in འཛིནད། འབྱོརད། བསལད།. At the end of a neutral letter and without re-suffix, due to no contact with either of stronger and weaker pronounced sounds, they do not change to either of stronger and weaker at all but stay an equal pronounced sound and hence are characterless neutral, as in མཐུན། འཐོར། འཁྲུལ།”.
gnyis pa don gyi 'jug tshul bshad pa
(b) Explanation of affixation by way of meaning
['di] la gnyis/ mdor bstan pa dang / rgyas par bshad pa'o/ /
dang po ni/
i) Synopsis
don ni rnam pa gnyis yin te/ / snga ma gang ltar 'gyur ba dang / / phyi ma gang ltar 'gyur ba'o/ /

zhes pa ste/ rjes 'jug rnams don gang dang gang la 'jug par 'gyur ba'i tshul ni rnam pa gnyis yin te/ snga ma rjes 'jug nyid gang la zhugs shing gnas pa'i ming de'i don gang ltar te/ ji lta bu zhig tu 'gyur ba dang / phyi ma rjes 'jug gam mtha' des ming mtha' la sogs pa 'dren tshul gyis don gang ltar 'gyur ba'o/ / zhes so/ /

This is saying, “The changes that occur to meaning when suffixes are affixed has two aspects. There is the way in which the meaning of the prior one—the name that the suffix has been affixed to, that is, positioned on—has changed that is, what it has changed to. There is the way in which the suffix or ending will change the meaning of the subsequent thing by its way of drawing the name- endings and so on.”
gnyis pa rgyas par bshad pa
ii) Extended explanation
['di] la gnyis/ snga ma gang ltar 'gyur ba bshad pa dang / phyi ma gang ltar 'gyur ba bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [snga ma gang ltar 'gyur ba bshad pa] ni/
a) The explanation of the way that the prior one changed
snga ma sngon 'jug lnga bzhin sbyar/ /
“The prior one is connected exactly to the five prefixes.”

zhes pa ste/ rjes 'jug rnams gang la zhugs pa'i ming de nyid ming mtha' sogs la ltos nas snga mar grub pas/ des bdag gzhan sogs don ci zhig ston pa ni ming de'i sngon du gnas pa sngon 'jug lnga las gang zhig yin pa de'i nus pa dang ji lta ba bzhin du sbyar nas bdag gzhan dang dus gsum sogs gang yin rtogs dgos te/ dper na/ 'jog byed/ brdeg bya/ bkag go/ 'gag par 'gyur/ dgag bzhin pa/ bdag bstod cigalta bu'o/ / 'on te sngon 'jug med kyang / rdeg byed/ sgug bya/ phog go/ sgug par 'gyur/ rdeg bzhin pa/ rtag pa/ shog cig lta bu rjes 'jug rnams bdag gzhan dang dus gsum la 'jug pa lta bur snang mod kyi/ zhugs so/ / gas so/ / phyinadato/ / lta bu sa'i 'jug yang 'jug gnyis ka dang da'i yang 'jug tsam kho nas 'das pa rang dbang du sgrub pa dang / 'a mtha' 'das pa la gtan nas mi 'jug pa'i khyad par tsam las gzhan ma tshig grogs kyis bsgyur ba'i nus pas ma gtogs rjes 'jug gis rang dbang du bdag gzhan dang dus gsum la 'jug pa ni med do/ /

This is saying, “The names to which suffixes are affixed themselves have, in dependence on the name-endings, and so on, produced the prior one. The specific meaning—of self, other, etcetera—shown by that prior name has to be understood—as self, other, etcetera, whatever it—by connecting it just exactly with the capacity as it is of whichever one of the five prefixes has been positioned in front of it. For example, འཇོག་བྱེད། བརྡེག་བྱ། བཀག་གོ །འགག་པར་འགྱུར། དགག་བཞིན་པ། བདག །བསྟོད་ཅིག.” Despite that, cases are seen where, even without a prefix, suffixes are affixed to give the meaning self-other and the three tenses, as in རྡེག་བྱེད། སྒྲུག་བྱ། ཕོག་གོ །སྒུག་པར་འགྱུར། རྡེག་བཞིན་པ། རྟག་པ། ཤོག་ཅིག. Nonetheless, except for cases of ་ sa both as suffix and re-suffix and ད་ da only as a re-suffix independently making the past as ཞུགས་སོ། །གས་སོ། །ཕྱིནད་ཏོ།, and except for cases where suffixes affixed for self-other or the three tenses due to the modifying capacity of another thing, a phrase assistive (and apart from just the special case of འ་ ’a ending certainly not being affixed for the past), suffixes are not affixed at all for independent production of self-other and the three tenses.
gnyis pa phyi ma gang ltar 'gyur ba bshad pa
b) The explanation of the way that the subsequent one will change.
['di] la gnyis/ mdor bstan pa dang / rgyas par bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [mdor bstan pa] ni/
1. Synopsis
phyi ma dag gi 'dren tshul ni/ /
“The way of drawing the subsequent one:”

zhes pa ste/ phyi ma ming mtha' dang rnam dbye sogs kyi thob thang gi don ji ltar 'jug par 'gyur ba'i tshul ni snga ma'i rjes 'jug dang / phyi ma'i brjod bya dag la ci rigs par ltos pa'i sgo nas 'dren pa'i phyir de'i tshul smos pa ni/ zhes so/ /

This is saying, “the way that affixing changes the meaning where the meaning is the subsequent one—the province of the name endings, cases, and so on—is that the subsequent one is drawn forth through one of several classes of relationship that exist between the prior one’s suffix and what the subsequent one is going to express. Because of that, there is an explanation of the way the drawing forth works.”
gnyis pa rgyas par bshad pa
2. Extended explanation
['di] la gnyis/ ming mtha' 'dren tshul bshad pa dang / rnam dbye sogs 'dren tshul bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [ming mtha' 'dren tshul bshad pa] ni/
i. Explanation of the way of drawing the name ending
pho yis pho yi ming mtha' drang / / mo yis mo yi ming mtha' drang / / ma ning gis ni ma ning ngo/ /

zhes pa ste/ de yang / cig car/ thad ka/ sgrub pa/ gnyis ka/ mkhyend pa/ 'byord pa/ bskald pa/ thugs ka/ bsgrubs pa/ dgongs pa/ goms pa/ lta bu ming snga ma'i mtha'i rjes 'jug pho yig gis ming de nyid kyi cha shas yin pas mtha' sbyor dgos pa'i ming mtha' gzhan gyi ming gzhi'i pho yig drang bar bya zhing / de bzhin du/ gsing ma/ tham ga/ dga' ba/ lta bu mo yig gis ming gzhi'i mo'i ming mtha' drang ba dang / dgun kha/ dbyar kha/ gsal kha/ lta bu ma ning gis ming gzhi'i ma ning gi ming mtha' drang bar bya'o/ / zhes so/ / de yang ming mtha' rtags mtshungs kho na 'dren pa lta bur gsungs pa ni gtso che ba tsam la dgongs pa yin pas de kho nar ma nges te/ stag ma/ tshad ma/ tshab ma/ lhas ma/ lta bu phos mo dang / rkang pa/ dam pa/ mda' pa/ lta bu mos pho dang / ston mo/ bstar ba/ rgyal ba/ lta bu ma ning gis mo drangs pa yang mang du 'byung zhing / de nyid rtags ma mthun kyang brjod bde gtso bor byas nas sgra mthun drangs pa yin pas sum rtags gnyis ka'i dngos bstan gyi dgongs par gnas so/ / gzhan yang sngar na ra la gsum yang 'jug can ma ning dang / nga ma yang 'jug can mor bzhag pa ni 'jug yang 'jug bsdebs pa'i sgra gdangs kyi nus pa 'chad pa'i skabs dang / 'dir de rnams pho rtags su bzhag pa ni/ yang 'jug gi rtags kyis ming mtha' 'dren pa skabs don yin pas mi 'gal lo/ / gzhan yang dkond cogarind cen/ lhand cig/ land cig/ thabs cig/ chabs cig/ stod kor/ klad kor/ pad kor/ yungs kar/ rgya gar/ lta bu brda rnying la rtags mtshungs 'dren pa shin tu mang yang phal cher skad gsar bcad kyi zhus dag mang bas nub par mngon no/ /

This is saying, “When a prior name has to have another name ending connected at its end, given that the name ending constitutes a part of that prior name, a male suffix letter ended prior name will draw a male name-base letter for the other name ending, as in ཅིག་ཅར། ཐད་ཀ །སྒྲུབ་པ། གཉིས་ཀ། མཁྱེནད་པ། འབྱོརད་པ། བསྐལད་པ། ཐུགས་ཀ། བསྒྲུབས་པ། དགོངས་པ། གོམས་པ། . Similarly, a female ending will draw a female name-base name ending as in གསིང་མ། ཐམ་ག །དགའ་བ།, and a neutral one will draw a neutral name-base name ending, as in དགུན་ཁ། དབྱར་ཁ། གསལ་ཁ།.”
Now that statement, which makes it seem as though drawing forth only occurs as name endings being drawn by equivalent gender, is a consideration only of the principal way that it occurs and is not the only way that it happens. Male also draws female, as in སྟག་མ། ཚད་མ། ཚབ་མ། ལྷས་མ།; female draws male as in རྐང་པ། དམ་པ། མདའ་པ།; neutral draws female as in སྟོན་མོ། བསྟར་བ། རྒྱལ་བ།; and there are many other possibilities. All of these are cases not of gender matching but of sound being matched. They happen because of making ease of expression most important. This can be seen in the text of both Thirty and Gender Signs which shows that it is the intent of their author.
Furthermore, previously the three ན་ na, ར་ ra, and ་ la with re- suffix were defined as neutral and ང་ nga and མ་ ma with re-suffix as female which is their meaning in the context of explaining the capacity of the pronounced sound of re-suffix applied to suffix. Here, they are defined as male gender signs, which is the meaning in the context of the re-suffixes’ gender signs drawing forth the name ending, so there is no contradiction.
Furthermore, drawing the equivalent gender sign appears very frequently in in old orthography as in དཀོནད་ཅོག །རིནད་ཅེན། ལྷནད་ཅིག །ལནད་ཅིག །ཐབས་ཅིག །ཆབས་ཅིག །སྟོད་ཀོར། ཀླད་ཀོར། པད་ཀོར། ཡུངས་ཀར། རྒྱ་གར། but because of the heavy editing that occurred in the language revisions, these have mostly diminished in appearance.
gnyis pa rnam dbye sogs 'dren tshul bshad pa
ii. Explanation of the way of drawing the cases and so on
['di] la gnyis/ spyir 'dren tshul bshad pa dang / nang gses 'jug tshul bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [spyir 'dren tshul bshad pa] ni/
a. The explanation in general of the way of drawing

ming mtha' de dag nyid kyis ni/ / de nyid rang gi sgra mthun pa'i/ / chos dngos las dang byed pa dang / / sbyin dang 'byung khungs 'brel pa dang / / gnas dang bod pa'i sgra yang drang / / gzhan yang slar bsdu lhag bcas dang / / 'byed sdud bsnan dang bdag po dang / / dgag sgrub rgyan dang dus la'ang 'jug/ de dag snga shugs 'dren pas 'byung / /

“Those name endings themselves draw Their own concordant terms of Things, objects, agents, Giving, source, connection, Place and calling terms. And, furthermore, concluders, continuatives, Separators, includers, emphasisers, and owners, Negators, accomplishers, and timings also are affixed. Those come drawn by force of the prior one.”

zhes pa ste/ bshad ma thag pa'i ming snga phyi de dag nyid kyis ming mtha' de dag nyid rang gi rtags mtshungs pa'am brjod pa bde bas sgra mthun par gyur pa'i rnam dbye dang po chos dngos te ngo bo tsam brjod pa dang / gnyis pa las su bya ba dang / gsum pa byed pa po'am byed pa tsam dang / bzhi pa sbyin pa'i yul gyis mtshon nas ched du bya ba dang / lnga pa 'byung khungs dang / drug pa 'brel pa dang / bdun pa gnas gzhi dang / brgyad pa bod pa'i sgra rnams kyang drang bar bya zhing / de bzhin du gzhan yang rnam dbye'i yan lag tu gyur pa'am/ ma gyur pa'i tshig phrad slar bsdu dang / lhag bcas dang / 'byed sdud dang / bsnan pa dang / bdag po dang / dgag pa dang / sgrub pa dang / tshig rgyan dang / dus te tshe skabs la 'jug pa'i sgra la sogs pa de dag rnams kyang snga ma'i ming mtha'i shugs kyis 'dren par byed pa na sbyor tshul legs par 'byung ba yin no zhes pa ste/ de dag las drug pa 'dren tshul sum cu par yang 'byung la/ gzhan yang i ldan dang / la don dang / slar bsdu dang / lhag bcas dang / 'byed sdud dang / bdag po dang / tshig rgyan dang / cing sogs kyi tshig phrad rnams ming snga ma'i rjes 'jug gi shugs kyis sgra rtags gang rung mthun pa ji ltar 'dren tshul gyi sdom tshig mdor bsdus shig kho bos rang lo nyer gsum gyi tshe bkod zin pas der shes par bya'o/ /

This is saying, “The just-explained prior and subsequent names, where these names and endings themselves are due either to equivalence of own gender signs or are harmonious terms based on ease of expression, draw the terms of case one, things, that is, just expressing the entity of dharmas; case two, the objective; case three, agentive; case four, on account of, illustrated by the object of giving; case five, source; case six, connection; case seven, place and basis; and case eight, calling term. Similarly and furthermore, they draw the phrase linkers affixed to become either the branches of the cases or bases, the terms affixed for the concluders, continuatives, separation and inclusion, emphasis, owner, negation, accomplishment, phrase ornaments; time meaning timings and circumstances; and so on. All of them come along as nice ways of connection because all are produced through being drawn forth by the force of the prior name’s ending.”
One of those, the sixth case has its own way of drawing forth that is given in The Thirty. Furthermore, the ways that the phrase linkers—i-possessing, la-equivalent, concluder, continuative, separation-inclusion, owner, phrase ornament, ཅིང་ cing, and so on— are drawn forth by the force of the prior name’s suffix, whether due to concordance of sound or gender matching were set out in that one summary of these topics by Thonmi at the age of twenty-three. Thus, this subject should be known through that treatise.
gnyis pa nang gses 'jug tshul bshad pa
b. The explanation of how the sub-divisions are affixed
['di] la gnyis/ mdor bstan pa dang / rgyas par bshad pa'o/ /
dang po ni/
1. Synopsis
de dag nang gses gang 'jug pa/ / mthar sbyar 'og ma'i ming don las/ /
“Which of those sub-divisions will be affixed comes From the name equivalent to be connected beyond, at its end.”

zhes pa ste/ rnam dbye dang tshig phrad de dag gi nang gses gang dang gang zhig 'jug pa ni gtso bor rnam dbye'i phrad dang bcas pa'i ming tshig de'i mthar sbyar rgyu'i ming don 'og ma las shes par bya'o/ /zhes so/ /

This is saying, “Which one of those sub-divisions of the cases and phrase linkers will be affixed there? There is a phrase, which is the name together with its case linker. Then there is the name equivalent that is yet to be connected to the end of that phrase and which will, therefore, come beyond it. Principally, the sub-division that will be affixed will be known from the name equivalent beyond the phrase.”
gnyis pa rgyas par bshad pa
2. Extended explanation
['di] la gnyis/ rnam dbye'i nang gses gang zhig 'jug pa bshad pa dang / phrad kyi nang gses gang zhig 'jug pa bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [rnam dbye'i nang gses gang zhig 'jug pa bshad pa] ni/
A. The explanation of the internal divisions of cases which are affixed
spyir 'jug yod dam byed pa yod/ / de bzhin ched byed rten byed dang / / las bya blang bya bsgrub par bya/ / sngon du 'os pa gnas pa'am/ /
“There is generality for affixing and there is doing, Likewise does purpose, does support, and Karma done, acceptance done, accomplishment done, Prior is a suitable position, and …”

zhes pa ste/ de la rnam dbye'i nang gses gang dang gang zhig 'jug pa ni/ ming bdud rtsi lta bu'i rjes su gang zhig lta bu spyi la 'jug pa'i sgra sogs yod na ming snga ma la rnam dbye dang po 'jug pa yin kyang bod skad la dang po mtshon byed kyi sgra med pa shas che bas bdud rtsi gang zhig lta bu'am/ yang na bdud rtsi nyid gang zhig lta bu dang / yang ming de'i mthar 'tsho bar byed lta bu byed pa'i sgra sogs yod na rnam dbye gsum pa 'jug pas bdud rtsis 'tsho bar byed lta bu dang / de bzhin du sbyar te/ mos pa lta bu ched du byed pa'i sgra yod na rnam dbye bzhi pa 'jug pas bdud rtsi la mos pa lta bu dang / yang rten lta bu rten byed kyi sgra sogs yod na rnam dbye bdun pa 'jug pas bdud rtsi la rten lta bu dang / yang bsgyur lta bu las su bya ba'i sgra yod na rnam dbye gnyis pa 'jug pas bdud rtsir bsgyur lta bu dang / yang blang bar bya/ lta bu blang bya'i sgra sogs yod na rnam dbye lnga pa 'jug pas bdud rtsi las blang bar bya lta bu dang / yang na rgya mtsho lta bu bsgrub par bya ba'i sgra yod na rnam dbye drug pa 'jug pas bdud rtsi'i rgya mtsho lta bu dang / yang sngon du ming bdud rtsi ma lta bu yod la de la'ang bdag la 'chi med stsol lta bu 'bod par 'os pa'i don yod na rnam dbye dang po 'jug cing bod pa gsal byed kyi sgra'ang sbyar dgos pas/ bdud rtsi ma kye bdag la 'chi med stsol/ lta bur 'gyur ba sogs shes par bya ste/ 'am ni sdud pa'i tshig phrad do/ /

This is saying, “In regard to that, which sub-divisions of those cases are affixed for what is as follows. If a name like བདུད་རྩི་ has a generality term like གང་ཞིག་, or other such term after it, then the prior name has the first case affixed to it except that in Tibetan language there is no term that illustrates the first case, so there is བདུད་རྩི་གང་ཞིག་ or བདུད་རྩི་ཉིད་གང་ཞིག་ . Or, if the end of that name has a term of doing, that is, of the agent, like འཚོ་བར་བྱེད་ etcetera, added to it then the third case has been affixed to give for example བདུད་རྩིས་ འཚོ་བར་བྱེད་. Similarly, if it has a term that provides the meaning of something done for the purpose of something else, for example མོས་ པ་, then the fourth case has been affixed to give for example བདུད་རྩི་ལ་མོས་པ་. Or, if it has a term that provides the meaning of support like རྟེན་ etcetera, added to it, then the seventh case has been affixed to give for example བདུད་རྩི་ལ་བརྟེན་. Or, if it has a term of an action done to a karma like བསྒྱུར་ added to it, then the second case has been affixed to give for example, བདུད་རྩིར་བསྒྱུར་. Or, if it has a term of action that will be done where something is taken from it, for example བླང་བར་བྱ་ etcetera, added to it, then the fifth case has been affixed to give for example བདུད་རྩི་ལས་བླང་བར་བྱ་. Or, if it has a term where an action of accomplishment will be done, like རྒྱ་མཚོ་ added to it, then the sixth case has been affixed to give such as བདུད་རྩིའི་རྒྱ་མཚོ་. Or, for something prior like བདུད་རྩི་མ་ , if it were suitable to call out to, with something like བདག་ལ་འཆི་མེད་སྩོལ་, then the first case would be affixed and the term signifying the calling also would be be connected to give such as བདུད་རྩི་མ་ཀྱེ་བདག་ལ་འཆི་མེད་སྩོལ། “Amrita Lady, O, please give me immortality”. Etcetera, etcetera, these various types of change must be known.
The འམ་ “and” is an inclusion phrase linker.”
gzhan yang ming mtha' tsam gyis rnam dbye 'dren pa dang / ming mthas ming mtha' gzhan drangs/ des rnam dbye 'dren pa'ang yod do/ /
Furthermore, there is just the name ending drawing the case, and there is also the name ending drawing another name ending which in turn draws the case.

gzhan yang / nges bzung gi sgra sogs yod na snga mar dang po dang / bsgrub bya'i sgra sogs yod na snga mar gsum pa dang / ming mtha' de las byung ba'i sgra'am/ dgar bya'i sgra'am/ bsgrub bya'i sgra sogs yod na snga mar lnga pa dang / rten byed ltar snang gi bya tshig sogs yod na/ snga mar bdun pa 'jug pa'ang yod de/ dper na/ bdud rtsi de/ brjid pas nyi ma dang mtshungs/ sa las rtswa skyes/ mi las lha bzang / mi rtag pa las dngos por grub/ mtshon khar bsad ces pa lta bu'o/ /

Furthermore, if there is a term of identification, etcetera, then the prior one has the first case affixed; and if there is a term of an action that will be accomplished, etcetera, then the prior one has the third case affixed; and if there is a term of something arisen from that name ending or a term of segregation from it or a term that produces from it, etcetera, then the prior one has the fifth case affixed; and if there is a verb that appears to be doing support, then the prior one has the seventh case affixed. As an example of that, བདུད་རྩི་དེ། བརྗིད་པས་ཉི་མ་དང་མཚུངས། ས་ལས་རྩྭ་སྐྱེས། མི་ལས་ལྷ་བཟང་། མི་རྟག་པ་ལས་དངོས་པོར་གྲུབ། མཚོན་ཁར་བསད་
gnyis pa phrad kyi nang gses gang zhig 'jug pa bshad pa ni/
B. The explanation of the internal divisions of the linkers which are affixed

gzhan yang tshig don 'og ma las/ / bsdu rgyu yod dam med pa dang / / gong ma las kyang de bzhin te/ / rnam grangs dag kyang bkod pa las/ / bskyar ba yod dam med pa dang / / pho sgra dag ni mo sgra dag/ ming gi mtha' na yod med dang / / rgyan du gyur pa rnams la yang / / don la bsnyegs pa yod med dang / / bstan bya lhag ma yod med dang / / tshig don rdzogs dang ma rdzogs kyis/ / de dag nang gses rnam par dbye/ /

“Furthermore, from the phrase equivalent beyond, There is to be included or not and Likewise from the one before, too, From an arrangement of enumerations, too, Whether there is repetition or not, and Whether male terms and female terms Are at the end of the word or not, and For the ones become ornaments also Whether they follow up to a meaning or not, and Whether there is extra to be shown or not, and Whether the phrase equivalents are complete or not. Thereby, their sub-divisions are completely dissected.”

zhes pa ste/ gzhan yang ming mthas tshig phrad kyi nang gses gang zhig 'dren par 'gyur ba ni brjod 'dod tsam gyis grub pa re gnyis yod pa ma gtogs phal cher ming de'i mthar sbyar rgyu'i tshig don 'og ma las shes dgos te/ tshig don 'og ma gong ma dang mtshungs pa las/ gong ma bsdu rgyu yod na ming snga ma snga ma'i mthar sdud pa'i tshig phrad sbyar dgos te/ lha dang / mi dang / lha ma yin dang / dri zar bcas pa'i 'jig rten yi rang ste/ lta bu dang /

This is saying, “Furthermore, the name ending will draw one of the sub-divisions of the phrase linker and which one it will be has to be known not only from each of the two things that have been produced through what one desires to express but normally from the phrase equivalent that is to be connected at the end of, that is, beyond that name. “From the two equivalent possibilities of phrase equivalents before and beyond, if there is one before that is to be included, an inclusion phrase linker must be connected to the end of the prior name(s) as in ལྷ་དང་། མི་དང་། ལྷ་མ་ཡིན་དང་། དྲི་ཟར་བཅས་པའི་འཇིག་རྟེན་ཡི་རང་སྟེ།.

de bzhin du tshig don gong 'og mtshungs pa las 'og ma bsdu rgyu yod na 'og ma sdud pa'i tshig phrad sbyar dgos te/ lhas kyang btud na mis lta ci smos/ lta bu dang / mjug tu bya tshig lta bur lhan cig tu sbrel ba'i phyir tshig don snga ma rnams la phyi ma bsnan dgos na'ang / sdud pa'i bye brag bsnan pa'i phrad sbyar dgos te/ gser dngul zangs lcags gsha' tshe'ang sbyar/ lta bu dang /

And similarly, from the two equivalent possibilities of phrase equivalents before and beyond, if there is something beyond that is to be included, an inclusion phrase linker must be connected beyond as in ལྷས་ཀྱང་བཏུད་ན་མིས་ལྕ་ཅི་སྨོས།. At the finish, if a verb is added in order to put the whole thing together, then prior phrase equivalents must have the subsequent ones added to them as in གསེར་དངུལ་ཟངས་ལྕགས་གཤའ་ཚེའང་སྦྱར།.”

phyi mar ming tshig gi rnam grangs gcig gam gnyis sam mang po bkod pa las/ de dag kyang gal te don bskyar ba yod na snga ma snga mar rnam grangs kyi 'byed pa'i phrad sbyar dgos te/ 'chi med dam/ rnam sad dam/ mig mi 'dzum ni lha'o/ /lta bu dang / tshig don gnyis ka bskyar ba yod na rnam grangs kyi sdud pa'i phrad sbyar dgos te/ gtub cing gtub cing drag tu gsol bar byed/ lta bu dang /

“And, where there are one, two, or more enumerating names or phrases set out in a subsequent position, they too, if they provide repetition of the meaning, must have linkers that separate the enumerations connected to the prior ones as in འཆི་མེད་དམ། རྣམ་སད་དམ། མིག་མི་འཛུམ་ནི་ལྷའོ།. And if both phrase equivalents have repetition, then a linker for inclusion of the enumerations must be connected as in གཏུབ་ཅིང་གཏུབ་ཅིང་དྲག་ཏུ་གསོལ་བར་བྱེད།.”

ming gi mthar pa lta bu'i pho sgra gsar du sbyar yod na ming mtha' de nyid bdag po'i sgrar 'gyur ba/ rta pa/ sgrub pa po/ lta bu dang / ming gi mthar med/ min lta bu'i mo sgrar gtogs pa gsar du sbyar yod na ming mtha' de nyid dgag pa'i sgrar 'gyur ba/ 'chi med/ lha min/ lta bu dang / gsar du sbyar ba ma yin par dang po nas ming gi cha shas su yod na pho mo'i sgra de bdag sgra dang dgag sgrar mi 'gyur bar ngo bo gang yin pa de nyid sgrub pa'i sgrar 'gyur ba/ dam pa/ bla ma/ lta bu dang / tshig don snga ma dang chos mthun pa'i phyi tshig gzhi gcig tu bsdu rgyu yod na snga ma la mthun pa'i rgyan du gyur pa'i tshig phrad sbyar dgos te/ mdzes kyang mdzes la 'od kyang 'tsher/ lta bu dang / snga phyi chos mi mthun pa gzhi gcig tu bsdu na snga mar mi mthun pa'i rgyan 'jug ste/ khro ba spangs kyang dgra 'joms pa/ lta bu ste/ rgyan du gyur pa'i tshig phrad de dag kyang nges par don la bsnyegs pa yod na mi sbyar du mi rung zhing / tshig mdzes byed tsam yin na ma sbyar kyang rung ba dang /

“And if there is a male term like པ་ newly joined to the end of the name, then that name ending itself changes to a term of the owner as in རྟ་པ། སྒྲུབ་པ་པོ།. And if there is a term incorporating the female newly joined at the end of the name, like མེད། མིན།, that name ending itself changes to a term of negation as in འཆི་མེད། ལྷ་མིན།. And if there is a part of the name that was not newly connected but was there to begin with, then it does not change to the owner term or negation term but changes to a term that shows just what the entity is, as in དམ་པ། བླ་མ།.” “And, if there is a prior phrase equivalent to be included into one basis with a later phrase that is concordant to it, then a phrase linker cum ornament of concordance must be connected to the prior one, as in མཛེས་ཀྱང་མཛེས་ལ་འོད་ཀྱང་འཚེར།. And if inclusion into one basis is a case of former and later ones being non-concordant, then an ornament of non-concordance must be affixed to the prior one as in ཁྲོ་བ་སྤངས་ཀྱང་དགྲ་འཇོམས་པ།. Also, if those phrase linkers cum ornaments lead up to a specifier of meaning, it is not all right not to join them, though if the construction is simply making a nice phrasing, not joining them could be all right.”

tshig don snga ma'i de ma thag tu bstan bya lhag ma yod na snga ma la lhag bcas kyi phrad sbyar dgos te/ rgyas btab ste bzhag lta bu dang / tshig don snga ma'i de ma thag tu bstan bya lhag ma med par rdzogs na slar bsdu'i phrad sbyar dgos te/ rdzogs so/ / lta bu rnam dbye dang tshig phrad de dag gi nang gses gang dang gang zhig 'jug cing don ci 'dra zhig ston pa rnam par dbye bar bya'o zhes so/ /

“And if there is extra to be shown immediately after the prior phrase equivalent, then it is necessary to join the continuative linker as in རྒྱས་བཏབ་སྟེ་བཞག་. And if, there being nothing extra to be shown immediately after it, that prior phrase equivalent is complete and a concluding linker must be joined to complete it as in རྫོགས་སོ།. Which of the sub-divisions of the cases and linkers are affixed and the sort of meaning that they show is thereby completely dissected.”

de yang rnam dbye ni legs sbyar gyi skad la/ ming gi mthar sbyar bas tshig tu 'grub par byed pa'i rkyen si sogs nyer gcig ste/ bod skad la'ang legs sbyar dang bstun nas sngar gyi rnam dbye bdun po de rnams gcig tshig nyid dang / gnyis tshig dag dang / mang tshig rnams kyi dbye bas nyer gcig tu 'gyur zhing / 'di rnams kyi khyad par phra mo rnams shin tu 'byed dka' bar snang yang yi ges 'jigs pas ma spros so/ / tshig phrad ni/ ming tshig la ma sbyar na rang stobs kyis don mi ston cing / ming gi thog mtha' dang bar du sbyar na brjod bde ba dang / mtshams sbyor ba dang / don gsal ba la phan 'dogs pa zhig ste/ 'di dag phal cher legs sbyar gyi ni pA ta ste nges tshig gam mi zad par grags pa dang 'dra'o/ / de yang don gyi ldog pa kho na ston pa'i rnam dbye yin na tshig phrad yin pas khyab kyang / tshig phrad yin na don gyi ldog pa kho na ston pa'i rnam dbye yin pas ma khyab bo/ /

Additionally, where case is concerned, the Sanskrit language has the twenty-one circumstances of si and the rest, which are used to produce a phrase by connecting them to the end of a name. Similarly, in Tibetan, the seven cases mentioned above with the added divisions of singular being as it is, the dual plural being དག་, and the multi-plural being རྣམས་, has a total of twenty-one variants. These subtle distinctions seem to be extremely difficult to dissect and if one is afraid of letters one won’t find any joy in it. Phrase linkers, when they are not joined to names or phrases, do not show meaning of themselves. If they are joined before, after, or in the middle of names or phrases, then they do help to provide ease of expression, boundary marking, and clarification of the meaning. Thus for most part, they are like what is known in Sanskrit as ནི་བཱ་ཏ་ that is, like ascertaining words. Then again, if it is a case that shows only a facet of meaning, then it pervades being a phrase linker, but if not a phrase linker, it does not pervade being a case which shows only the facet of meaning.
bzhi pa ci phyir 'jug pa bshad pa
d. The explanation of why they are affixed has two parts
['di] la gnyis/ rjes 'jug gi dgos pa dngos bshad pa dang / zhar byung yi ge'i 'jug pa spyi'i dgos pa bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [rjes 'jug gi dgos pa dngos bshad pa] ni/
(1) The actual explanation of the need for the suffixes
ci phyir 'jug par byed ce na/ / yi ge'i khongs nas ming dbyung ste/ / ming gi khongs nas tshig phyung nas/ / tshig gis don rnams ston par byed/ /
“If you ask, “Why is the affixing done?” From the letters, names are drawn, From the names, phrases are drawn, then Phrases are what show meanings.”

ces pa ste/ rjes 'jug gi yi ge bcu po de rnams dgos pa ci'i phyir du 'jug par byed ce na/ sngon 'jug dang dbyangs yod med gang yang rung ba'i ming gzhi'i yi ge gcig gam gnyis sam du ma 'dus pa yin yang rung / rjes 'jug gi yi ge gang rung zhig ma zhugs na don gyi ngo bo ston pa'i ming du 'grub pa mi srid pas yi ge'i khongs nas ming dbyung bar bya ba'i phyir dang / ming gcig gam gnyis sam du ma sbrel du zin kyang mtshams sbyor bar byed pa'am/ don gsal bar byed pa'i rnam dbye dang tshig phrad sogs phal cher rjes 'jug las 'byung zhing rjes 'jug la ltos pas de rnams ma zhugs na don gyi khyad par ston pa'i tshig tu 'grub pa mi srid pas ming gi khongs nas tshig dbyung ba'i phyir 'jug ste/ de lta bu'i tshig gis 'jig rten du don rnams rjod par byed pa'i phyir don mtshon pa'i brjod pa ji snyed pa'ang rjes 'jug gi yi ge rnams 'jug pa'i dgos par grub bo zhes pa ste/ 'dir yi ge dang / ming dang / tshig dang / brjod pa rnams kyi khyad par bod skad kyi dbang du byas nas dbye bar bya'o/ /

This is saying, “If you ask, “What is the need for affixing those ten suffix letters, why is their affixing done?”, the answer is this. One, two or several name-bases put together is all right, no matter whether they have a prefix or a vowel or not. However, unless one of the suffix letters is affixed, a meaning, that is, a name that shows the entity, will not have been produced. Hence suffixes are affixed because names are drawn from letters.
Then, it is the linkage of one, two, or several names together that causes boundary connection. The cases, phrase linkers, and so on that make meaning clear normally are produced from the suffixes and depend on the suffixes so, unless the suffixes are affixed, the phrases that show distinctions of meaning cannot be produced. Hence suffixes are affixed because phrases are drawn from names.
Because the phrases are what cause the expression of meaning in the world, every expression that there is which demonstrates meaning also proves the need for affixing the suffix letters.”
That section has set out the distinctions of letters, names, phrases, and expressions needed for the Tibetan language.
gnyis pa zhar byung yi ge'i 'jug pa spyi'i dgos pa bshad pa
(2) Ancillary to that, the explanation of the need in general for using letters
['di] la gnyis/ yi ge'i 'jug pa rnams kyi rang bzhin gyi dgos pa bshad pa dang / yi ge'i 'jug pa ston pa'i bstan bcos 'di nyid brtsams pa'i dgos pa bshad pa'o/ /
dang po [yi ge'i 'jug pa rnams kyi rang bzhin gyi dgos pa bshad pa]
(a) The explanation of the natural need for the use of letters
['di] la gnyis/ dgos pa ldog phyogs nas bstan pa dang / nying dgos ldog phyogs nas bstan pa'o/ /
dang po [dgos pa ldog phyogs nas bstan pa] ni/
i) The need shown from an opposite perspective

mo yi yi ge med pa na/ / pho yig brjod pa med par 'gyur/ / pho yig de dag rnams la yang / / 'jug par bcas pa med na ni/ / ming dang tshig kyang gsal mi nus/ / ming tshig gsal ba med na ni/ / don rnams brjod par mi 'gyur ro/ /

“If female letters were not to exist, Male letters would become inexpressible, And if those male letters were To become without affixation, then Names and phrases also could not be distinct. If names and phrases were not distinct, Then meanings would become inexpressible.”

zhes pa ste/ mo yi yi ge gi gu sogs A li bzhi po med na pho yig kA li rnams kho nas brjod pa med par 'gyur te/ A li rnams la ltos pa'i brjod pa de snyed mi tshang bar 'gyur ba'i phyir dang / pho yig kA li de dag rnams la'ang A li dang ldan min ji ltar yang 'jug par bcas pa ste/ 'jug pa'i yi ge bcu med par gyur na ni don gyi ngo bo ston pa'i ming dang / khyad par ston pa'i tshig kyang gsal bar mi nus par gong du bshad zin pa'i phyir dang / ming dang tshig gsal bar gyur pa med na ni don gyi rnam pa rang dang gzhan la mtshon zhing go bar byed pa'i brjod pa rnams kyang med par 'gyur ro/ / des na A li rnams ni kA li'i brjod pa yongs su rdzogs pa'i phyir dang / 'jug pa rnams ni ming tshig gsal ba'i phyir dang / ming tshig rnams ni don brjod pa'i phyir 'jug pas yi ge'i sbyor ba rnams ni dgos pa chen po dang bcas pa yin no/ / zhes so/ /

This is saying, “If the female letters gigu and so on—the four āli— were not to exist, then there would be no expressions coming from the male letters kāli because all expressions that there are that depend on the āli would thereby be incomplete. And if those male letters kāli, no matter whether they did or did not have āli, were to become without the affixable ones, that is, without the ten letters to be affixed, then the names that convey meaning by showing the entity, and the phrases that show the distinctions of the meanings of those name would also thereby be not present because of what has been explained above. And, if the name and phrases were to become non distinct like that, then the expressions that demonstrate or convey the meaning to oneself and others would also become non- existent. Therefore, there is a very great need for the connection of letters that comes with the affixation of the ālis because they make the kāli expressions whole, with the affixes because they cause the presence of names and phrases, and with names and phrases because they express the meaning.
gnyis pa nying dgos ldog phyogs nas bstan pa ni/
ii) The core need shown from an opposite perspective
de ltar gyur na 'jig rten du/ / don mtshon brjod pa kun kyang med/ / rig byed smra ba'ang yod mi 'gyur/ / nyan thos rang rgyal sangs rgyas kyi/ / bslab pa rnams kyang med par 'gyur/ /

zhes pa ste/ de ltar ming tshig brjod pa thams cad med par gyur na 'jig rten 'dir don mtshon par byed pa'i brjod pa ste lung du ston pa'i sgra skad thams cad mi 'byung bas de la ltos pa'i 'jig rten pa dang mthun mong ba'i bzo gnas dang / rtsis dang / snyan ngag sogs rig byed smra ba rnams kyang yod par mi 'gyur zhing / 'jig rten dang mthun mong min pa'i shes bya nyan thos dang / rang sangs rgyas dang / rdzogs pa'i sangs rgyas kyi bslab pa rnams ston cing smra ba'ang med par 'gyur ba de'i phyir ming tshig brjod pa thams cad 'jig rten du yod na ni 'khor 'das kyi blang dor mtha' dag ston cing smra ba 'byung la/ blang dor la zhugs na ni gnas skabs dang mthar thug gi don thams cad 'grub pa yin no zhes so/ /

This is saying, “If like that, every name, phrase, and expression were to become non-existent, then every expression that causes the conveyance of meaning in this world, that is, all the articulated sounds of language, would cease to occur. Thus all the things that depend on them such as the worldly, ordinary things of crafts, calculations, the poetry, and so on, and the propounders of the Vedas would become non-existent. And as well as that, the showing and propounding of the knowables not common to the world, which are the trainings related to shravaka, pratyekabuddha, and complete buddha, would also become non-existent.
The opposite of that is that, if all of the names, phrases, and expressions were to exist in the world, then the entirety of acceptance and rejection in relation to saîsāra and nirvāṇa would be shown and propounded and, for someone who became involved in such acceptance and rejection, every meaning both relative and ultimate would be produced.”
gnyis pa yi ge'i 'jug pa ston pa'i bstan bcos 'di nyid brtsams pa'i dgos pa bshad pa
(b) The explanation of the need for composition of this particular treatise that shows the use of letters
['di] la gnyis/ dgos pa dngos bshad pa dang / dgos pa de 'grub par smon pa'o/ /
dang po [dgos pa dngos bshad pa] ni/
i) Actual explanation of the need

ji ltar 'jig rten sems can rnams/ / phung po khams dang skye mched dang / / grub mtha' gzhan yang yod na yang / / rang nyid kyis ni mi shes bzhin/ / de bzhin yi ge'i 'jug tshul rnams/ / smra ba kun la gnas gyur kyang / / rang tshul de nyid mi shes pas/ / don la sbyor ba ga la shes/ / de phyir smra ba'i dbang phyug gi/ rjes smras/

“How would it be—sentient beings of the world Having skandhas, dhātus, ayatanas, and Tenet systems, and furthermore existing yet, Themselves not understanding themselves? Likewise, the ways of affixing letters Might be present in every one who speaks but, How could they, not understanding its ways, Know how to connect them to be meaningful? Therefore may this, spoken following The lords of speech …”

zhes pa ste/ dpe ji ltar na 'jig rten gyi sems can rnams la gzugs sogs phung po dang / mig gi khams sogs khams dang / mig gi skye mched sogs skye mched rnams rang rang la yod par ma zad/ grub pa'i mthas bzhag pa gzhan yang grangs can pa'i de nyid nyer lnga dang / theg chen pa'i rnam shes tshogs brgyad sogs kyang yod cing / sngon nas lhan cig tu 'grogs pa yin kyang / de lta bu'i rnam gzhag gzhan gyis ma bstan na rang nyid kyis mi shes pa de bzhin du rang rang gi yi ge rnams ji ltar 'jug pa'i tshul yang yul so so'i lung ston pa'i sgra skad kyi smra ba thams cad la rang bzhin gyis gnas pa ste med pa mi srid kyang / gzhan gyis brda ma sprad par rang nyid kyis yi ge rnams ming tshig sogs la 'jug pa'i tshul de nyid kyang mi shes na ming tshig la sogs pa de rnams bye brag phye nas don la ji ltar sbyor ba'i tshul ga la shes te mi shes so/ / de bas na blang dor mtha' dag shes pa'i rgyu ming tshig yi ge'i sbyor ba rnams gsal bar byed pa'i bod skad la mkho ba'i bstan bcos 'di nyid 'phags yul la sogs pa'i smra ba'i dbang phyug mkhas pa rnams kyi brda sprod pa'i bstan bcos kyi rjes su 'brangs nas thu mi bdag gis brtse bas smras pa yin no/ / zhes so/ /

This is saying, “How for example, would it be? The sentient beings of the world each have their own skandhas of form and so on, dhatus of eye and so on, and ayatanas of eye and so on, and not only that but also have the items defined in their tenet systems—the Samkhyas twenty-five suchnesses, the Great Vehicles’s eight-fold grouping of consciousness, and so on. Yet, despite that fact that all they do have these things, if such classifications were not taught to them by another, they themselves would not know of them. Similarly, for everyone who speaks a language, the usage of their letters and the articulation of the language of their country is naturally present in them—it is not possible that it could be non- existent. Yet, if another person did not pass it on to them and so if they themselves did not know how letters were affixed in names, phrases and so on, how could they know how the particulars of names, phrases, and so on are connected to be meaningful? They could not know!”
“Therefore, I, Thumi, out of love, have set forth this very śhāstra needed for the Tibetan language, one that clearly shows the connections of letters of the names and phrases and which in itself is the cause of knowing the entirety of acceptance and rejection. I have done so following the śhāstras of grammar of the expert, lords of speech of the Noble Land, and so on.”
gnyis pa dgos pa de 'grub par smon pa ni/
ii) Prayer for the accomplishment of the aspiration
'di kun rtogs gyur cig/
“May this be comprehended by all.”

ces pa ste/ de ltar yi ge'i 'jug pa legs par sbyar ba'i tshul 'di gangs can skye bo kun gyis rtogs nas ming tshig brjod pa thams cad la rmongs pa med par smra ba'i dbang phyug chen por gyur cig ces nying dgos de rnams 'grub pa'i thugs smon mdzad pa'o/ /

This is saying, “‘May this good composition on affixing letters be comprehended by all the beings of the Snowy Land and through that may they become great lords of speech without any lack of knowledge of names, phrases, and expressions’, which is a prayer of aspiration made by him that they accomplish the core meaning.”

smras pa/
shAkya seng+ge'i bstan la rab zhugs shing / / lag pa'i mig la dbyangs 'jug bzhi bcu dang / / mtshams kyi bgrod par 'phul rten rtse zung gis/ / brgyan pa'i 'bod bya ldan pa gang de yis/ / gangs can mig gcig sam+b+ho Ta yi gzhung / /

I would like to say:
With the teaching of the Lion of the Śhākyas firmly established, The fourteen vowels in the eye of the hand, and The frontings that are the transit from the boundary, Ornament what is to be spoken which in turn produced The text of Sambhota, the one eye of the Snowy Land.
gangs can brda sprod phyi mo sum rtags don/ / gangs can mkhas pa kun gyi legs bshad bzhin/ / gangs can bstan 'gro'i don du sbyar mod kyi/ / rgyal bstan snang gter dus ris sgrib la nye/ /

The meanings of the mother grammars Thirty and Signs of the Snowy Land, As shown in the good explanations of all the experts of the Snowy Land, Do connect to the aims of the teaching and migrators of the Snowy Land, Nevertheless, the conqueror’s teaching is becoming dark.
dpang gyur mkhas pa'i mtsho skyes phal cher zum/ / gzu lum spyod pa'i 'byung bya rang dgar rgyu/ / bsil ljongs skye bo'i gdong mun ji ltar sel/ /
gdung sprul phal cher 'dod yon spyod la yengs/ / sgom chen phal cher zog rdzun bya bas brel/ / mkhas rlom phal cher tshong zhing las la spyod/ / kye ma thub bstan su yis 'dzin par 'gyur/ /
don gnyer 'dun pa'i kar+Na gting nas 'gags/ / legs nyes lta ba'i tsak+Shu 'grib kyis non/ / phyogs lhung gdon gyis ma na cher brlams pa/ / de dag legs bshad nA das ci zhig bya/ /
'on kyang gzur gnas dpyod ldan mkha' nor gyis/ / bskul tshig tsha zer lan mang spros pa'i tshe/ / legs bshad sbrang rtsi skyug dang mi skyug gi/ rang dbang 'dab stong can la yod ma yin/ /

Right before me these fine analysers enjoy themselves in their Mistake-filled expanse with many emphatic zapping replies But the wretched vomit of their elegant explanations Cannot stand up to this explanation having a thousand leaves.
de phyir 'dir 'bad legs byas 'bab ldan ma/ / brgya phrag gcig tu bsdoms pa'i rnam sad chus/ / rab rmongs khyab 'jug rkang dri bkrus la slar/ / byang chen rgya mtsho'i gsos su 'jug gyur cig/

Therefore, may the nice effort that has descended here, A water of wakening that wakes up one hundred with just one, Wash the feet of these utterly stupid Vishnus so that they once again Enter the reviving ocean of great enlightenment.

ces yul gangs can gyi skad kyis brda sprod pa'i bstan bcos sum cu pa dang / rtags kyi 'jug pa'i rnam bshad mkhas mchog si tu'i zhal lung zhes bya ba 'di ni/ sdom brtson mang du thos pa'i dge slong dz+nyA na mi tras nan chen pos bskul ma mdzad pa la brten nas mkhas grub dam pa ngag dbang rdo rje dpal bzang po'i zhabs rdul spyi bos reg cing / spel khang paN+Di ta chen po'i zhal gyi bdud rtsi cha shas tsam myangs pas bod kyi brda dag gi bstan bcos phal mo che'i dgongs don smra ba la mkhas pa'i mdun sar mi zhum pa'i spobs pa cung zad thob pa'i shAkya'i dge slong d+harma b+ha dra zhes bya bas sum rtags dang smra sgo dang mkhas pa'i kha rgyan la sogs pa'i bod kyi brda sprod pa'i bstan bcos rtsa 'grel mang po la zhib tu dpyad de de dag gi legs cha mtha' dag phyogs gcig tu btus nas rang lo so lnga pa zad pa zhes pa me stag lo'i gro bzhin zla ba'i dkar tshes dga' ba dang po'i nyin gtsang g.yas ru bzhad kyi bye brag dngul chu'i ri khrod dga' ldan rtse'i spong khang du sbyar ba 'dis kyang rgyal ba'i bstan pa rin po che gangs can gyi ljongs su yun ring du gnas pa'i rgyu byed nus par gyur cig/ //

This text, “The Supremely Learned Situ’s Words, A Thorough Explanation of the Grammar Śhāstras of the Language of the Snowy Land, “The Thirty” and “Application of Gender Signs”” was written at the very insistent urgings of the bhikṣhu Jñānamitra who keeps his vows and who has great learning. It was written by the Śhākya monk named “Dharmabhadra” who, having touched the crown of his head to the dust of the feet of the learned and accomplished holy Ngawang Dorje Palzangpo and having tasted a few specks of the nectar coming from the mouth of Spelkhang Mahāpaṇḍita, had gained sufficient confidence not to shrink back in the presence of the experts who communicate the intended meanings of the standard treatises of Tibetan grammar. Having researched the root treatises on Tibetan grammar the Thirty and Gender Signs and many of their commentaries, such as The Speech Door and Mouth Ornament of the Experts, and others, all of their good parts were combined into this one composition which was completed in my thirty-fifth year, in the Fire Tiger year “Kṣhaya”, the month “śhravaṅā”, and on the First Joy day of the white phase of the moon. It was written in Tsang’s Yayru, in the area called Zhey, in the mountain place called Ngulchu, in the hermitage at the top of Tushita. By this, may it be possible for the precious teaching of the Conqueror to remain for a long time in the Snowy Land.

d.crumb: dka' gnad gsal ba'i me long

f.d: @#/ / rtags kyi 'jug pa'i snying po'i don mdo tsam brjod pa dka' gnad gsal ba'i me long zhes bya ba bzhugs so/ /

d.crumb: a mirror which reveals the difficult points

f.d: “A MIRROR WHICH REVEALS THE DIFFICULT POINTS”: A SHORT STATEMENT OF THE ESSENTIAL MEANING OF THE APPLICATION OF GENDER SIGNS
by Yangchen Drubpay Dorje, translated by Tony Duff
@#/ / na mo many+dzu shrI ye/
Namo Mañjuśhrīye

rgyal kun mkhyen pa'i ye shes dpyid/ / gzhon nu'i gzugs kyis rnam rol ba/ / rje btsun brtan pa'i 'khor lo dang / / dbyer med bla ma'i zhabs btud nas/ / mkhas mchog thon mi'i thugs mtsho las/ / byung ba'i brda sprod phyi mo mchog/ rtags kyi 'jug pa'i snying po'i don/ / mdor bsdus tshig gis gsal bar bya/ /

I bow at the feet of the guru who is inseparable from The delight of the wisdom knowledge of all conquerors Sporting in the youthful form of Jetsun Tenpa’i Khorlo.
The essential meaning of The Application of Gender Signs, The supreme grandmother of grammars that came from The ocean of the mind of the supreme expert Thonmi, Will be made clear here in summary form words.
spyir ni dbyangs mo gsal byed pho/ / de phyir kA li sum cu po/ / pho yi yi ge 'ba' zhig la/ / nang gses sde tshan lngar dbye ste/ /
Overall vowels are female and consonants male. Therefore, the thirty kāli as a whole Are male letters only and they Are sub-divided into five sets.

ka ca ta pa tsa rnams pho/ / kha cha tha pha tsha ma ning / / ga ja da ba dza wa zha/ / za 'a ya sha sa rnams mo/ / nga nya na ma shin tu mo/ / ra la ha a mo gsham ste/ / a ni mtshan med ces kyang bya/ /

ka, ca, ta, pa, tsa are male. kha, cha, tha, pha, tsha are neutral. ga, ja, da, ba, dza, wa, zha za, ’a, ya, sha, sa are female. nga, nya, na, ma are extremely female. ra, la, ha, aa, are barren and aa is also named “characterless”.
sngon 'jug lnga yi ba yig pho/ / ga da ma ning 'a mo yig/ ma ni shin tu mo yin no/ /
Of the five prefixes, letter ba is male, ga and da are neutral, and ’a and ma are female letters.

de rnams gang la gang 'jug na/ / pho yig ba ni ka ca ta/ / tsa ga nga ja nya da na/ / dza zha za ra sha sar 'jug/ ma ning ga ni ca ta tsa/ / nya da na zha za ya sha/ sar 'jug ma ning da yig ni/ / ka pa ga ba nga mar 'jug/

For those, which is affixed to which? Male letter ba is affixed to ka, cha, ta tsa, ga, nga, ja, nya, da, na, dza, zha, za, ra, sha, and sa. Neutral ga is affixed to ca, ta, tsa, nya, da, na, zha, za, ya, sha, And sa. Neutral letter da is affixed to ka, pa, ga, ba, nga, and ma.
mo yig 'a ni ga ja da/ / ba dza kha cha tha pha tshar/ / shin tu mo yi ma yig ni/ / kha cha tha tsha ga ja da/ / dza nga nya na rnams la 'jug/
Female letter ’a is affixed to ga, ja, da, ba, dza, kha, cha, tha, pha, and tsha And extremely female letter ma to kha, cha, tha, tsha, ga, ja, da, dza, nga, nya, and na.
ji ltar 'jug par byed ce na/ / pho ni sgra rtsol drag par 'jug/ ma ning ran par 'jug pa yin/ / mo ni zhan pa'i tshul gyis te/ / shin tu mo ni mnyam pas so/ /

ci phyir 'jug par byed ce na/ / thog mar 'di ltar shes dgos te/ / las gang zhig la byed pa po/ / gzhan dang dngos su 'brel ba yi/ / dbang du byas nas byed po dang / / de yi byed pa gnyis po ni/ / dngos po bdag yin bya yul dang / / bya ba gnyis po dngos po gzhan/ /

Why is the affixing done? To begin with, this has to be understood: From the standpoint of an agent In actual relationship to a karma as other, The two of agent and its instrument Are the self thing and the two of place of action And action are the other thing.
de bzhin byed pa po gzhan dang / / dngos su 'brel min ji ltar yang / / bya ba byas zin 'das pa dang / / bya ba byed 'gyur ma 'ongs dang / / byed bzhin pa ni da lta ba/ /

No matter how it is—whether there is agent as other like that Or there is no actual relationship—still, that The action has been done is past, The action will be done is future, and The action is being done is present.
de phyir dus gsum dbye bas ni/ / byed las dang 'brel ngag gi ni/ / sbyor ba kun la khyab pa yin/ /
Therefore, distinction of three tenses Pervades all spoken constructs Related to verb function.
bdag gzhan dbye bas de tsam du/ / khyab pa min yang byed po dang / / bya yul bsdu phyir dbye ba de/ / mdzad nas bdag gzhan dang 'brel ba'i/ / bya byed rnams kyang de khongs bsdus/ /

The distinction of self-other does not Pervade simply that but is a distinction made In order to include agent and place of action, One which also includes the action and agent Related as self and other within it.

des na dus gsum du dbye ba/ / bdag gzhan dbye bas ma khyab pa/ / bsdu ba'i don du shes dgos par/ / gsungs kyang sngon 'jug 'a yig skabs/ / byed las tsam dang 'brel ba yi/ / dngos po bdag la'ang 'jug pa mthong / /

Thus it has been stated that the distinction Into three tenses not being pervaded by The distinction into self-other is to be Understood as the meaning of inclusion. Still, in the case of the prefix ’a letter, Affixation also to the self thing Connected with mere verb function is seen.
de ltar nges nas pho yig ba/ / bsgrubs so lta bu 'das pa dang / / bsgrub bya'i lha dang bsgrub par bya/ / zhes sogs dngos po gzhan la 'jug/
That ascertained, male letter ba is affixed For the past as in བསྒྲུབས་སོ། and For other thing as in བསྒྲུབ་བྱའི་ལྷ་, བསྒྲུབ་པར་བྱ་, and so on.

ma ning ga da gnyis po ni/ / gcod pa po dang gcod par byed/ / gcod par 'gyur dang dkri ba po/ / dkri bar byed dang dkri bar 'gyur/ / zhes sogs dngos po bdag don dang / / gcad bya'i shing dang gcad par bya/ / dkri bya'i snal ma dkri bar bya/ / zhes sogs dngos po gzhan don dang / / gcod bzhin pa dang dkri bzhin pa/ / zhes sogs da lta bsgrub ched 'jug/

Neutral two ga and da are affixed In གཅོད་པ་པོ་ and གཅོད་པར་བྱེད་, And གཅོད་པར་འགྱུར་ and དཀྲི་བ་པོ་, And དཀྲི་བར་བྱེད་ and དཀྲི་བར་འགྱུར་, And so on to mean self thing and In གཅད་བྱའི་ཤིང་ and གཅད་པར་བྱ་, And དཀྲི་བྱའི་སྣ ་མ་དཀྲི་བར་བྱ་, And so on to mean other thing and In གཅོད་བཞིན་པ་ and དཀྲི་བཞིན་པ་ And so on, to produce the present.

mo yig 'a ni 'chad pa po/ / 'chad par byed dang 'chad par 'gyur/ / zhes sogs dngos po bdag dngos dang / / 'gro ba po dang 'gro bar byed/ / ces sogs bdag don phal pa dang / / 'khyil lo zhes sogs da lta dang / / 'khyil bar 'gyur sogs ma 'ongs 'jug/

Female letter ’a is affixed in འཆད་པ་པོ་, And འཆད་པར་བྱེད་ and འཆད་པར་འགྱུར་, And so on for thing of self thing and In འགྲོ་བ་པོ་ and འགྲོ་བར་བྱེད་ And so on for the meaning of self as complement and In འཁྱིལ་ལོ་ and so on for the present And in འཁྱིལ་བར་འགྱུར་ and so on for the future.
shin tu mo yi ma yig ni/ / bdag gzhan dus gsum mnyam par 'jug/ 'on kyang byed po gzhan dngos dang / / 'brel ba'i 'das la 'a'i sngon 'jug/ med par nges shing ga da nyung / /

The extremely female letter ma Is affixed equally for self, other, and the three tenses. Nonetheless, for the past of an agent in actual Relationship with other, the ’a prefix Certainly not and ga and da a little.
da lta ba la ba'i sngon 'jug/ nyung zhing mgo can da lta bar/ / bas 'phul med par nges pa tsam/ /
For the present, the prefix ba A little and for headed present Not having ba fronted is simply certain.

gzhan yang bas 'phul can phal cher/ / byed pa po ni da lta dang / / bya yul ma 'ongs par bsdus nas/ / 'das la bas 'phul yang 'jug yod/ / da lta ba la gnyis ka med/ / ma 'ongs 'phul yod yang 'jug med/ / skul tshig 'phul med yang 'jug yod/ /

Furthermore, for ba fronted forms usually The agent is included in the present and The place of action in the future, thus The past has ba fronting and a re-suffix, The present has neither of the two, The future has a fronting and no re-suffix, and The imperative has no fronting and has a re-suffix.
skabs 'gar 'das dang skul tshig la/ / sa rkyang sbyar bas 'thus pa'ang yod/ /
Sometimes past and imperative having A bare sa connected to them is also acceptable.
rjes 'jug yi ge bcu po yi/ / ga da ba sa bzhi rnams pho/ / nga ma 'a gsum mo yin cing / / na ra la gsum ma ning ste/ / ming gzhi'i yi ge kun la 'jug/
Of the ten suffix letters, The four ga da ba sa are male, The three nga ma and ’a are female, And the three na ra and la are neutral; They affix to all name-base letters.
ji ltar 'jug tshul gnyis yin te/ / dang po sgra yi 'jug tshul ni/ /
How they affix has two parts: First, the way of affixation in relation to sound.
pho yi ga yig yang 'jug can/ / skyes bu rab dang pho yig ba/ / yang 'jug can ni skyes bu 'bring / / ga ba yang 'jug med pa dang / / da sa'i mtha' can tha ma ste/ /
The male ga letter having a re-suffix Is strongest being; male letter ba Having a re-suffix is middling being; And endings ga and ba without re-suffix Or with an ending of da or sa are weakest.
drag pa pho la'ang nang gses kyis/ / drag zhan bar ma gsum du dbye/ /
The strong males also are divided into Three sub-divisions of stronger, weaker, intermediate.
de bzhin zhan pa mo la yang / / nang gses drag zhan gnyis dbye ste/ / nga ma yang 'jug can mo dang / / nga ma yang 'jug med pa dang / / 'a mtha' can rnams shin tu mo/ /
