zhes pa/ gtso che ba rnams ming mtha' dang mthun par 'dren tshul de ltar yin zhing / de byings brjod pa bde ba'i ched dang / 'jig rten pa'i nyer spyod dang bstun dgos pa sogs kyis 'dren tshul yang shin tu mang bar 'byung ste de rnams kyang bye brag ma 'dzings par rtogs par bya dgos te/ dper na/ phos mo drangs pa/ thog ma/ lta bu dang / mos pho drangs pa/ khang pa/ lta bu dang / ma ning gis mo drangs pa/ thal mo/ lta bu dang / ma ning gis pho drangs pa/ char pa/ lta bu mang du byung ba shes dgos par ma zad/ gzhan yang brda rnying la rtags mtshungs 'dren pa shin tu mang yang skad gsar bcad kyi zhu dag mang bas nub tshul gsungs pa ltar dper na/ brda rnying rtags mtshungs drangs pa ni/ brag ca/ dkon cog/ rin cen/ lta bu la brda gsar ni/ brag cha/ dkon mchog/ rin chen/ zhes pa 'di rnams kyang rtogs dgos pa'i gnad do/ / brjod bde 'dren tshul rnams rtags ma mthun kyang brjod bde gtso bor byas nas sgra mthun drangs pa yin pas sum rtags gnyis ka'i dngos bstan gyi dgongs par gnas so/ /

The primary one is that way of drawing it concordant with the name ending and then there are the ways of drawing it for ease of expression of the dhatu, of having to conform with the ways of the world, and so on which also appear very frequently. The latter ones also must be comprehended without getting the particulars tangled. For example, there is male drawing female as in ཐོག་མ།, female drawing male as in ཁང་པ་, neutral drawing female as in ཐལ་མོ།, neutral drawing male as in ཆར་པ།, and many others that occur. Not only must they be understood, but there is old orthography as well where they are very many cases of bringing equivalent gender but which most editors of the new language revisions state to be an outdated system. For example, the cases in old orthography of drawing matching gender such as བྲག་ཅ། and དཀོན་ཅོག་རིན་ཅེན། are written in new orthography as བྲག་ཆ། and དཀོན་མཆོག་རིན་ཆེན། and it is a key point that these also have to be understood.
The way of drawing ease of expression does not result in concordance of gender rather, since it is done chiefly for ease of expression, it draws concordance of term. Thus, both The Thirty and Gender Signs have this in them as the directly stated intent.
gzhan yang ming mtha' de nyid kyis/ / rtags mtshungs pa'am sgra mthun pa'i/ / rnam dbye brgyad dang slar bsdu sogs/ / snga ma'i shugs dang mthun par 'dren/

“Furthermore these items at the end of a name— The eight cases, the concluders, and so on With their equivalence of gender or their harmony of sound— Are drawn according to the force of the prior one.”

zhes pa/ gong gi ming mtha' 'dren tshul sogs bshad zin pa de las/ gzhan yang rnam dbye dang de min tshig phrad 'dren tshul ni/ bshad ma thag pa'i ming mtha' de nyid kyi snga ma'i rjes 'jug gi shugs kyis rnam dbye sogs rtags phan tshun mtshungs pa'am brjod bde'i sgra mthun pa'i rnam dbye dang po chos rnams ngo bo tsam brjod pa/ gnyis pa las su bya ba/ gsum pa byed sgra/ bzhi pa dgos ched/ lnga pa 'byung khungs/ drug pa 'brel sgra/ bdun pa rten gnas/ brgyad pa bod pa'i sgra bcas brgyad dang / dngos su bstan pa slar bsdu/ sogs khongs nas thon pa lhag bcas/ 'byed sdud/ bsnan pa/ bdag sgra/ tshig rgyan/ tshe skabs sogs kyang ming snga ma'i shugs dang mthun pa phyi ma 'dren dgos so zhes pa'o/ /

This is saying, “Following on from the above explanation of the ways of drawing the name-ending, and so on, which is now finished, there is the way of drawing the cases and phrase linkers as follows. The just-explained name endings draw, by the force of the prior part’s suffix, the cases and so on in a process either of mutually equivalent gender or ease-of-expression’s concordance of term. These name endings drawn like this are in fact the eight cases—case one, just expressing the entity of dharmas; two, the objective; three, agentive term; four, purposiveness; five, source; six, connective term; seven, basis; eight, calling term—and they are the concluders and the others explicitly brought out in the body of the text— continuative; separation and inclusion; emphasis; owner term; phrase ornament; timing; and so on. And all of them have to conform to the process that the subsequent one is brought in concordance with the force of the prior name.”
de dag nang gses gang 'jug ni/ / rnam dbye'am phrad bcas ming tshig de'i/ / mthar sbyar ming don las shes bya/ /
“The particular division of what has been placed— Either a “case” or “linker”—can be known from the name equivalents resulting from the connection at The end of that name or and phrase.”

zhes pa/ bshad ma thag pa de dag nang gses gang la gang 'jug pa ni/ rnam dbye'am de min tshig phrad bcas ming tshig rnams de'i mthar sbyar rgyu'i ming don 'og ma las legs par shes par bya'o zhes pa'o/ /

This is saying, “These just-explained sub-divisions of what is affixed and where are to be properly known from the name equivalents coming beyond, that is, the ones that will be connected to the ends of the phrases, that is, the names together with the cases or other non-case phrase linkers.”
de yang chos rnams ngo bo tsam/ / brjod pa rnam dbye dang po ste/ / dper na bum pa ka ba bzhin/ / gsal byed bod kyi skad la nyung / /
“Further, case one, expresses Just the entity of the dharmas; Its signifiers, for example like “pot” and “pillar”, Are few in the Tibetan language.”

zhes pa/ bshad ma thag pa de yang chos rnams kyi ngo bo tsam brjod pa rnam dbye dang po yin la de'i gsal byed ni/ dper na/ bum pa/ ka ba/ lha lta bu/ ngo bo tsam brjod pa nyid dag rnams sogs yin yang bod kha ba can pa rnams kyi skad la shin tu nyung ngo / /zhes pa'o/ /

This is saying, “Further to what was just explained, the expression of just the entity of dharmas is case one. Its signifying terms, for example like བུམ་པ། “pot”, ཀ་བ། “pillar”, and ལྷ། “god”, and so on, are themselves the expressors of just the entity but in the language of Tibet, the snow lands, there are very few of them.”

las dang bya yul don gcig ste/ / de lta'i bya ba'i yul zhig la/ / bya ba byas par ston pa la/ / gnyis pa las su bya ba dang / / gnyis pa'i nang tshan de nyid dang / / bzhi pa dgos ched gsum 'dra yang / / bya ba byas pas bya ba'i yul/ / de 'am de dang 'brel ba la/ / phan thogs med na gnyis pa ste/ / dper na shar du 'gro lta bu/ /

“Karma and place of action mean the same; Showing that some place of an action like that, Has had an action done to it, Is the second, the objective case and The second’s sub-division, identity. It is like the fourth, purposiveness’s three but for A place of action that has had an action done to it Where that or what is connected with it Is not benefited, that is the second, For example, like “going to the east”.”

zhes pa/ las dang bya ba'i yul don gcig ste de lta bu'i sgo nas bya ba'i yul zhig la bya ba byas par ston pa de la rnam dbye gnyis pa las su bya ba dang / gnyis pa'i nang tshan de nyid dang / bzhi pa dgos ched gsum 'dra bar snang mod/ de rnams kyi dbye ba gang gis 'byed na/ bya ba byas pas bya ba'i yul de 'am de dang 'brel ba la phan thogs med na rnam dbye gnyis pa las su bya ba yin te/ dper na/ shar du 'gro/ lta bu'o/ /

Karma and place of action mean the same; given such, the showing that a place of action has had an action done to it appears to be the second one, objective, and the internal division of the second, identity. Moreover, it does appear to be like the fourth, purposiveness’s three. Nevertheless, the thing that distinguishes them is that if there is no benefit to that place of action that has had an action done to it or to the thing connected with it, then it is the second case, objective, for example, “going to the east”.
phan thogs yod na bzhi pa ste/ / dper na slong la byin lta bu/ /
“If there is benefit, it is the fourth, For example, like “giving to a beggar”.”

zhes pa/ bya ba byas pas bya ba'i yul de'am de dang 'brel ba'i las la phan thogs yod na rnam dbye bzhi pa dgos ched yin te/ dper na/ dge slong la sbyin/ slong mkhan la ster/ zhing du chu 'dren/ lta bu'o/ /

If there is benefit for that place of action that has had an action done to it or to the karma connected with it, it is the fourth case, purposive, for example, དགེ་སློང་ལ་སྦྱིན། “giving to a monk”, སློང་མཁན་ལ་སྟེར། “giving to a beggar”, ཞིང་དུ་ཆུ་འདྲེན་, “bringing water to a field”.
phan thogs med kyang bya yul dang / / bya ba ngo bo gcig yin na/ / gnyis pa'i nang tshan de nyid de/ / dper na lha ru gsal lta bu/ /
“Even if there is no benefit, if the place of action And the action are of the same entity, It is the second’s sub-division, identity, For example, like “appeared as the deity”.”

zhes pa/ bya ba byas pas bya ba'i yul de la phan thogs med kyang bya ba'i yul dang bya ba gnyis po ngo bo gcig yin na rnam dbye gnyis pa'i nang tshan de nyid yin te/ dper na/ lha ru gsal/ 'od du 'tsher/ lta bu'o/ /

Even if there is no benefit to that place of action that has had an action done to it, if both the place of action and the action are of the same entity, then it is the second case’s internal division, identity, for example, ལྷ་རུ་གསལ། “(he himself) appeared as the deity”, འོད་དུ་འཚེར། “(a light) radiating light”.
gang zhig gang la brten pa 'am/ / gnas dang yod pa'i don tsam las/ / bya ba gtan nas mi byed na/ / rnam dbye bdun pa gnas gzhi ste/ / dper na steng du mi yod ltar/ /

“If there is just the meaning of something which is relying on Or is positioned on or existing on something else And otherwise does no specific action, It is the seventh case, basis, For example, like “there is a man on top”.”

zhes pa/ chos gang zhig gzhi gang la brten pa'am gnas pa'am yod pa'i don ston pa tsam las bya ba gtan nas mi byed pa yin na rnam dbye bdun pa gnas gzhi yin te/ dper na/ steng du mi yod/ dbus su jo bo bzhugs/ lta bu'o/ /

If it just shows the meaning of some thing that relies on or is positioned on or exists on something else and other than that does no specific action then it is the seventh case, basis, for example like སྟེང་དུ་མི་ཡོད། “there is a man on top”, དབུས་སུ་ཇོ་བོ་བཞུགས། “the lord was seated in the middle”.
tshe skabs gnyis dang don 'dra na/ / bdun pa'i nang tshan tshe skabs te/ / dper na mchu zla shar ba na/ / cho 'phrul dus chen tshugs lta bu/ /

“If like the meaning of the second’s timings- circumstance, It is the seventh’s sub-division of time-circumstance, For example, when the Magha moon appears, The commemoration of miracles is undertaken.”
zhes pa/ tshe dang skabs gnyis kyi don dang 'dra na rnam dbye bdun pa'i nang tshan tshe skabs yin te/ dper na/ hor zla dang po shar ba na cho 'phrul dus chen tshugs/ lta bu'o/ /

If has the sort of meaning of the two time and circumstance, then it is the seventh case’s internal division, time-circumstance, for example, ཧོར་ཟླ་དང་པོ་ཤར་བ་ན་ཆོ་འཕྲུལ་དུས་ཆེན་ཚུག ། “when the moon of the first lunar month appears, commemoration of miracles occurs”.
rnam dbye gnyis bzhi bdun pa dang / / de nyid tshe skabs gsal byed sgra/ / su ru ra du na la tu/ / yin zhing phal cher la sgra dang / / mthun pas la don rnam dbye'ang zer/ /

“The terms which elicit cases two, four, Seven, and timing-circumstance and identity Are su, ra, ru, du, na, la, tu, And given that they usually concur with the la term They are also called “the la-equivalent cases”.”

zhes pa/ rnam dbye gnyis pa/ bzhi pa/ bdun pa/ gnyis pa'i nang tshan de nyid/ bdun pa'i nang tshan tshe skabs bcas lnga po 'di rnams kyi don gsal bar byed pa'i sgra ni/ su dang / ru dang / ra dang / du dang / na dang / la dang / tu bcas bdun po 'di rnams yin zhing / phal cher la sgra dang 'jug tshul mthun pas na la don dang / tshig grogs kyi dbang gis rnam dbyer gyur tshe la don gyi rnam dbye'ang zer ro/ / 'jug tshul mthun lugs ni/ dbus su 'gro/ dbus la 'gro/ lta bu mthun pas so/ /

The terms which elicit these five—cases two, four, and seven and the second’s internal division, identity, and the seventh’s internal division, time-circumstance—are these seven: su, ru, ra, du, na, la, tu. And since they usually concur with the way of placing the la term, they are also called the “la-equivalents” and when they have become phrase assistives and hence turned into cases they are also called “la-equivalent cases”.
The system of their concurring with the way of affixation is because of their concurrence like in དབུས་སུ་འགྲོ། and དབུས་ལ་འགྲོ།.
'on kyang na la de nyid la/ / mi 'jug smra ba'i sgo las gsungs/ /
“Nevertheless, it says in the Speech Door That na and la are not placed for identity.”
zhes pa/ 'on kyang na la gnyis ni rnam dbye gnyis pa'i nang tshan de nyid la mi 'jug pa smra sgo mtshon cha las gsungs te/ smra sgo las/
Despite that, it says in the Speech Door that na and la both are not used for case two’s internal division, identity; it says,
du la sogs pa la dang mthun/ / de nyid dag ni lhag pa yin/ /
“Du and so on concur with la; The two for identity are special.”
gsungs so/ / 'dir yang phal cher zhes ma nges pa'i tshig smos pa dper na/ lha na gsal/ 'od la 'tsher/ lta bu sbyar mi rung ba'i don to/ /
Here it also has to be pointed out that “usually” is a word of uncertainty, for example, it means that constructions like ལྷ་ན་གསལ། and འོད་ལ་འཚེར། are not all right.
rnam dbye gang la sbyor yul des/ / nye 'gyang gang du bya ba zhig/ byas na gsum pa byed sgra ste/ / dper na bdag gis bshad lta bu/ /
“If the place to which the case is connected, Does an action somewhere far or near, It is the third one, the agentive case, For example, “I explained”.”

zhes pa/ rnam dbye gang la sbyor yul des nye ba dang 'gyang ba gang rigs su bya ba zhig byas na rnam dbye gsum pa byed sgra ste/ dper na/ bdag gis bshad/ mig gis lta/ lta bu nye ba dang / mig gis shel rtse'i rtse mo nas phyogs thams cad du yang dang yang du legs par bltas so/ /lta bu 'gyang ba'o/ /

If the place to which the case is connected does an action in somewhere whether nearby or far away, then it is the third case, the agentive term, for example བདག་གིས་བཤད། “I explained” and མིག་གིས་ལྟ་ “He (his eye) looked” are cases of nearby and མིག་གིས་ཤེལ་རྩེའི་རྩེ་མོ་ནས་ཕྱོགས་ཐམས་ཅད་དུ་ཡང་ཡང་དུ་ལེགས་པར་བལྟས་སོ། “He pointed the telescope in every direction again and again and so looked carefully” is a case of far away.
bya ba gtan nas mi byed par/ / snga phyi 'brel byed tsam ston na/ / rnam dbye drug pa 'brel sgra ste/ / dper na bdag gi mig lta bu/ /
“If it definitely does no action and Shows just the making of a connection between former and later, It is the sixth case, connective term, For example, like “my eye”.”

zhes pa/ las sam bya ba'i yul la bya ba gtan nas mi byed par tshig snga ma dang phyi ma 'brel byed tsam ston na rnam dbye drug pa 'brel sgra zhes bya ste/ dper na/ bdag gi mig/ khab kyi rtse/ lta bu'o/ /

Without the specific doing of an action to a karma, that is, a place of action, if it shows just the making of a connection between former and later words, then it is the sixth case, named “the connective term”, for example as in བདག་གི་མིག my eye, ཁབ་ཀྱི་རྩེ། the point of the needle.
rnam dbye drug gsum gsal byed sgra/ / sa mtha' yod dang med pa yi/ / gi kyi gyi 'i yi lnga yin/ /
“The terms which elicit the third and sixth cases Are the five gi, kyi, gyi, ’i, and yi With and without a sa ending respectively.”

zhes pa/ rnam dbye drug pa dang gsum pa gnyis gsal bar byed pa'i sgra ni/ tshig gi mtha' na sa yod pa/ gis/ kyis/ gyis/ 'is/ yis dang / tshig gi mtha' na sa med pa/ gikyi/ gyi/ 'i/ yi lnga po 'di rnams yin no zhes pa'o/ /

This is saying, “The terms which elicit both the sixth and third cases are those with a sa at the end of the word gis, kyis, gyis, ’is, and yis and those without a sa at the end of the word, the five gi, kyi, gyi, ’i, and yi”.

gang zhig gang las 'byung ba'am/ / bye dang lhung ba'i don ldan na/ / rnam dbye lnga pa 'byung khungs te/ / dper na zhal nas thos lta bu/ / gsal byed sgra ni nas las te/ / dgar dang sdud pa'ang lnga par gtogs/ /

“If it has the meaning of something that arises from or, Comes out or issues forth from somewhere, It is the fifth case, source; For example, “heard from the mouth”. The terms which elicit it are nas and las. Segregation and inclusion also are included in the fifth.”

zhes pa/ chos gang zhig gzhi gang las byung ba'am bye ba'am lhung ba'i don dang ldan na rnam dbye lnga pa 'byung khungs zhes bya ste/ dper na/ zhal nas legs bshad thos/ rgya mtsho nas nor bu 'byung / lta bu dang / de rnams gsal byed kyi sgra ni nas las gnyis yin cing / der ma zad dgar ba dang sdud pa gnyis kyang rnam dbye lnga pa'i khongs su gtogs te/ dper na/ lha yi nang nas brgya sbyin mchog/ lta bu dgar ba dang / spyi gtsug nas rkang mthil bar/ lta bu sdud pa'o/ /

If it has the meaning of something that arises from, comes out of, or issues from some thing which is a basis, it is the fifth case, named “source”, for example ཞལ་ནས་ལེགས་བཤད་ཐོས། heard a good explanation from the mouth (in person), རྒྱ་མཚོ་ནས་ནོར་བུ་འབྱུང་ jewels come from the ocean. Their terms which elicit it are the two, nas and las. And not only that but both segregation and inclusion also are included in the fifth case, for example, segregation as in ལྷ་ཡི་ནང་ནས་བརྒྱ་སྦྱིན་མཆོག་ “from amongst the gods, Kaushika is supreme” and as in སྤྱི་གཙུག་ནས་རྐང་མཐིལ་བར་ “from the top of the crown the soles of the feet”.
gzhan yang tshig don gong 'og tu/ / bsdu rgyu yod na sdud pa'i sgra/ / dang dang kyang yang 'ang sogs sbyor/ /
“Furthermore, if the meanings of phrase equivalents Before and after are to be included, Dang, and kyang, yang, and ’ang, and so on are connected.”

zhes pa/ gzhan yang tshig gi don gong dang 'og gang rigs su bsdu rgyu yod na sdud pa'i sgra/ dang dang / kyang dang / yang dang / 'ang sogs sbyor dgos te/ dper na/ lha dang mi dang lha ma yin dang dri zar bcas pa'i 'jig rten yi rangs te lta bu sdud pa dang / bsad kyang lang / mgo yang gug/ skra'ang dkar/ lta bu'o/ /

Furthermore, if there is to be inclusion of the meanings of whatever words before and after, the terms of inclusion dang and kyang and yang and ’ang and so on must be connected, for example, ལྷ་དང་མི་དང་ལྷ་མ་ཡིན་དང་དྲི་ཟར་བཅས་པའི་འཇིག་རྟེན་ཡི་རངས་ཏེ་ “the world’s gods and men and demi-gods and gandharvas together rejoiced”, བསད་ཀྱང་ལངས། “woke and rose”, མགོ་ཡང་གུག་སྐྲ་འང་དཀར། “head and curly hair too, were white”.
rnam grangs du mas don bskyar na/ / 'byed sdud sgra 'jug/
“If several enumerations repeat the meaning, The separation-inclusion terms are affixed.”

ces pa/ rnam grangs du mas don bskyar dgos na snga ma snga mar 'byed sdud kyi sgra 'jug ste/ dper na/ don bskyar ba/ 'chi med dam/ rnam sad dam/ mig mi 'dzum ni lha'o/ / lta bu dang / tshig bskyar ba/ pad+ma dkar po'am pad+ma dkar po lta bu'i sems dpa'/ lta bu dang / tshig don gnyis ka bskyar ba/ bskor zhing bskor zhing slar yang de ru 'bab/ / lta bu'o/ /

If many similar terms supporting the meaning is needed, then the terms of separation or inclusion are affixed prior to each. For example: where the meaning is supported འཆི་མེད་དམ། རྣམ་སད་དམ། མིག་མི་འཛུམ་ “deathless, or always awake, or eyes not closing”; and where the words are supported པདྨ་དཀར་པོའམ། པདྨ་དཀར་པོ་ལྟ་བུའི་སེམས་དཔའ། “white lotus or brave-minded like a white lotus”; and where both word and meaning are supported བསྐོར་ཞིང་བསྐོར་ཞིང་སླར་ཡང་དེ་རུ་འབབ། “turning and turning and once again falling down there”.
dgag pa dang / / bdag don yod na thog mtha' ru/ / pa sde'i rtags rnams ci rigs 'jug/
“If there are the meanings of negation or Of owner, then one of the gender signs of the pa section From beginning to end as appropriate is affixed.”

ces pa/ pa sde'i khongs nas byung ba'i ma yig thog mtha' bar gsum gang du zhugs kyang dgag pa'am dgag sgra yin te/ ma yin/ mi 'dug/ bdag min/ 'dre med/ mi skya ma yin/ ga ma sa/ lta bu dang / pa sde'i khongs nas byung ba'i pa dang / ba dang / ma ste pho mo ma ning rtags rnams ci rigs ston pa'i bdag sgra ming gzhi'i mtha' ru zhugs na bdag po'i don gsal bar byed pa yin te/ dper na/ rta pa/ nang ma/ lha rtse ba/ lta bu'o/ /

The ma letter that comes from within the pa section, whether it is affixed before, after, or in between—any of these three—is negation or the term of negation as in མ་ཡིན། མི་འདུག བདག་མིན། འདྲེ་མེད། མི་སྐྱ་མ་ཡིན། ག་མ་ས། and the pa and ba and ma that come from within the pa section that is, the male, female, and neutral genders, whichever is appropriately shown for the term of the owner, are, if affixed at the end of the name-base, the distinguishers of the meaning of the owner, for example རྟ་པ། ནང་པ། ལྷ་རྩེ་བ་.
rgyan du gyur pa'i tshig phrad kyang / / don la bsnyegs sa yod na sbyor/ /
“Phrase linkers that become ornaments also Are connected if there is a follow-up to their meaning.”
zhes pa/ rgyan du gyur pa'i tshig gi 'phrad rnams kyang don la bsnyegs sa ste sbyor sa yod na sbyor dgos te/ dper na/ mdzes kyang mdzes/ btud kyang khro lta bu dang / mi dgos par sbyor mi rigs so/ /

The phrase connectors that are also ornaments must be connected if they are in a position trailing a meaning, that is, if a meaning is connected following them, for example མཛེས་ཀྱང་མཛེས། “more beautiful than beautiful”, བཏུད་ཀྱང་ཁྲོ་ “bowing but angry”. And, it is not acceptable to connect them when there is not that need .
de bzhin bstan bya lhag yod na/ / lhag bcas sgra sbyor/
“Likewise, if there is some extra to be shown, A continuative term is connected.”
zhes pa/ bshad ma thag pa'i tshig rgyan gyi sbyor tshul de bzhin du bstan bya lhag ma yod na lhag bcas kyi sgra sbyor dgos te/ dper na/ don rtogs te nyams su blangs/ lta bu'o/ /

Like with the way of connecting phrase ornaments just explained, if there is some extra to be shown, the continuative term must be connected, for example, དོན་རྟོགས་ཏེ་ཉམས་སུ་བླངས། “realized the meaning, that is, gained the experience (in meditation)”.
tshig don ni/ / rdzogs na slar bsdu'i sgra rnams sbyor/ /
“When a phrase equivalent is complete, The concluder terms are connected.”
zhes pa/ gang brjod rgyu'i tshig don ni rdzogs na slar bsdu'i sgra rnams sbyor dgos te/ dper na/ mchog go/ bzang ngo / / lta bu'o/ /
When a phrase equivalent, what is to be expressed, is complete, one of the concluder terms must be connected. For example, མཆོག་གོ, བཟང་ངོ་།.
rjes 'jug gi dgos pa bstan pa ni/
6. Teaching the need for the suffixes
dgos pa ci phyir 'jug ce na/ / mo yig dbyangs dang mi ldan na/ / pho yig gsal byed brjod mi nus/ /
“Why do they need to be affixed? If it is not associated with a female letter, a vowel, Then a male letter, a consonant, cannot be expressed.”
zhes pa/ rjes 'jug gi yi ge rnams dgos pa ci phyir 'jug par byed ce na/ mo'i yi ge dbyangs yig rnams dang mi ldan na/ pho yig gsal byed rnams brjod mi nus pa yin no zhes pa'o/ /

This is saying, “If you ask, “Why do the suffix letters need to be affixed?”, then it is because if the male letters, the consonants, do not have a female letter, a vowel, then the male letters cannot be expressed.”

de phyir dbyangs lngar bzhed pa bde/ / pho yig dbyangs ldan de dag la'ang / / rjes 'jug bcu po ma zhugs na/ / don gyi ngo bo tsam ston pa'i/ / ming dang don gyi khyad par rnams/ / ston pa'i tshig dang don ldan pa'i/ / ngag gi brjod pa yod min te/ / yi ge'i khongs nas ming dbyung zhing / / ming gi khongs nas tshig phyung nas/ / tshig gis don rnams ston pas so/ /

“Therefore, it is convenient to assert five vowels. Moreover, for such male letters having a vowel, If it does not have one of the ten suffixes affixed, then The meaning carried by the names which show just the entity, and The distinctions of the names’ meaning shown by the phrases, and The verbal expressions that convey such meanings would not exist.”

zhes pa/ rgyu mtshan de'i phyir dbyangs yig dngos bstan bzhi dang shugs bstan a bcas lngar bzhed pa bde bar ma zad pho'i yi ge ka sogs la dbyangs sam gi gu sogs dang ldan pa de dag la'ang rjes 'jug gi yi ge bcu po gang rung zhig ma zhugs na don gyi ngo bo ston pa'i ming dang / don gyi khyad par ston pa'i tshig dang / brjod bya'i don dang ldan pa'i ngag gi brjod pa gang yang yod min te/ yi ge'i khongs sam nang nas ming dbyung ba ste byung zhing / ming gi khongs nas tshig rnams phyung nas tshig gis don rnams ma 'dres par so sor ston par nus pas so zhes pa'o/ /

This is saying, “For that reason, it is convenient to accept the four vowels actually taught together with the implied ཨ་ a to make five. Not only that, but for those male letters ཀ་ and so on, having a vowel that is, the gigu and so on, also, if they do not have any one of the ten suffix letters, whatever it is, in place, then the meanings which are the names that show the entity, the distinctions of the meanings which are the phrases that show them, and expressions of speech that have meaning to be expressed, would not exist at all. It is so, because the names are drawn out from, that is, come from, the letters; the phrases are drawn out from the names, and it is by way of the phrases that the meanings can be individually shown without mix-up.”
ming tshig brjod pa med na ni/ / mthun mong mthun mong ma yin pa'i/ / shes bya ston pa'ang med par 'gyur/ /
“If there were no names, phrases, or expressions, The teaching of ordinary and extraordinary Knowables also would become non-existent.”

zhes pa/ ming dang tshig gi brjod pa med na ni phyi rol pa dang mthun mong pa'i snyan dngags la sogs pa'i rig byed rnams dang / mthun mong ma yin pa thub pa sangs rgyas bcom ldan 'das kyis gsungs pa'i mdo sngags kyi bka' bstan bcos rnams kyi gzhung don la shes par bya ba'i yul ston pa'ang med par 'gyur ro/ /zhes pa'o/ /

This is saying, “If there were no names, phrases, or expressions, the showing of the knowables which are the meanings in the treatises both of the ordinary outsider’s Vedas with their poetry and so on, and of the extraordinary sýtras and tantras of the sage, the bhagavat buddha, in the Kangyur and Tangyur, also would become non- existent”.
de phyir 'phags yul mkhas rnams kyi/ / rjes su 'brangs nas gsungs pa 'di/ / skye bo kun gyis rtogs gyur cig/
“Therefore may this, spoken following The Noble Land’s experts, Be realized by all beings.”

ces pa/ dgos pa de'i phyir na rgya gar 'phags yul du byon pa'i mkhas pa chen po bram ze li bi ka ra la sogs pa rnams kyi rjes su 'brangs nas thon mi nyid kyi brtse bas kun nas bslangs te gsungs pa'i bstan bcos sum cu pa dang rtags kyi 'jug pa 'di gnyis kyi dgongs don rnams phyin ci ma log par gangs can gyi skye bo kun gyis bde blag tu rtogs par gyur cig ces thugs smon mdzad pa'o/ /

This is the aspiration made, “Therefore, since there is that need, may the intended meaning of the two treatises, The Thirty and The Application of Gender Signs, that I, Thumi, motivated by love, set forth following the great experts of the Indian Noble Land, Brahman Livikara and others, be, without mistake, easily realized by all beings of the Snowy Land”.
tshig gi sgra tsam 'dra na yang / / don la khyad par shin tu che/ / de phyir brda dag la brten nas/ / ma nor don rnams 'tshol ba gces/ /
“It seems like this is just terms of words But the distinctions of meaning are very great. Therefore, rely on the pure signs then Hold dear seeking out the un-mistaken meaning.”

zhes pa/ ming phan tshun tshig gi sgra tsam 'dra bar snang yang don la khyad par shin tu che ba yod de/ dper na/ gri lta bur mtshon na/ ga gri/ da dri/ ba bri/ sogs phan tshun ming gzhi'i sgra tsam 'dra na yang so sor 'byed na mtshon gyi ral gri la ga gri/ sna la bsnam bya'i dri la da dri/ ri mo bri la ba bri sogs khyad par shin tu che ste/ de yang sngon rgyal po wang dang / gung gnyis mi mthun pa'i gzhi yi ge 'bri ba pos da dri ga gri nor 'khrul byung rkyen gyis 'thab rtsod byung ba'i lo rgyus kyang gsungs so/ /

This is saying, “Although this looks like this text is just a collection of a few terms about words, the distinctions of meaning contained in it are very great. For example, if we use gri to demonstrate this: ག་གྲི། ད་དྲི། བ་བྲི། ga gri, da dri, ba bri and so on, seems like just a few terms of name-bases collected together but, if each is analysed, as follows, the differences in meaning are very great: མཚོན་གྱི་རལ་གྲི་ལ་ག་གྲི། “the weapon sword is ga gri”; སྣ་ལ་བསྣམ་བྱའི་དྲི་ལ་ད་དྲི། “the filth on the handkerchief for the nose is da dri”; and རི་མོ་བྲི་ལ་བ་བྲི་ “in drawing a painting, drawing is ba bri”. Further, there is the history told of the previous kings Wang and Gung who fought with each other because of a misunderstanding that arose when a scribe mistook ད་དྲི་ da dri for ག་གྲི་ ga gri.

rgyu mtshan de'i phyir bshes gnyen dam pa'i zhabs pad bsten nas brda dag par byed pa'i brda sprod kyi gzhung rnams la brten nas sbyangs stobs phul phyin gyis ming tshig rnams kyi dbye ba ma nor bar byas nas don rnams 'tshol ba snying gi dbus su gces par gzung dgos so/ /zhes pa'o/ /

Therefore, for that reason, first serve at the holy friend’s lotus feet and involve yourself with the grammar texts that purely show the signs of the language then, with the strength of learning produced, you will un-mistakenly differentiate names and phrases; having done that, you must hold dear, that is, cherish deep in your heart, seeking out the meaning”.
don la mi rmongs rmongs pa yang / / lugs 'dir mkhas min gyis byed de/ / sgra shes don la mi rmongs zhes/ / mkhas pa'i gsung la yongs su grags/ /
“Whether ignorant to the meaning or not, In this system, the production of expertise and not, Is known everywhere in the words of the experts as, “In knowing the terms, no ignorance.””

zhes pa/ de ltar brda dag gi gzhung la thos bsam gyi sgo nas zhugs na rgyal ba'i gsung rab dang dgongs 'grel rgya bod mkhas grub kyi gzhung don rnams kyi dgongs pa 'byed pa la mi rmongs pa'i blo gros mchog tu rgyas nas mkhas pa chen por 'gyur zhing / brda dag gzhung la thos bsam gyis ma zhugs na bka' dang dgongs 'grel ma zad tha na srid kyi bya bzhag gi don la'ang mi shes pa'i rmongs par 'gyur ba ste/ de ltar rmongs mi rmongs kyang rtsa ba brda sprod kyi gzhung sum rtags gnyis po 'dir mkhas mi mkhas kyis byed de bod du sgra sum rtags yin zhing / sgra shes na don la mi rmongs zhes rgya bod kyi mkhas grub rnams kyi gsung la yang yongs su grags pa yin no zhes pa'o/ /

This is saying, “If you are in the position of having heard and contemplated the texts of pure signs of the language like that, you will be able to analyse the intent contained in the Conqueror’s excellent discourses and the meanings of the texts containing the commentaries to his intent by the Indian and Tibetan experts and accomplished ones, and having done so, will have a fully-developed intellect free of ignorance and will become a great expert because of it. If, you are not in the position of having heard and contemplated the texts of pure signs of the language, you will have the ignorance of not knowing the meaning of buddha word and commentaries on their intent and not only that but will finish up having the ignorance of not knowing the meaning even of worldly activities.
“Moreover, such ignorance and non-ignorance is produced by being expert or not in the two root texts of grammar here, The Thirty and Application of Gender Signs which in Tibet are called “སྒྲ་སུམ་རྟགས་ Terms, The Thirty and Gender Signs” and it is also known everywhere within the writings of Indian and Tibetan learned and accomplished ones that, “If you know the terms, you are not ignorant of the meaning”.
'di la ma sbyangs rmongs tshod kyis/ / 'chad rtsod rtsom pa'i grwar 'jug pa/ / wa skyes seng lpags gyon pa bzhin/ / nam zhig rjes ngan gsal bar 'gyur/ /
“Anyone who has not learned and is ignorant of it, who Enters an institution of exposition, debate, and composition, Will, like a fox in lion’s clothing Sooner or later be revealed.”

zhes pa/ brda dag gi gzhung lugs kun gyi ma phyir gyur pa sum rtags 'di la ma sbyangs pa'am ma bslab par rmongs tshod spyi brtol gyis rgyal ba'i gsung rab kyi dgongs don gzhan la 'chad pa dang / pha rol po dang rtsod pa byed pa dang / rang gis rtsom pa sogs mkhas pa'i bgyi ba gsum gyi grwar ram gras su 'jug par byed pa de ni/ dper na wa skyes seng ge'i pags pa gyon pa de gnas skabs seng ge lta bur mngon na'ang dus nam zhig gi tshe wa'i gzugs brnyan gsal bar mthong ba'i rjes ngan ston pa de bzhin du skabs der 'chad rtsod sogs grwar zhugs kyang nam zhig ma sbyangs pa'i rjes ngan rnams gsal bar ston par 'gyur ro zhes pa'o/ /

Because it is the grandmother of all textual systems of pure signs of language, the ignorant ones who have not learned, that is, not trained in these Thirty and Gender Signs enter into the institutions, the ranks where the three activities of the learned are conducted, and just spout the meanings of the intent of the excellent discourses of the conqueror, debate with others, write their own texts, and so on. They are like a fox in lion’s clothing; for the time being they look like lions but one day that will change and their lack of learning will be nakedly revealed.
de phyir blo gsal don gnyer rnams/ / rtags 'jug dka' gnad gzugs brnyan kun/ / gsal bar 'char ba'i me long 'dir/ / la 'ur gzigs mor spyon dang kye/ /
“Therefore, those who seek a clear intellect: Hey! Come quick and look at the image In this mirror that clearly displays all reflections Of the difficult points of the Application of Gender Signs.”

zhes pa/ rgyu mtshan de'i phyir blo gsal thos bsam gyi don gnyer dang ldan pa rnams rtags 'jug gi dka' gnad dam don rtogs dka' zhing gnad che ba rnams kyi gzugs brnyan kun ma 'dres par gsal bar 'char ba'i me long 'di nyid kyi ngos la la 'ur te mgyogs par gzigs mo 'am ltad mo lta bar spyon dang kye zhes bos pa ni da lta 'dir byon cig blo gsal rnams/ zhes pa'o/ /

This is saying, “Therefore, for that reason, those of clear intellect, who seek for the meanings of hearing and contemplation, “Hey! I cry out to you, come here now, quickly, you of clear intellect!” and look at this image on the surface of this mirror in which clearly appears, un-muddled, all the reflections of the difficult points, that is, the meanings difficult to comprehend that are the greater points, of the Application of Gender Signs.
'di la nongs pa'i tshogs mchis na/ / gzur gnas mkhas pa'i spyan sngar 'chags/ /
“If errors have accumulated in here, They are confessed right here in view of the experts.”

zhes pa/ rtags 'jug dka' gnad gsal ba'i me long 'di la nor 'khrul gyi nongs pa ste nyes pa'i tshogs mchis na/ gzur gnas sam drang por gnas pa'i mkhas pa kun gyi spyan sngar mthol lo 'chags sam bshags so/ / zhes pa'o/ /

This is saying, “If mistakes have accumulated in this Mirror that Reveals the Difficult Points of the “Application of Gender Signs”, they are admitted and confessed before all experts who are right here, that is, straight in front of me”.
cung zad 'bad las thob pa'i dges/ / kun gyis 'di don rtogs par shog/
“By the virtue obtained from this small effort, May all comprehend the meaning of this.”

ces pa/ dbyangs can grub pa'i rdo rje bdag gis rtags 'jug gzhung 'di nyid bskrun pa'i ngal ba cung zad 'bad las thob pa'i dge ba des gangs can 'gro ba kun gyis 'di'i don legs par rtogs nas 'chad rtsod rtsom gsum la sogs pa'i sgo nas rang gzhan gyi don rnams mthar phyin par byed nus par shog cig/ ces bsngo smon mdzad do/ /

This is the dedication and aspiration. It is saying:
“Through the virtue obtained from the small effort involved in producing this text of the Application of Gender Signs by myself, Yangchen Drubpay Dorje, may all of the migrators in the Snowy Land nicely comprehend the meaning of it and then, via the three, exposition, debate, and, composition, may they have the means to complete the aims of themselves and others.”

'dir smras pa/ thu mi'i thugs bskyed chu gter bsrubs pa las/ / 'ongs pa'i sum rtags dgos 'dod nor gyi dbyig/ phan bde'i 'od 'bar snang ba'i dpal yon can/ / 'di ko sngon byon mkhas rnams mig bzhin gces/ /

I would like to say this here:
The Thirty and Gender Signs, the jewel wealth of our fulfilled desires and hopes, That came from churning the ocean mine of Thumi’s motivation, Is a glorious thing seen blazing with the light of benefit and ease That all of the previous experts have held as dear as their eyes.
de phyir gzhung 'grel nam mkha'i skar tshogs bzhin/ / rang rang khyer so'i 'phro 'du mkhas pa'i dbus/ / skal bzang kun+da'i 'dzum pa lhug po ru/ / 'grol nus dngul chu'i legs bshad zla snang mchog/

Thus there are constellations of commentaries to the treatises Emanated by the experts but at their centre is Ngulchu, Whose supreme, brilliant moon of fine explanations, Is able to open up the drooping and closed Kunda of good fortune.
e ma brda dag gzhung lugs rgya mtsho'i mtha'/ / byis blo'i mig gi spyod yul ga la zhig/ de slad 'di la nongs pa'i tshogs mchis na/ / gzur gnas mkhas la 'chags so byi dor mdzod/ /

E ma, how could the far limits of the ocean of the system of texts of the pure signs Of language be within the domain of the eye of intellect of the immature? Due to that, if errors have accumulated in here, They are confessed to the experts right before me; please wipe them off!
cung zad 'bad las thob pa'i dge ba'i cha/ / kha ba dung dang pad rtsa 'o mtsho ltar/ / dkar ba gang des lung rtogs dam pa'i chos/ / rang gzhan rgyud la mchog tu rgyas gyur cig/

By the whiteness, like snow, a conch, and the root of lotus, a milk lake, Of the little bit of virtue obtained from this small effort, May the holy dharma of scripture and realization Increase fully in the minds of self and others.

ces pa 'di yang rang slob rtse drung rgyal mtshan chos ldan lags kyis rtags 'jug dka' gnad gsal ba'i me long gi 'grel pa phal tshig go bde ba zhig dgos zhes nan gyis bskul bar/ rang ngos nas 'di ltar smra ba'i spobs pa rdul phran tsam ma mchis kyang skul ba po'i gsung ngo ma ldog par spyi brtol bskyed nas b+hik+Shu dka' chen pad+mas skyes bu'i don grub 'bras bu zla ba'i dkar phyogs rdzogs pa gsum pa'i nyin mjug grub par bgyis pa'o// //

My own disciple Tshedrung Gyaltsen Chodan pressed me, saying that an easy-to-understand commentary using ordinary terms to explain A Mirror that Reveals the Difficult Points of the “Application of Gender Signs” was needed. From my side, I had not even an atom of confidence that I could expound such a thing, but not wanting to turn away the request of the person who prompted me, I just spouted this out. It was completed by the Kachen Bhikṣhu Padma at the end of the day of the third Completion of the light phase of the Siddhartin.

III. Identifying the Tibetan Vowels and Consonants
['di] la dngos dang mtha' dpyad do/ /
dang po [dngos] ni/
A. Main part
(Thumi) says,
yi ge A li kA li gnyis/ / A li gsal byed i sogs bzhi/ / kA li sum cu tham pa'o/ /
zhes pas bstan te/

de'ang yi ge zhes bya ba legs sbyar gyi skad du/ ak+Sha ra ste mig lta bu 'dren byed lta byed la sogs pa ming du mas bsnyad du yod la ka lta bu ni gzhan gyis ma yin pa sa 'gyur med dang / byany+dza na ste ming tshig mtha' dag 'dis gsal bas na gsal byed dang / warna ste don mda' dag 'dis brjod pa'i phyir rjod byed kyang yin zhing de nyid lha'i skad kyi dbang gis dbyangs yig bcu drug dang / gsal byed sum cu rtsa gsum du bsdu ba sogs skad kyi bye brag dang skabs thob las sna tshogs par 'gyur na'ang rigs mthun tshogs par byas pa'i dbyangs gsal gnyis su dbye ba tsam gyi sgo nas yi ge mtha' dag bsdus pa'i phyir A li ste a phreng dang kA li ste ka phreng gnyis su dbye'o/ /

“Letter” in the Sanskrit language is “akṣhara” which is dis- cussed in many ways such as “that which leads the eye”, “that which causes the eye to see”, and so on and, as for example in ཀ་, means “not by something else so unchanging”. Then in Sanskrit there is also “vyañjana” which, since it makes the entirety of names and phrases clear or explicit” is therefore “something that makes clear or explicit”. Then in Sanskrit there is also “varna” which, because it this expresses the entirety of the meaning is therefore “an expressor”. In the divine language, the individual circumstances of showing the particulars of the language cause the letters to be shown in various ways—they are summed up as sixteen vowels and thirty-three consonants, and so on. However, when they are categorized by type, they are only divided into two—vowels and consonants. Categorizing letters by type does includes every one of them so they are divided into the āli, that is, the “a string” and kāli, that is, “the ka string”.

de las gangs ri'i khrod 'dir 'jebs par brtsi pa'i skad la yongs su grags shing nye bar mkho ba ni A li'i bya ba gsal bar mtshon par byed pa'i yi ge i u e o bzhi dang / kA li mtshon par byed pa/ ka kha ga nga / ca cha ja nya/ ta tha da na/ pa pha ba ma/ tsa tsha dza wa/ zha za 'a ya/ ra la sha sa/ ha a ste sum cu tham pa yod do/ /

Of them, the language spoken in this region of snow-mountains has for its consensus and requisite letters: the four letters ཨི་, ཨུ་, ཨེ་, and ཨོ་ which are the indicators that explicate the functions of the āli; and the thirty that indicate the kāli—ཀ་ཁ་ག་ང་། ཅ་ཆ་ཇ་ཉ། ཏ་ཐ་ད་ན། པ་ཕ་བ་མ། ཙ་ཚ་ཛ་ཝ། ཞ་ཟ་འ་ཡ། ར་ལ་ཤ་ས། ཧ་ཨ་.
gnyis pa mtha' dpyad ni/
B. Critical Analysis

'di skabs 'grel byed snga ma kha cig gis/ a yig A lir bgrangs pa'i A li lnga dang kA li nyer dgur 'dod pa byung mod kyi mkhan po'i dgongs pa ma rtogs par gzu lum byas par snang ste rtsa ba las dngos 'gal du smras pa'i phyir/ 'o na brda sprod pa'i gtsug lag rnams las 'byung ba bzhin du 'dir yang yi ge tshogs pa mtshungs pa so sor bsdu bar mdzad na a yig kho na tshogs pa mi mtshungs par bskyal ba'i dgos pa ci zhig ces 'dri na 'di la sngon chad mkhas pa'i go sar bzhugs pa mang pos ro 'dzin g.yo bar ma mdzad kyang bshad par bya ste/

In regard to this, an earlier commentator did assert that the ཨ letter is to be counted with the āli to give five āli and twenty-nine kāli. However, the claim directly contradicts the text therefore is seen as a case just of making up something to suit his purposes without having understood what the master intended.
This raises the question that if we too were to put each of the letters into its appropriate group as has been done in the grammatical literature, why would the ཨ་ letter be singled out as not corresponding to the grouping it has been given? This is so provocative that many of the past experts, even though they are now dead and not moving, would speak out!

legs par sbyar ba'i skad la gsal byed srog can srog med gnyis su dbye ba'i srog de yin na dbyangs yin pas khyab pa'i phyir ka lta bu srog med rkyang pa brjod mi btub pa yin zhing / bod du'ang / legs zer ba lta bu la? yig e zhugs kyi rjes su ga? sa? srog med sbyar ba sogs 'ga' zhig la rigs 'gre nus kyang / mgo can/ 'phul can/ 'dogs can sogs kyi rnam gzhag mdzad pas mtha' gcig tu srog can srog med kyi dbye ba de bde ba'ang ma yin zhing 'jug par dka' pa dang / dgos pa lhag por mi che bas de lta'i rnam gzhag ma mdzad do/ /
de bas na brjod du med pa'i srog med rkyang pa 'dir mi 'dod cing a yig de ka la sogs par zhugs pa'i tha snyad byar med pas des de dag la A li'i bya ba gsal bar byed ma nus pa'i phyir kA li'i sde tshan du 'dren par mdzad pa yin no/ /

In spoken Sanskrit, the consonants are differentiated into “breathed” and “un-breathed” portions. That “breathed” part is exactly the vowel because of which a consonant like “ka” which is the bare un-breathed portion is not pronounceable. In Tibetan, too, it is possible to make such a separation, for example in ལེགས་—which would be taken as ལ྄་ “l” with ཨེ་ “e” on it followed by un-breathed ག྄ “g”and ས྄་ “s”—and others but, since super-fix containing, fronted, sub-fix-containing, and so on letters were classified, that separation into breathed and un-breathed is not only complex but difficult to apply in a final, encompassing way and, since there is no other great need for it, that kind of classifica- tion was not made. Following on from that, an inexpressible, bare un-breathed portion is not asserted and there is no convention of ཀ་ “ka”, and so on having an ཨ “a” letter in place on them made, thus, because that ཨ “a” letter is not able to show the āli function for them, it was taken into the kāli section.

'o na mkhan pos yi ge srog med kyi rnam gzhag ma mdzad na/ 'og tu de la A li bzhi pa sbyar sogs ji ltar 'grel ce na/ de ni srog med la A li zhugs pa'i don ma yin gyi kA li de dag nyid la rna ru sogs sbyar ba'i don yin te/ gi gu zhabs kyu/ 'greng bu/ rnam ru bzhi la i u e o bzhir btags pa'i phyir dang de dag gis ka lta bu'i sgra'i ngo bor der ki ku ke ko sogs sgra'i khyad par skyed nus pas A li'i bya ba gsal bar mtshon nus pa tsam la dgongs nas A li'i sgrar yang gsungs pa'i phyir ro/ / des na kA li sum cu pa la A li dang po sbyar bas i yig tu 'grub pa sogs yin pas de dag gi a yig ni brjod don rjes 'brel du byas pa'i phyir dbyi bar bya ba nyid do/ /

Faced with that, there might be the question, “If the master did not make the classification of un-breathed letters, how do you explain his statement “connection of the four āli to that” and so on, further down in the treatise?” That line does not mean “putting āli in place on the un-breathed, rather, it is about the connection of the rna.ru and so on to the kāli themselves. It is so because the four—gi.gu, zhabs.kyu, ’greng.bu, and sna.ro—were designated as the four ཨི་ཨུ་ཨེ་ཨོ་ and because, intending just that, since they are able to generate the particular sounds of ཀི་ཀུ་ཀེ་ཀོ་, and so on, on the entity of the sounds of such as ཀ་, they are able to explicitly indicate the function of the āli, he also stated that they were the sounds of the āli. Thus, since connecting the first āli to the thirtieth kāli does produce an ཨི་ letter, and so on, then, because the ཨ letter belonging to them has made a subsequent connection to what is actually expressed, it is to be erased.

'dir kha cig gi gu la sogs pa kho na 'dir bstan gyi A li yin na de dbyangs yig ma yin par 'gyur te/ dbyangs ni nga ro'i rnam pa can yin zhing de dag ni gsal byed gzhan la ma ltos par 'don du med pa'i phyir zhes dogs pa skye ba srid kyang skyon med de/ dngos su 'dir A li srog zhugs gyi rnam gzhag ma mdzad kyang mtshon byed tsam la brten nas dbyangs kyi bya ba gsal bar mtshon nus pa la dgongs pa'i phyir dang / de lta ma yin na legs sbyar ltar a i 'dus pas e sogs su 'gyur bar khas len dgos pa'i skyon yang yod pa'i phyir ro/ /

At this point, one person has said, “It is that just the gi.gu, and so on are being show here, that is correct, still, if they were āli, they would change to not being spoken vowels, because a spoken vowel is that which has the aspect of a tone and it cannot be pronounced except in dependence on some other consonant”. This kind of concern could be raised but there is no fault because, although he did not make an explicit classification of breathed āli in place, he intended that just the indicators themselves would explicitly indicate the function of the spoken vowels and besides, if it were not so, there would be the fault that one would have to assert, like in Sanskrit, the combining of ཨ་ “a” and ཨི “i” changing to ཨེ་ “e” and so on.

de ltar gzhung 'di'i skabs su yi ge bsdu tshul tsam du ma zad gsal byed ces pa la'ang mang pos 'bru gnon log par byas 'dug pas kho bos legs par bshad pa 'di ni snang byed kyi nyi ma chen po ltar bsten par 'os so/ /

Here the text, put the way it is, not only groups the letters but also has the so-called consonants done such that in many cases they precisely pick out the bits. Thus, this excellent explanation of his is worthy of attending to as a great, illuminating sun.
gsung btus
Excerpts (from Tibetan Grammar by Alexander Graf)
yul gangs can pa'i brda yang dag par sbyor ba'i bstan bcos kyi bye brag sum cu pa dang rtags kyi 'jug pa'i gzhung gi rnam par bshad pa mkhas pa'i mkhul rgyan mu tig phreng mdzes
Beautiful Pearl Necklace Adorning the Neck of Scholars: A Thorough Commentary on the Texts Sum cu pa and Rtags kyi ’jug pa, Quintessence of the Śāstra of Correct Grammar in the Land of Snow.
Si tu'i 'grel chen
Si tu’s Great Commentary.

bod skad la rnam dbye brgyad du phyes pa de/ rgya gar gyi skad la dpe blangs pa yin kyang/ dpe de don la mi 'byor mi nyung ba zhig yod pa ni/ sgra la gzigs rtogs gnang ba'i mkhas pa sus kyang shes/ skad rigs gzhan pa'i shan shor du ma bcug par/ bod skad rang gi grub lugs dang khyad chos mtshon thub pa zhig gi steng nas gzhi rtsa 'dzin dgos so//

The analysis of Tibetan into eight cases is based on a Sanskrit model. But the model does not work in many occasions. Every scholar who pays attention to grammar knows that very well. Avoiding the bad habit of copying other languages, one should describe the Tibetan language only on the basis of its own structure and specificities.
[…] smag la sgron me bteg pa bzhin du shākya'i bstan pa byang phyogs su rgyas pa'i lam gyi thog ma snang bar gyur to/ zhes grags so/
it is said that the path of Shakyamuni’s teaching started to spread in the north, similar to a lamp raised in the darkness.

sngon lha sras yab kyi ring la/ ā cārya bo dhi satva dang/ ye shes dbang po dang/ zhang rgyal nyen nya bzang dang/ blon khri gzher sang shi dang/ lo tsā ba dznyā na de ba ko ṣa dang/ lce khyi 'brug dang/ bram ze ā nanda la sogs pas chos kyi skad bod la ma grags pa las ming du btags pa mang dag cig mchis pa'i nang nas kha cig chos kyi gzhung dang/ byā ka ra ṇa'i lugs dang mi mthun te/ mi bcos su mi rung ba rnams kyang bcos/ skad kyi ming gces so 'tshal gyis kyang bsnan nas theg pa che chung gi gzhung las ji ltar 'byung ba dang/ gna'i mkhan po chen po nā gā rdzu na dang/ ba su bandhu la sogs pas ji ltar bshad pa dang/ byā ka ra ṇa'i sgra'i lugs las ji skad du 'dren pa dang yang bstun te/

Earlier, during the time of the father (i.e. Khri srong lde btsan; r. 755-797) of the divine son (i.e. Khri lde srong btsan), a great corpus of terms had been coined from the Dharma language [previously] unknown in Tibet by Ācāryabodhisattva, Ye shes dbang po, Zhang Rgyal nyen nya bzang, the minister Khri bzher sang shi, the translator Jñānadevakoṣa, Lce Khyi ’brug, the brahmin Ananda and others. Among these [terms], some had to be inevitably amended due to their discordance with the Dharma sources and the grammatical system (= vyākaraṇa). Furthermore, [this corpus of terms] was augmented by all the nomenclature that was deemed important. Then [these terms] were [coined] in accordance with the way they occur in the scriptures of the higher and lower vehicles, the way they were explained by earlier masters, such as Nāgārjuna, Vasubandhu and others, and the way they are derived from the linguistic system of vyākaraṇa.

dbul ba 'joms byed rnyed dka' rin po che/ bgrod dka' rgya mtsho che la gnas pa dag legs par gru btsugs dar phyar rlung gis bskyod/ rin chen thob byed gzhan du thabs med bzhin/ sdug bsngal 'joms byed dam chos rin po che/ rtogs dka' gsung rab rgya mtsho dag la gnas/ yi ge ming dang tshig gi 'bru btsugs te/ sgra yi dar phyar shes rab rlung gis bskyod/ dam chos thob byed gzhan du thabs med do/

The poverty’s conqueror, the jewels difficult to find dwell in the great ocean difficult to traverse. Having built a proper boat [and] hoisted the sail, moved by the wind [one] attains the jewel. Other than that, there is no way. Likewise, the jewel [which is] the suffering’s conqueror, the noble Dharma, dwells in the ocean of Buddha’s word (gsung rab) difficult to realize. Having built the boat of letters (yi ge), free, lexical word forms (ming) and syntactic forms (tshig) and hoisted the sail of linguistics, moved by the wind of wisdom [one] attains the noble Dharma. Other than that, there is no way.

dam pa'i chos bsgyur ba'i lugs ni don dang yang mi 'khal la bod skad la yang gar bde bar gyis shig dharmma bsgyur ba la rgya gar gyi skad kyi go rims las mi bsnor ba bod kyi skad du bsgyur na don dang tshig tu 'grel zhing bde na ma bsnor bar sgyur cig bsnor na bde zhing go ba bskyed pa cig yod na/ tshigs bcad la ni rtsa ba bzhi pa'am/ drug pa'ang rung ste/ tshigs su bcad pa gcig gi nang na gang bde ba bsnor zhing sgyur cig rkyang pa la ni don gang snyegs pa yan chad kyi tshig dang don gnyis ka la gar bde bar bsnor zhing sgyur cig

As for the manner of translating the sublime Dharma: It must not contradict the meaning (don dang [...] mi ’khal ba), but it must also be done in a way that is accessible (~ easy [to read/understand]; bde ba) in Tibetan language. When translating Dharma, if translated into the Tibetan language without deviating from the Sanskrit structure (go rims), then under the condition that it is coherent and accessible in content as well as syntax (don dang tshig tu ’brel zhing bde). If [one] deviates [from the Sanskrit structure], then under the condition that it is accessible and comprehensible: As for verses, four or also six lines are suitable, and within one single verse line one may deviate and translate whatever is accessible/easy [for the reader]. As for prose, one may deviate and translate whatever is accessible in terms of both syntax and content (tshig dang don gnyis ka la gar bde), [as long as the syntax/phrasing (tshig) and content/meaning (don) remain] within the boundaries of the meaning pursued [by the translated text].

mkhas par khas 'che ba 'ga' zhig sgra tsam gyi rnam gzhag dang/ ming sgrub pa la rnams [sic!] par dbye ba'i rkyen ster ba dang/ khams sgrub pa la ti ngan ta'i rkyen ster ba dang/ byed pa'i tshig la bzhi dang drug la sogs pa'i sbyor ba dang/ dpe la dngos dang bzlog pa la sogs pa'i khyad par dang/ tshig gi rgyan la rang bzhin dang/ rdzas dang yon tan brjod pa la sogs pa'i dbye ba dang/ dbye ba sgo tha dad pa'i tshul dang/ bsdu ba la spyi bye brag gis sgo nas ji ltar sdud pa dang/ grangs nges pa la dngos 'gal rnam par gcod pa dang/ log rtog bzlog pa dang/ dgos pa'i sgo nas ji ltar nges pa dang/ go rims la tshig dang don gyi rim pas brjod bde zhing rtogs sla ba'i sbyor ba la gangs can gyi khrod 'di na legs par ma sbyangs pa'i skye bo phal cher 'khrul par mthong nas/ de la phan pa'i don du mkhas pa 'jug pa'i sgo 'di bshad do/

Some here in the snowy mountain ranges [of Tibet] who claim to be learned are not well trained in the analysis of sound itself, in providing the grammatical affixes for nominal inflection of a formed word, in providing the grammatical affixes (ti ngan ta) in verbal formation, in applying the four, six, etc. kārakas, in distinguishing such things as the object (dngos, vastu) and the reversal (bzlog pa, viparyāsa) in an analogy, in the nature of verbal ornamentation, in distinguishing among such things as expressions of substance and quality, in the different methods for divisions and headings, in how to summarize based on the general and subheadings in a summary, in deciding among opposing [positions] in reckoning and ascertainment (grangs nges pa), in eliminating wrong views, in how to get a definitive ascertainment by way of the purpose, and in joining the order of words and meanings in a structure that is pleasant to say and easy to understand, and so [they] are, for the most part, mistaken. This Gateway of Learning is related for their benefit.

rig pa'i gnas lnga dag la mkhas par ma byas par// 'phags mchog gis kyang thams cad mkhyen nyid mi 'gyur te// gzhan dag tshar gcad rjes su gzung bar bya phyir dang// rang nyid kun shes bya phyir de la de brtson byed//

Without becoming a scholar in the five sciences Not even the supreme sage can become omniscient. For the sake of refuting and supporting others, And for the sake of knowing everything himself, he makes an effort in these [five sciences].
gang dag thar mchog bde chen dbyig thob phyir/ des don snying po'i rgya mtshor 'jug 'dod na/ ming tshig brjod gzhi yi ge'i sbyor ba'i gru/ blo ldan ded dbon tshogs kyis bsten bya yin/

For attaining the treasure of liberation and highest joy, if one wishes to enter the seas of quintessence and definitive meaning, the basis of free, lexical words (ming), syntactic forms (tshig) and sentences (brjod pa), the boat of applying letters, is to be relied on by those helmsmen gifted with acumen.

dbul po'i rigs skyes mu to ba rnams kyis// nor bu 'ching bu'i bye brag mi shes shing// brgya lam dbyig mchog rin chen thob gyur kyang// don ldan byi dor cho ga shes mi srid// de bzhin sgra rig mi shes mkhas rloms kyis// legs bshad nyes bshad dbye ba mi shes shing// dam pa'i gzhung bzang 'chad par rloms pa yang// phal cher tshig don log par 'phyan pa mang//

Beggars, people destitute and poor, Do not know the arts of formal dress. And if they chance to gain a precious jewel,
They know not how to don it to impress. Just so fake scholars know not language arts, And don’t distinguish eloquence from chatter. They vainly teach the good and holy scriptures, Yet mostly stray from words that actually matter.
ci phyir deng dus skye bo phal mo che// blun po 'khor mang stobs 'byor ldan pa'am// rmongs pa mkhas snyems zol zob gyon can la// mkhas par bstod cing ri bong cal rjes 'jug//
Why do the masses around today, Chase fools like rabbits, chattering praise? These fools with power, wealth, and command, Are idiots posing as scholars – a scam!
gang ci'i gsung 'phros smar [sic!] bar byung song yang lo tsā ba mi mkhas pa dag bar du bcug dgos pa'i stabs kyis chos phyogs kyi gsung 'phros 'dra ni cher byung ma song/
Whatever conversation came up, it was necessary to bring in the unlearned translators, for which reason a real conversation on Dharma could not take place for the bigger part.
[…] chos ldan gyi bya ba dang phal cher bzlog tu med pa'i gzhan dbang gi khol po […]
duties related to the Dharma as well as mostly not declinable obligations outside of [his] control,

de las sum cu pa dang rtags kyi 'jug pa gnyis kho na deng sang gi bar du yod cing/ mkhas blun mang pos 'grel bshad kyi khur blangs pas don gzhan dang gzhan du 'don pa'i glegs bam gyi phreng bar gyur mod/ 'on tang rnam dpyod dang ldan pa kha cig gis rigs pa'i mda' rnon gyis phug pas gzhung don mang po zhig dpyis pyin par gyur cing/ phal cher ni byang pyhogs 'dir gtsug lag gnyis ka bar du nyams pa'i dbang las bshad rgyun dang bstan bcos kyi yan lag gzhan ma tshang ba'i phyir mi gsal ba rnams kha khral 'jal ba tsam las don du gnas par ma mngon pas/ bdag lta bus mtha' gcig tu bshad par sla ba ma yin kyang blo gros kyi nor dang ldan pa gzhan dag gis kyang ched du bskul ba dang/ rang nyid gzhung khyad par du 'phags pa 'di dag la 'jug par 'dod pa'i spro ba brtas pas rjes dpag gsum gyis ji ltar dpag pa dgrol bar bya'o/

Of these [eight treatises originally composed by master Thon mi Saṃbhoṭa], only the two, Sum cu pa and Rtags kyi ’jug pa, are preserved up to the present day. Since many learned ones as well as fools have taken on the burden of a commentary, a series of works expounding this and that interpretation (~ don) has emerged. Yet, while some with the gift of thorough analysis have pierced the treatises’ meaning with the sharp arrow of reasoning, thus clarifying much of it, the majority [of explanations] lacks clarity, because the transmission as well as the remaining branches of the [eight] treatises are incomplete due to their downfall between the two disseminations (gtsug lag gnyis ka bar du ?) here in the north (i.e. Tibet). Apart from paying tribute [to master Thon mi], they appear to miss the [texts’] meaning (don du gnas par mi mngon). Consequently, even though a definitive explanation (mtha’ gcig tu bshad pa) is not easy for someone like me (bdag lta bus), after others gifted with the jewel of intellect also requested it and, as for myself, being full of enthusiasm, wishing to engage in these two sublime treatises, [I] will elaborate how to measure [them] by means of the three inferences (rjes dpag gsum).

[…] zhes smos te bstan bcos 'da [sic!] dpyad pa gsum gyis rnam par dag pas rjes 'jug rnams kyis 'phags yul nas bsgyur pa'i bstan bcos khyad par 'phags pa rnams dang mtshungs par lta zhing don du gnyer rigs so zhes 'doms pa'i don du thu mi nyid kyis bsgyur pa'i mdo rgyud rnams kyi 'gyur phyag dang mthun par 'phags pa 'jam dpal la phyag mdzad pa'o/

[The root text SCP] says the following [through the translator’s homage]: For the sake of expounding that, due to [its] full purity (rnam par dag pa) by means of the threefold analysis, it is reasonable to aspire towards this śāstra (= SCP and TKJ) and regard it as equivalent to those noble śāstras translated from the Noble Land by [his] successors, Thu mi payed homage to Mañjughoṣa in accordance with the translator’s homage of the sūtras and tantras he himself translated.

de la 'dod pa snga ma de ni shin tu 'khrul te/ rjes 'jug sa ra da gsum gyi mthar su ru du rnams 'jug zer ba nyi tshe zhig gzhung 'dis bstan par song bas ru dang du gnyis kyi 'jug yul da dung gzhan yang yod na gzhung 'dis mi ston pa'i rgyu mtshan 'thad ldan smra dgos shing/ rgyu mtshan med na ni gzhung gi bstan bya ma tshang ba'i skyon du 'gyur ba […]

As regards that first assumption, it is strongly deluded for the following reason: if this text (SCP) should have taught such a half-finished statement (zer ba nyi tshe zhig) that su, ru [and] du join at the end of the three postscript letters sa, ra [and] du, one has to give a plausible reason (rgyu mtshan ’thad ldan), [why], given there are still also other letters (~ yul) which the two ru and du join to, this text did not teach [these]. If there is no reason, the error follows that the content of the text is incomplete. […]

[…] 'grel byed kha cig gis/ lhag bcas kyi sgra ste kho nar 'dod pa ni mi 'thad de/ gong smos ltar rjes 'jug 'ga' zhig la ste sbyar ba klog dka' ba'i skyon dang/ de yig lhag bcas kyi don can 'jug pa'i skabs mi 'byung ba'i skyon dang/ sngon gyi glegs bam dag pa rnams la yongs su grags pa dang 'gal ba'i skyon yang yod pa'i phyir ro/

[…] Regarding some commentators’ assumption that ste is the only morpheme [in the function] of lhag bcas, it is not apt, because there is the fault, as stated above, that the application of ste with some postscript letters is difficult to read, and the fault that there would be no possibility for letter de to join in the meaning of lhag bcas as well as the fault that it contradicts the common convention in the pure books of earlier [times].
gzhan yang bod yig gi sdeb ji ltar sbyor ba'i tshul ni sngon gyi bod skad dag pa nyid la brjod pa'i sgra ji ltar 'byung ba de ltar mkhan po 'dis sbyar ba yin […]

Furthermore, regarding the mode of how to combine Tibetan letters (bod yig gi sdeb ji ltar sbyor ba’i tshul), this master [Thon mi] applied the sounds/morphemes (sgra) as [they] occurred [in] the pronunciation of the pure Tibetan language itself of the past (sngon gyi bod skad dag pa nyid la brjod pa).

da drag can gyi mthar to la sogs pa 'thob pa'i don ni/ […] spyir btang rjes 'jug la ltos pa'i rnam dbye dang phrad rnams la/ sbyor yul ming tshig gi mtha' de dang sbyar bas brjod pa bde zhing sgra mthun pa yod na rtags mthsungs nyid sbyar bar bya zhing/ de lta bu med na'am yod kyang brjod mi bde na brjod bde ba gang yin sbyar bar bya ba yin pa dang/ de dag kyang 'jig rten gyi grags pa'i rjes su 'brang dgos pas rjes 'jug gzhan rnams rang rang la rna ru sogs sbyar bar rtags mthsungs min ci rigs yod kyang brjod bde ba dang drags zhing grub pa'i phyir 'od pa yin […]

As for the point that the ending of [a word] with da drag (= secondary postscript da) takes to, etc.: […] In general, regarding the cases and [syntactic] links that are dependent on the postscript letter (rjes ’jug la ltos pa’i rnam dbye dang phrad rnams), if there is an easy pronunciation and morphological/phonological agreement (brjod bde zhing sgra mthun pa), [then] the concordant sign (rtags mthsungs) is to be applied directly (~ nyid). Yet, regardless of whether or not there is such a [concordant sign that is easy pronounceable and morphological/phonological agreeing], if not easy to pronounce, whatever is easier to pronounce is to be applied. And since the [other postscript letters] also must follow worldly convention (’jig rten gyi grags pa), it is apt to apply rna ru (= vowel ‘o’) at the end of the other postscript letters as such, no matter if it is the concordant sign or not, because it is easier to pronounce (brjod bde), commonly known/used (grags pa) and established (grub pa) [in that way]. […]
ming mtha' de dag nyid kyis ni// de nyid rang gi sgra mthun pa'i// chos dngos las dang byed pa dang// sbyin dang 'byung khungs 'brel pa gnas dang bod pa'i sgra yang drang//

By these very word endings (ming mtha’), in morphological agreement with themselves, [the syntactic links] chos dngos, las, byed pa sbyin,’byung khungs, ’brel ba, gnas dang// and also the morpheme for bod pa are triggered.

smra sgo rtsa 'grel dang smra ba kun la 'jug pa'i sgra'i bstan bcos rtsa 'grel 'di rnams la'ang mi 'thad pa shin tu mang zhing mkhas pa gzhan gyis gnad [sic!] byed brjod pa gnad du song ba'ang mang bar snang bas 'phags yul mkhas pa'i legs bshad ni min par nges mod/ 'on kyang sum cu pa'i skabs su 'ga' zhig drangs pa sogs gzhung 'di'i don dang skabs 'gar mthun pa'i legs bshad mang dag kyang 'dug pas rnam pa kun tu 'dor bya ni ma yin no/

Root text and commentary of the Speech Door (Smra sgo) as well as root text and commentary of the Linguistic Śāstra Pertaining to all Speech (Smra ba kun la ’jug pa’i sgra’i bstan bcos) not only convey plenty of inadequacies (mi ’thad pa), but there also seem to [be] many trenchant refutations expressed by other scholars (mkhas pa gzhan gyi gnod byed brjod pa gnas du song ba). Therefore, [these texts] are not the lucid exposition of scholars [of] the Noble Land. However, since [they] also contain numerous lucid explanations which on several occasions agree with the content of these texts (= SCP and TKJ), e.g. some derivations (’ga’ zhig drangs pa ?) in the SCP, they are not to be rejected in all respect.
P 2.3.2 karmaṇi dvitīyā
If there is a karman, a second [vibhakti occurs].
P 2.3.4 antarāntareṇa yukte
In connection with antarā (‘in between’) and antareṇa (‘without’), [a second vibhakti occurs].
tshig gang zhig rang la bstan par bya ba'i don med cing gzhan la phan 'dogs shing gsal bar byed pa de ni tshig gi phrad ces bya ste/ dper na lcags gnyis sbyor bar byed pa'i tsha la lta bu'o/

Any word form (tshig gang zhig) that has no meaning on its own to be indicated and benefits as well as clarifies [the meaning of] another [word form] is called syntactic link (tshig gi phrad, lit. ‘connection of syntactically functioning word forms, phrases, subclauses, or other syntactic forms’), for example like the solder that attaches two iron pieces.
[…] tshig gi phrad ces bya ba ni spyir ming tsam gnyis sam du ma sbrel ba'i tshe bar du mtshams sbyor ba'am don gsal ba la phan 'dogs par byed […]

[…] Regarding ‘syntactic link’ (tshig gi phrad), in general, whenever two or more mere lexical word forms (ming tsam) are combined together (sbrel ba), [a syntactic link] connects between [them] (bar du mtshams sbyor ba) and benefits the clarification of the meaning (don gsal ba la phan ’dogs par byed) […].
de ltar na 'khor 'das kyi dngos po'i don brjod par bya ba rnams brjod par byed pa'i tha snyad thams cad ni brgyad po 'di las ma 'das shing/ 'dir ma 'dus pa'ang gcig kyang med pa kho na'o/

Accordingly, regarding all terms (tha snyad thams cad) which express the meanings to be expressed of a real phenomenon in saṃsāra or nirvāṇa (ʼkhor ʼdas kyi dngos po), they do not exceed these eight [cases], nor are there any [such terms] which are not included in them.

rnam dbye zhes pa ni legs sbyar gyi skad la ming gi mthar sbyar bas tshig tu 'grub par byed pa'i rkyen si sogs bdun gsum nyi shu rtsa gcig po rnams te/ don thob kyi dbang gis don rjod par byed pa'i skad rigs thams cad la rnam dbye de rnams med pa mi srid pas mkhan po 'dis bod kyi skad la'ang legs sbyar dang bstun nas rnam dbye de rnams kyi 'jug pa gsal bar mdzad pa yin no/

’Case’ [refers] to 21 – seven times three – suffixes in Sanskrit, such as si, etc., which complete/accomplish (’grub par byed pa) a word through their application at the end of a nominal stem. However, actually for all languages that express meaning it is impossible that these cases do not exist, and therefore this teacher here has elucidated the application of these cases in accordance with Sanskrit also for the Tibetan language.
gzhan dag bdag la mi dga' ba/ des ni tshe 'di 'am tshe gzhan la/ bdag la za bar mi byed na/ bdag ni ci phyir de mi 'dod/
If the repugnance/disfavour [of] others towards me does not consume me in this life or another, why do I dislike it?
bslab pa kun gyi gzhi 'dzin cing// rig byed smra ba rnams kyi rgyu// ming tshig brjod pa kun gyi gzhi// yi ge'i sbyor ba bshad par bya//
The fundament of all [Buddhist] teachings, the cause of the proclamation of the Vedas, the basis for expressing all lexical word forms and syntactic forms, the application of letters will be taught.
P 1.4.14 suptiṅantaṃ padam
[A] pada [is that which either] ends [in a] nominal suffix (sup) [or a] verbal suffix (tiṅ).
P 1.2.45 arthavad adhātur apratyayaḥ prātipadikam
[A] prātipadika [is that which is] meaningful, neither a verbal root (dhātu) nor a suffix (pratyaya).
P 1.3.1 bhūvādayo dhātavaḥ
[A] dhātu [is] bhū (‘to be’) etc.
AK 2.47 a-b: nāmakāyādayaḥ saṃjñāvākyākṣarasamuktayaḥ
nāmakāya, etc., are the groups of saṃjñā, vākya, and akṣara.

AKBh on AK 2.47 a-b: ādigrahaṇena padavyañjanakāyagrahaṇam/ tatra saṃjñākaraṇaṃ nāma, tad yathā rūpaṃ śabda ity evam ādi/ ‘vākyaṃ padam’, yāvatā 'rthaparisamāptiḥ/ tad yathā anityā bata saṃskārā ity evam ādi/ yena kriyā-guṇa-kāla-sambandha-viśeṣā gamyante/

The word ‘etc.’ denotes padakāya and vyañjanakāya. Among these [groups which are mentioned in the kārikā], nāman is the same as saṃjñākaraṇa, as when we say ‘colour’, ‘sound’, etc. [By] ‘vākya’ [mentioned in the kārikā,] [we mean] pada [by which term we do not mean a ‘word’, but a set of words, used] in so far as a meaning (idea?) is brought to complete expression. For instance: ‘impermanent are the saṃskāras’, etc. [A pada is defined as that] by which the specific relations of action, quality, and time are known.

padaṃ tu suptiṅantaṃ padaṃ gr̥ hyate/ tenātha ‘yāvatārthaparisamāptis tad yathā anityā bata saṃskārāḥ ity evam ādi' iti/ ādiśabdena utpādavyayadharmiṇaḥ, utpadya hi nirudhyante, teṣāṃ vyupaśamaḥ sukham ity evam ādi/

Pada is [usually, by the grammarians,] taken [in the meaning of] that which has a nominal or verbal ending. Therefore [i.e. in order to preclude this interpretation] the author says: ‘in so far as a meaning (idea?) is brought to complete expression. For instance: impermanent are the saṃskāras, etc.’ By ‘etc.’ [the rest of Śakra’s words are meant]: having as attributes birth and decay, for having been born they die; their cessation is happiness. And so on.

Kātyāyana's Vārttika 9 on P 2.1.1: sāvyayakārakaviśeṣaṇaṃ vākyam iti vākyavido vadanti/ tad yathā pacati paṭhati gacchatīti, kr̥ ṣṇo gauro raktaḥ iti, pacati pakṣyaty apākṣīd iti kriyā-guṇa-kālānāṃ sambandhaviśeṣā gamyante tat padam/

The [Pāṇinian] experts on vākya say that vākya [sentence] is what has indeclinable words and kāraka as qualifiers. [But according to Vasubandhu,] that is pada, whereby are known specific relations connected with action: e.g., is cooking, is reading, is going – with quality: e.g., black, white, red – and with time: e.g. is cooking, will be cooking, has cooked.
ākhyātaṃ sāvyayakārakaviśeṣaṇaṃ vākyam
A sentence is a finite verb qualified by avyayas (indeclinables) and kārakas.
ekatiṅ
[A sentence is that which has] one [word form ending in] tiṅ.
tathā hi sāmānye vartamānānāṃ padānāṃ yad viśeṣe 'vasthānam sa vākyārtha ity āhuḥ/ tad evaṃ svalakṣaṇābhidyotakaṃ nāma kriyādisambandhaviśeṣābhiyotakaṃ padam ity uktaṃ bhavati/

Thus, it is said [by Patañjali in his Mahābhāṣya on P 1.2.45 that] ‘the sentence meaning represents the particularization (= contextualization) of [the meanings of] these words which otherwise have generic [= uncontextualized, lexical] meanings.’ Likewise, it is said [by Vasubandhu] that that which indicates a svalakṣaṇa is nāma [and] that which indicates a specification of relations of action, etc. is pada.

de la ming ni don gyi ngo bo brjod par byed pa ste gzugs zhes pa lta bu'o/ ngag ni tshig ste don gyi khyad par ston pa kye ma 'dus byas rnams mi rtag ces bya ba la sogs ba'am/ bstan du med la thogs pa dang bcas pa'i gzugs zhes bya ba lta bu ji tsam gyis don yongs su rdzogs pa (ra ston pa bstan bcos la sogs pa) ste/ tshig gang gis lhas byin (dkar sham) 'gro zhes ba la sogs pa'i bya ba dang/ kha dog dkar sham la sogs pa'i yon tan dang/ btsos so 'tshed do 'tshed par 'gyur ro zhes pa la sogs pa (ngo bo dang yon tan dang bya ba dang) dus kyi 'brel ba'i khyad par rtogs par 'gyur ro/

As regards ming, it expresses the essence of a meaning (don gyi ngo bo) as in ‘form’ (gzugs). As regards a sentence (ngag) it is tshig. [This] is the indication of a qualification/specification of [that] meaning (don gyi khyad par), a full completion of the meaning to the extent [of that qualification] as in ‘Oh, impermanent are the saṃskāras (’dus byas)’ or ‘the form which cannot be indicated and is endowed with resistance’ [A sentence is] any tshig, by which [the meaning’s] qualification [in terms] of connections of action, such as ‘Devadatta goes’ (lhas byin ’gro), qualities, such as ‘pure colour’ (kha dog bkar sham), or time, such as ‘having cooked,’ ‘cooking,’ ‘will be cooking’ (btsos so, ’tsed do,’tsed par ’gyur ro), is comprehended.
su banta'i rkyen gyis sgra sgrub pa'i tshul 'di saṃ skrīta la shin tu dgos mod/ bod kyi skad la mi dgos pa'i phyir re zhig gzhag go

This system of accomplishing a word form (~ sgra sgrub pa) by means of the subanta- suffixes is very much required for Sanskrit, yet [I] ignore [it] for the time being, since it has no need in Tibetan language.
ming ni chos rnams kyi ngo bo nyid kyi tshig bla dwags te yi ge 'dus pa'i bdag nyid do/
Regarding ming, it is a designation (tshig bla dwags) of the essence of phenomena (chos rnams kyi ngo bo nyid), an entity of collected letters (yi ge ’dus pa’i bdag nyid).
tshig ni chos rnams kyi khyad par gyi tshig bla dwags yin te ming 'dus pa'i bdag nyid can no/
Regarding tshig, it is a designation (tshig bla dwags) of the specification/qualification of phenomena (chos rnams kyi khyad par), an entity of collected ming (ming ’dus pa’i bdag nyid can).
de la rgyu ni dper na rdul 'dus pa las gong bu grub pa na de nyid dang gzhan du brjod du med pa bzhin yi ge 'dus pa las ming 'grub ste/

Regarding the cause for this [ming], for example like a lump that results from a gathering (= collection) of dust particles cannot be said to be separate from these very [dust particles], a ming results from a gathering (= collection) of letters/phonemes.
de la rgyu ni ming ngo/ rang gi ngo bo ni de 'dus pas don gyi khyad par brjod pa'o/
Regarding the cause for this [tshig], it is ming. [Tshig’s] essential characteristic (~ rang gi ngo bo) is that it expresses the specification of a meaning through the collection of that [ming].

[…] tshig ces bya ba ni ming 'dus pa la bya ste/ ji ltar don gyi khyad par ston na ming gnyis sam/ ming mang po 'dus kyang rung ste tshig ces bya'o/ 'di ltar ka ba ring po zhes brjod na ka ba'i khyad par rjod par byed do/ de bzhin du ka ba ring po 'di ni dkar po'o zhes bya ba la sogs pa'ang tshig ces bya'o/

[…] So-called ‘tshig’ is to be regarded as a collection/combination of ming. If [it is asked] how a specification of meaning (don gyi khyad par) is indicated, either two ming or multiple ming are suitable and are called tshig. Likewise, if one says ‘long pillar’ (ka ba ring po), a specification of the pillar is being expressed. Similarly, also ‘Regarding this long pillar, [it is] white.’ (ka ba ring po ’di ni dkar po’o) and the like are called tshig.

ming gnyis 'dus pas don gyi khyad par brjod pa sangs rgyas ni skyabs so zhes pa lta bu dang/ ming mang po 'dus pas don gyi khyad par brjod pa chos thams cad bdag med pa'o zhes pa lta bu'o/ de bzhin du 'du byas mi rtag pa'o zhes ming gnyis pa dang/ mya ngan las 'das pa sdug bsngal thams cad zhi ba'o/ zhes pa ming mang po 'dus pa yin te/ de ni chos mngon par gsungs pa'i tshig yin no/ brda sprod pa po la grags pa'i tshig ni/ ming la rnam dbye brgyad phye ba/ nyi shu rtsa bzhi sbyar ba dang/ byings la ti sogs sbyar ba yis/ rang rang don rnams 'byed pa'i tshig/

[Tshig is] the expression of a meaning’s specification through the combination of two ming, such as ‘The Buddha is the refuge.’ (sangs rgyas ni skyabs so), and the expression of a meaning’s specification through multiple ming, as in ‘All phenomena are selfless.’ (chos thams cad bdag med pa’o). Likewise, ‘The saṃskāras are impermanent.’ (’du byas mi rtag pa’o) [is the] combination of two ming and ‘Nirvāṇa [is the] pacification of all suffering’ (mya ngan las ’das pa sdug bsngal thams cad zhi ba’o) is the combination of multiple ming. This is pada [as] propounded in the Abhidharma. Pada [as] it is known to the grammarian (brda sprod pa po) is as follows: To a nominal stem (ming), eight cases distinguished [into] 24 suffixes are to be applied, and to the verbal roots (byings) ti, etc. are to be applied by which the individual meanings are distinguished. [That is the grammarian’s] pada.

bya [sic!] ka ra ṇa'i lugs la rnamd dbye'i mtha' can ni tshig go rnam dbye med pa ni ming ngo/ zhes 'byung yang/ bod skad la rnam dbye dang po'i gcig tshig ming tsam las logs su dbyer med cing/ dag dang rnams kyi phrad kyis gnyis tshig dang mang tshig mtshon yang da dung de dag gi mthar rnam dbye gzhan 'jug pa sogs kyis rnam gzhag de lta bu sbyar du mi rung ba dang/ chos mngon pa'i lugs kyi yi ge du ma 'dus pa las ming/ ming du ma 'dus pa las tshig ces gsungs pa'ang spyir btang rags pa tsam yin pas 'dir phra ba'i dbang du byas na mi 'byor […]

It occurs in the system of vyākaraṇa that a syntactic form (pada, tshig) is that which has a case ending (rnam dbye’i mtha’ can), and a nominal stem (prātipadika, ming) is that without a case (rnam dbye med pa). However, in Tibetan language the mere nominal stem (ming tsam) is not distinguishable from the singular of the first case, and although the dual and plural is indicated (mtshon) by the [syntactic] links dag and rnams, there is still another case joining (’jug) at their end. Due to this and other [reasons], this [Sanskrit grammatical] model (rnam gzhag de lta bu) is inapplicable. Furthermore, the teaching of the Abhidharmic system that from many letters [results] a lexical word form (ming) [and] from many lexical word forms [results] a syntactic form (pada) is merely general and rough, therefore not applicable from the perspective of a more detailed investigation here […].
ci phyir 'jug par byed ce na/ yi ge'i khongs nas ming dbyung ste/ ming gi khongs nas tshig phyung nas/ tshig gis don rnams ston par byed/
Why are [letters] joined? Out of letters, lexical word forms are to be brought forth, Out of lexical word forms, syntactic forms are brought forth and Through syntactic forms, meanings are indicated.

[…] skabs 'dir ni bod skad gzhir gzhag gis gang zhig yi ge gnyis sam mang po 'dus pa'ang rung don gyi ngo bo tsam ston pa'i sgra ni ming yin zhing/ ming de nyid rnam dbye'am phrad gang rung dang ldan pas don gyi khyad par ston par byed pa rnams ni tshig dang/ tshig mang po sprel nas don dang ldan pa'i ngag gi phreng bar grub pa ni brjod pa zhes bya'o/

[…] For our current context, therefore, taking Tibetan language as the basis, any indication of a mere essence of a meaning, regardless of whether two or more letters are combined, is a lexical word form/word stem (ming). And the indication of a specification of the meaning by that very lexical word form/word stem endowed with any case or [syntactic] link is a syntactic form (tshig). And after connecting many syntactic forms, the resulting speech sequence (ngag gi phreng bar grub pa) endowed with meaning is called ‘a sentence’ (brjod pa ?).
[…] byed pa pos bya ba la sbyor ba ston pas na gzhung gzhan du rnam dbye gsum pa zhes 'byung ba byed pa po'i sa re shes par bya'o/

[…] [The morphemes gis, kyis, ’is, yis and gyis], since they indicate the engagement of an agent in an action, are known as the semantic domain of the agent, which in other texts occurs as third case.
